In my opinion as an average voter and US citizen, this book is an overall accurate retelling of Trump's  first 9 months as President.The events, controversies, rumors and news reporting of the chaos at the time of the events are organized into a narrative that injects the visceral reactions of Trump's inner circle.I know Trump supporters who stopped listening to the news after Trump's election. Any negative item about him they did manage to hear was dismissed as "fake news" and a "what about Hilary?" This book can get them up to speed with the reality of the mess called the Trump Presidency.If you were one the millions of people who closely followed the real news reporting this past year, you may find the book a bit anticlimactic. We know all this. We know Donald Trump and almost his entire staff have no real expertise and qualifications for their position.The value of this book is putting the experience of the Trump/Bannon chaos into the historical record.

Had I confidence in knowing that President Trump had the wherewithal and skill to read anything longer than a fast food restaurant menu, I might easily accept his labeling this book as fake. The stories in this book are at once outlandish, disturbing and intriguing. So much so that I found myself having to take it in very small doses throughout.The authorâ€™s claimed frame of reference is the halls and waiting areas just outside Trumpâ€™s reach. Though the book is ultimately about Trump, his reach in the book never quite touches Trump and instead is completely filtered through the revolving cast of characters working with and around Trump. This point of view makes the book even more surreal as he paints those people as being as much flawed and overwhelmed as Trump himself. This altogether gives the book the sense of taking place in an old insane asylum.Within that sense is a back story about many of the events of the Trump presidency that has left me dumbfounded. The White House seems to be crazy from the outside. This story reinforces that with an even bigger story of crazy from the inside. Itâ€™s too much to explain. You have to read it to know.

Based on interviews of Michael Wolff on various news and entertainment outlets and the author's own statement that he had to stretch the truth in some instances just to let people realize the chaos in the White House was out of control.  I guess it's called being glib.  Anyway, most of what he writes about has been since verified but in the end the reader is left with more questions rather than answers about Trump's agenda.  Maybe that's because it's always been an agenda in progress subject to the daily whim of Trump himself.  It does prove one thing though and that is that Trump is definitely in over his head.  Whether or not Trump really wants or wanted to be President is also not answered.  He failed to address what everyone else is asking:  did Trump run for financial gain?  That is, there's lots to be gained by being a perpetual candidate in terms of usable money from campaign fund raising, a full war chest and the pitfalls for someone like Trump to fall into because of his dearth of ethics.  I need to re-read this book.  Maybe I missed something that was supposed to read between the lines.

This is an amazing book. Have watched Wolff's comments in interviews, read reviews, and find the current situation appalling and fascinating. Wolff has clearly explained Trump's win, and filled in background for readers. Helps make some sense of this last year. Events and outlooks in this book seem clearly accurate if you have been following politics. It didn't cheer me up, but it certainly helped me better understand current events. It also enforced my belief in our amazing Constitution. Perhaps, unless it is obvious, I should add that I am a Democrat. I do think that a lack of understanding of the Constitution's separation of powers, and an inability or unwillingness to honestly face this country's needs are  FAR more important, or should be, than party affiliation. As we watch  totally unqualified people given department head positions, and the blurring of lines when it comes to separations of powers, Wolff has helped fuel the fires of protesters. Although it's frightening that it needs to be said, loudly and often "COUNTRY OVER PARTY," Wolff's book was perfectly timed. And it's totally believable, sadly.

I pre-ordered this book primarily because Trump was opposed vehemently to its publication.  (The same reason, years ago, that I saw "The Last Temptation of Christ."  Local religious extremists were picketing the theater.)I cannot say that reading the book was enjoyable.  It reflects the troubling times we are in now and the likelihood of difficult times ahead.  And I am asked to trust this author regarding the details.  It would be easier for me if Wolff had been a journalist with the discipline imposed by a news editor.  As it is, the quotes and attributions stand as gossip (though I am inclined to believe most or all of them, since they appear to fit logically with information already public).The broad brush (e.g., "All of the senior staff...") may be true, but could a careful investigator not find a true believer among them?  I am certain that I could not work in this administration, but there must be one who is as devoted to Trump as I have been to other elected officials for whom I have worked.Did I learn anything?  Some details, perhaps, but not the big picture.  I had known that this president is a dangerously ignorant narcissist from his public statements.  Is his public persona (a childish, insecure man who holds grudges, lashes out at real or perceived opposition, and evidences no maturity) likely to be similar to his behavior in the White House? It seems probable.

So, have finished my first listen-through of Fire and Fury via Audible (the narrator is excellent).  Basically, the book is a Cliffs Notes version of American MSM over the past year.  Nothing too surprising, although interesting tidbits here and there, such as The Mooch was considered for what has to be the best gig in the galaxy: U.S. Ambassador to the OECD, which comes with a 20-room "apartment" in Paris, full staff, and absolutely no responsibilities.  Trump, it is clear, is just a vehicle, a tool, for others to obtain the power or push their policies through.  He is utterly oblivious to this fact.  And it extends even to his own children, who don't refer to him as dad, but DJT.  The only seeming humanity that comes through for this man-child, is that he allegedly does "love" Melania, although he literally refers to her as his trophy wife without any sense of irony or realization that it is not a compliment either to him or Melania.At bottom, the White House doth protest too much over this book.  It is not so much a critique of the utterly bizarre and disorganized mess the executive branch has become (and to be sure, it is that in large doses), but an examination of Trump--a lonely, petulant man-child wholly unaware of his power, his place in history, and his responsibility (indeed, it seems that that concept-responsibility-is a concept unknown to him).Fire and Fury is, in essence, the Truman Show with Trump as Truman.  In that regard, it is very hard to believe that someone could be so shallow, so anti-intellectual (the fact he refuses to read absolutely anything is beaten to death in the book), so lacking in self-awareness and yet exist, let alone function.  And yet, here he is.  The most powerful, yet loneliest man in the world, wholly incapable of reflection, let alone self-reflection.  It is, to use the cliche, a tragedy of Shakespearean proportions.The only upside to the book is that it reinforces the strength of our institutions.  That they are stronger than any single person, or even any single "administration," which absolutely must be written with scare quotes when discussing the current "administration."  Trump didn't surround himself with incompetents and Wormtongues as much as they were foisted upon him or wriggled into his inner circle like a malignant cancer.  And as some cancers die (e.g., Bannon, Mooch) more appear.  Yet, the immune systems of our institutions are quite strong.And so finally, what is quite apparent, is that Trump is so unsophisticated, so naive, that he could not have possibly colluded with the Russians, at least intentionally.  Indeed, if even a quarter of the book is to be believed, he never wanted the job.  And as I noted above, that is perfectly consistent with who Trump is, which unfortunately has been reinforced now that the presidency has been effectively forced on him.  Incompetence and an apparent urge for Junior to impress "DJT" was the source of the apparent collusion.  What is most unfortunate for Trump, is that he is quite literally too stupid to effectively respond to the investigation and, mainly as a result of all the Machiavellis surrounding him, only makes matter worse.  In short, no one learned from Nixon (and yes, I can hear Trump ask: "Who's Nixon?  What's Watergate?") that it is the cover-up that gets you.So, at the end, a breathtaking read, but not because there are any explosive revelations (although many tabloid-ish gossipy items), but rather the full picture it paints of Trump.  Friends, we clearly are without a leader.  There is no president in office.  The Emperor not only has no clothes, but no mind or even a tentative grasp on reality other than satisfying his own immediate needs for food and entertainment.  And while that may initially be frightening or even repulsive, in a sense it is (at least to me) reassuring.  Our great state, these United States, have behind them an inertia that a collective psychoses--really, I think, a collective prank we played on ourselves--cannot succumb to even the most inept people that we may place in the White House.  In other words, so far, we have past the test of Fire and Fury of this "administration."  And that is perhaps the best take-away from this book.  We are still here to read it.

I also picked up from the audio a criticism of the press for their role in this rapidly approaching constitutional crisis. Some in the media have been fawning and feeding the immature presidential ego, and others have gone straight to hand-wringing horror. It is clear the media has helped to create this monster. The author is actually more balanced in his approach than you would expect from the title and pre-release publicity. Also, an illustration of the problem is the presidentâ€™s reaction to the release of this book. He thinks he is entitled to stop the publication. Hell, no! I will be purchasing the digital version to read again, and a hard copy (just because it is my right) to share.

The Trump White House continues to be one of the most newsworthy and controversial entities of our time.  With that said, any book written from an insider's perspective on it will certainly be best seller.  If you watch the news, perhaps 80% of the book will not be a surprise. More, 80% of the book will be a regurgitation of headlines, the various scandals and confirmation of the fall out between various people: Jared and Ivanka's hatred of Bannon.  The other 20% is an insight into Steve Bannon, the opinions of those in the White House and a myriad of stories about how the staff was assembled.  The portrait painted of Bannon is particularly dark. Bannon is an agent of chaos, someone willing and interested in seeing politics as a war of attrition as opposed to an idealistic search for compromise and an evaluation of the best opinions.  The insights into what staff thinks of Trump become almost repetitive: Trump is an imbecile who is temperamental and reflexively spits out policy that is the product of his gut reaction and not intelligent rationalizing.  Although I recommend the book to all, Moore's writing style is often obnoxious.  He over utilizes phrases appropriate for the New Yorker and obnoxious for a mainstream bestseller.  If you can stomach the writing style of an author with a propensity to use SAT vocabulary words, you'll find this book funny, entertaining and a quick read.
Interesting topic, but the book was written in Trump speak - difficult to follow and often repeating what was already written.

For the most part, there's nothing in here that will surprise anyone. If you've been paying attention, you already know that the president of the most powerful country on the planet (for now) is a weak, vain, emotionally unstable, intellectually challenged individual who has none of the qualities--courage, integrity, empathy, curiosity--one would ordinarily look for in a leader. Wolff's portrait merely confirms what is evident even from a distance.What I suppose is new is the revelation that those closest to Trump are all very aware of his deficiencies (though how could they not be?). Whether you find this comforting or even more frightening is, I suppose, a matter of individual judgment. I suspect that his enablers will be viewed with contempt by those who come after us. This book is a useful record of their role in tarnishing America's reputation, and undermining the country's respect around the world.

I give this book five stars not because Wolff's writing is top-notch, certainly not because he and his assistants took the time to properly proofread the manuscript (it is riddled with minor errors), and not because every bit of it is likely to be absolutely true (can absolute truth be expected from the pack of liars Wolff spent time with in the White House?).  I give it five stars because the book seems to me to reveal basic truths of Trump's not only corrupt but unbelievably WEIRD administration:  1) Trump is a pathological liar; he has hit a new low in dishonesty for the sake of personal and political expediency.  2)  Trump is a seriously unstable narcissist, a poster boy for empty arrogance and entitlement, not sure himself who he is besides a TV character.  3) The man is so intellectually, emotionally, and morally bankrupt that he brings out the worst in everyone around him.  I was not surprised by anything I read in this important book.  But I was shocked.  And upon closing FIRE AND FURY, I was frightened.  The country and the world is in serious danger as long as this clownish dictator-wannabe remains in office.  What have we come to?  Read the book as a first step in understanding what has happened to us and what the country needs to do now:  show Donald Trump out of office any way we can as soon as we can.

To begin with, I was very irritated by all the editing mistakes that appeared in the Kindle edition. Writers lose some credibility when their "finished" product is riddled with grammatical errors. This book is just not well-written. At first the account was galvanizing, especially seeing in print one of Trump's speeches--which I would assign a D-minus at best. Incoherent, highly repetitive writing (or in this case Trump's speaking) indicates incoherent thinking; the president does not argue, he asserts. He has anecdotes but no evidence. Facts are clearly anathema to him; logic escapes him. But all this is really no surprise because he has shown himself over and over to be a vain, emotionally needy idiot, who is a compulsive liar being propped up by immoral toadies (in his staff and in congress). That said, after the first 90 or so pages, I became really bored. And why not? Trump (the subject of the book, after all) has nothing to say. He has no plans to solve the country's many problems and seems dangerously susceptible to repeating what the last person he talked to said.

I didn't actually intend to buy this book until it was ordered not to be published. Mainly I was willing to pay the 15 bucks to support free speech.Other than a few typos, which I found a bit distracting, this was a sobering look at what many of us feared was going on in the White House. Told in a quite matter of fact way that did not seem to be going for shock value or sensationalism made it all the more believable. Combined with quotes from those he interviewed are the author's own impressions. If given a choice to believe a president who has lied every single day about easily fact checked events, and an author who was seen with a visitor pass on a nearly constant basis by white house reporters, I am more inclined to believe the author than a president who claims he wasn't there. There are a few descriptions of events that have been disputed as inaccurate but I don't think an honest mistake here and there (such as similar names being confused) negate the facts. Perhaps these were due in part to a rush to publish a week or so early in response to an attempt from the president to block the publication. Considering the president's desperate attempt to block this publication, and considering the author's statement that some of his interviews are recorded. combined with the fact that nobody is disputing the actual quotes, I find it to be believable. I mean considering the things Trump says in public it is not hard to believe what anyone else would say.

The meta analysis of this remarkable book by much of the self-flagellating mainstream media, fueled by paranoia about perceived liberal bias, has been silly and superfluous. Five minute segment-opening disclaimers about lack of independent corroboration and surgical dissection of specific quotes, scenes and attributions seem to suggest this is a piece of investigative journalism, which it is not and the author never claims it to be. The Washington Post, New York Times and others are already doing historic and admirable work in this regard.The reader needs to accept this book for what it is, a travelogue of the authorâ€™s journey down the rabbit hole and into the tragic and depraved insanity that is Trumpworld.  We shouldnâ€™t expect triple source corroboration of every anecdote or dialogue any more than we would expect it from descriptions of Aliceâ€™s encounters with the Mad Hatter and various other similarly fantastical characters. It also shouldnâ€™t matter that he insinuated himself into Trumpworld through deceitful flattery. The aggrieved simply had to google â€œMichael Wolffâ€ù or ring Rupert Murdoch if they thought he was there to do a puff piece. Any House of Cards fan knew what Tom was up to.In this context, the author provides us with a remarkably vivid and generally coherent view of the inner workings of one of the saddest and most tragic chapters in this countryâ€™s political history. Most importantly, this view comports very well with the collective narrative of an enormous volume of investigative reporting and other journalistic activity covering this period. The author makes clear that he is providing his own best, and likely imperfect, impression of the details of what transpired but this impression is not presented in a vacuum as a handful of deeply embedded sources, most notably Bannon, Walsh and Nunberg, happily provide extensive on-the-record commentary. Of course, as with even the most intensely sourced investigative piece, the biases of the on-the-record sources will tend to dominate the narrative and it is the discerning readerâ€™s responsibility to account for this.It is worth noting that readers looking to gorge on extra platefuls of salacious quotes will be disappointed. With the exception of a remarkable,extended and highly enlightening tirade by Bannon over Chinese food towards the end of the book and a insult by supposed FOD and party wingman Thomas Barrack, most of oh-my-god quotes were included in the pre-release excerpts and have already made headlines, much like a comedy movie trailer tends to give away all of the best jokes.  In between the hot bits, however, is a rich and engaging retelling of the Shakespearean tragedy unfolding behind the scenes of events we already know extremely well, the campaign, Election Day, the inauguration, the Flynn firing, the Comey firing, the Don Jr meeting and itâ€™s coverup, Charlottesville, etc. Some of the most eye-popping and nauseating parts are verbatim recitations of Trumpâ€™s own words such as the surreal CIA HQ speech or the ping-pong of scripted vs spontaneous Charlottesville comments.I have to give the author credit for getting this reader, as virulent a Bannon-hater as there is on the planet, to almost begrudgingly respect him as a man of passion, insight and purpose, even if to evil ends. Itâ€™s hard not to sympathize with his portrayal of the rest of the clown car brigade, including the Clown-in-Chief, as a bunch of hollow, vain, lightweights with no driving purpose other than their own personal glory and in some cases wealth and essentially no insight of how the sane world views them.One final observation. This book is not the liberal bias affirmation piece you might expect. The author takes repeated shots at the liberal media, Obama, the Clintons, etc. in fact, I have to assume that the diehard MAGA crowd (including Breitbart, the Mercers and Hannity) who quickly rallied around the presidentâ€™s family and banished Bannon to the wilderness over this excerpts from the book, donâ€™t read just as their leader doesnâ€™t read. If they did read this book, even with the most cynical of perspectives, they would have to conclude to their horror that the Jarvanka crowd, the â€œDemocratsâ€ù as the Bannonites call them, have won the battle for the Trumpâ€™s â€œheartâ€ù and dominion over Trumpworld itself.

This is a five star book with some factual errors but the gist of the book is correct.  Some people might ask how is a book with factual errors worth five stars?  I confess that I'm more liberal than I am conservative, so that might be one reason.  But I am not blind to errors of fact.  I am not deluded.  I do not ignore reality or truth, like some people, and plow on, as if facts don't matter.  For every error in this point, my guess is that our president has told a fifteen or twenty lies.  The President has also not read this book, so how can he call it anything.  How can anyone who has not read book have their comments taken seriously, though the natural line of defense from those who have not read it, but are commenting unfavorably, or favorably here, will be because they can.  This book is important because it is good enough.  And therefore relevant, given its subject.  It does its best to offer significance through relative truth.  And relative truth is important these days because we are combating the very serious dangers if not outright incompetence and possibly even the outright evil of a fake president.  We are enduring the everyday fakeries and racist and narcissistic lies of a fake president.  A president who himself doesn't take truth seriously.  Who has "legitimized" his own truth as somehow a prosperously fake truth with his conspiratorial style of leadership.  We can only hold our breath and pray, or meditate, that it will be over soon enough, and that our country will somehow survive.

I despise Trump tbh, and I'm a former Democratic State Committeewoman.  I believe he should be impeached (which means charged formally and brought to actual public trial, not removed from office unless convicted).  I suspect we are headed for at least a proxy war with Putin, which would make collaboration traitorous, and a capital offense.Even given that.All you have to do is read Wolff's description of how the NYC literati and press had it out for the man, and his blaming Kushner for the decline and early death of a news editor at a paper Kushner bought (I found Wolff's eulogy for that editor at The Guardian) and a picture emerges.This is a book by a man who believes that his cadre created Trump, in part, and so it is his responsibility to bring him down.There is social engineering, bullying, and snobbery underlying every line.Read this in part as a document of the psychology of the Eastern seaboard self-segregated urban elite who uses the term "fly-over state" to refer to the majority of the country by geography.All Democrats are not like this.  I grew up in a rural, agricultural state.  I was born in the Midwest.  But I live in Cambridge MA smack between Harvard and MIT, surrounded by any number of city people who wouldn't know what part of a cow to milk or what that was analogous to on a human, and if they thought too hard they'd never drink milk again.  I am not vegan.But there are a lot of Americans today avoiding thinking too hard about each other's realities.I also found Wolff's writing from back in the Clinton administration dissecting just what it took to push America into accepting that travesty -- and I believe he is taking those lessons and implementing them against a Republican administration.  It's a bed the GOP made and have to accept the short sheets they are sleeping in.  I believe we are finding far graver issues than a stained dress and a single lie here.I am still a liberal and a Democrat, but one determined to see all sides confront their mirrors.  If this is our accepted truth without looking for motivation and nuance, without asking questions regarding the author, then we have a problem regardless of party.  What we have here is a failure to communicate.How do we reunite this country?  This is not the answer.  What this is, is a strategic weapon aiming for hearts and minds.  How can we possibly know how much is true without reviewing audio?

Trumpâ€™s daily outbursts already create enough anxiety for most Americans and the citizens of the world, but I nevertheless felt it was important to read this book during my "leisure" time,Much of the subject matter is nothing new and has been reported extensively during the past year (not-so-spoiler alert:  most of the people who work/have worked with Trump do not believe he's fit to be President).  And all the new "bombshells", such as Bannon's comments about the Russian meeting at Trump Tower, have already made the headlines.  The book can be a little gossipy, and Wolff's journalistic reputation is not impeccable, but I believe that the book is mostly true - at least true enough that the overall depiction of the Trump Administration is accurate.Even though all the news-worthy information has already been reported, I am glad that this book was published.  Bumping up the publication date was a great move - Trump needs to be shown that he's now in the big leagues and can no longer bully the little guy by threatening lawsuits.  Plus, he needs to know that he canâ€™t get away with whatever he wants because he was born rich.Regardless of your opinion of the book, it will certainly hold a place in the history of the Trump Administration.

I was surprised to find in reading "Fire and Fury" - Michael Wolff's seventh book (I haven't read any of his others), that it was not the lurid secrets revealed that intrigued me most (they were old news by the time I got my back-ordered copy) nor the "behind the scenes" descriptions of "what really goes on in the White House" that I found to be the most remarkable element of the book, but rather it was the unusual run-on sentences with thoughts streaming in out of the blue, accompanied by a higher density by far of punctuation marks per word per page than other books I was reading at the time, e.g. "Leonardo", by Walter Isaacson, so different that I thought I would write this review (posted on both Amazon and LibraryThing using a similar style throughout to give you an idea of what you will frequently encounter should you decide to read it.  Of course, I could just reproduce a sentence or two, and in fact, I do that in the paragraph immediately below, but a few sentences, standing alone in a rather twisted weave, does not convey the same effect as a books-worth, and if you doubt my words, you may wish to stop at a bookstore and leaf through some random pages, or even easier, go to Amazon's review page and take a look at some of the "Look Inside" material.Here's Wolff, beginning page 161, bottom paragraph:For Breitbart, the House rebellion and transformation that had driven the former Speaker, John Boehner, from office, and which, plausibly, was set to remake the House into the center of the new radical Republicanism had been halted by Ryan's selection as Speaker.  Mitt Romney's running mate, and a figure who had merged a conservative fiscal wonkishness - he had been chairman of the House Ways and Means committee -with an old-fashioned idea of unassailable Republican rectitude, Ryan was the official last, best hope of the Republican Party. (Bannon, typically, had turned this trope into an official Trumpist talking point: "Ryan was created in a petri dish at the Heritage Foundation.")(Want more? try bottom of page 144 and just continue until....)Too often, I had to stop and go back to re-read, searching for the elusive main thought that had somehow escaped me, and coming away feeling I was reading a first draft, something rushed to take advantage of a marketing window (though whether that was the case or not I had no idea), and while this became the main negative of this book for me, it was not alone.  I'm certainly no prude and have no issues with salty language when used in appropriate circumstances, but I thought it was overdone here; I certainly have no illusions about the level of language used in almost all organizations including the White House and a few examples make the point, but I thought it was a bit overdone(and the author even feels it necessary to clarify "repetitions" as it applies to Trump's speaking skills or lack thereof), and speaking of overdone I wondered why Wolff found it necessary to make 4 uses of "Catholic" between pages 55 and 57 in describing Bannon's background; I found that rather strange and a bit overdone.There were some positives, little things mostly like the juicy bits about the Hicks-Lewandowski relationship and Bannon's (and apparently Wolff's) not too flattering assessment of Hope Hicks's abilities and then there's the frequent negative shots at Ivanka, and now I can stop having nightmares about her ever becoming POTUS, but then that was exactly the same I thought of her father two years ago.....OMG!  There was an especially funny line I hadn't heard before spoken by our President, per page 98, bottom:"They take everything I've ever said and exaggerate it," said the president in his first week in the White House during a late-night call.  "It's all exaggerated.  My exaggerations are exaggerated."Nikki Haley is compared to X in terms of her ambitions, and it's a hilarious comment - you'll have to read the book to find it (hint pg 309).  And I thought the descriptions of the first weeks in the White House were very interesting.  Not a lot that was new, but confirming my worst imaginings, somehow reading it as it actually happened was more unnerving than I thought it would be and I thought Wolff did a good job of describing the chaos that ruled and the sheer amateurism that prevailed.  So, would I recommend this book?.....you have to ask....absolutely not, I even feel my 3 star rating is overly generous and would I read a follow on book?, hell yes and don't ask me to explain why.

If you deplore Donald Trumpâ€™s racism, misogyny, meanness, stupidity, narcissism, and recklessness, and the sheer incompetence ofÂ his White House, as I do, and if there is a malicious streak in you, as there is in me, you may love Michael Wolffâ€™s Fire and Fury. It's difficult to imagine any account of the goings-on in Donald Trumpâ€™s White House that would paint a darker picture of this worst of all Presidents and the servile minions around him. Fire and Fury is scathing.Other reviewers have panned this bookHowever, far better writers than I have reviewed this book and found it wanting. Here, for example, is Masha Gessen writing in The New Yorker (January 7, 2008): â€œTheÂ President of the United States is a deranged liar who surrounds himself with sycophants. He is also functionally illiterate and intellectually unsound. He isÂ manifestly unfit for the job. Who knew? Everybody did.Â So why has a poorly written book containing this information, padded with much tedious detail, become an overnight sensation, a runaway best-seller, and the topic of every other political column, podcast, and dinner conversation? It seems we are in bigger trouble with reality perception than we might have realizedÂ . . .Â That â€˜Fire and Furyâ€™ can occupy so much of the public-conversation space degrades our sense of reality further, while creating the illusion of affirming it.â€ùIn a similarly unflattering review in the San Francisco Chronicle (January 9, 2018),Â Book Review Editor John McMurtry describes Fire and Fury as â€œa few hundred pages of gossipy, anecdote-heavy accounts that paint a highly unfavorable portrait of a deeply unpopular president . . . Of course, as with any satisfying dish that has you craving more, the book, with all its accounts of petty and profanity-infused backstabbing, can ultimately leave you with the feeling of having consumed one too many of Trump's beloved cheeseburgers.â€ùDespite the bad reporting, a terrible truth emergesItâ€™s difficult to disagree with any of this. Surely, Fire and Fury is a product of very bad reporting. But strip away the flimsy analysis, the nasty innuendo, the unattributed zingers, and the opinionated diatribe, and you're left with an indictment of Donald Trump that is still likely to shock anyone who is not immersed 24 hours a day in the seething cauldron of political news. The picture that emerges from even a skeptical reading of Fire and Fury is horrific. Everything I had come to believe about Donald Trump has been confirmed:Â Our president is an impulsive man of limited intelligence, a racist, a sexual predator, a pathological liar, and an unrelenting narcissist who almost never listens and never accepts criticism.What I learned from Fire and FuryStill, I learned a few things from Fire and Fury:Donald Trump never wanted to be president, and he was stunned when he won. His campaign was a brand-building exerciseâ€”a way for him to make a lot more money. â€œHe would come out of this campaign, Trump assured [former Fox News chairman Roger] Ailes, with a far more powerful brand and untold opportunities. â€˜This is bigger than I ever dreamed of,â€™ he told Ailes in a conversation a week before the election. â€˜I don't think about losing because it isn't losing. We've totally won.â€™â€ùPractically everyone on the White House staff, including his daughter and son-in-law, treat Trump like a willful two-year-old. Almost nobody ever says no to him. Those rare occasions when anyone does so trigger tantrums and vicious backbiting from the president. He even badmouths his daughter and son-in-law.All this may be old hat to you, if you obsessively follow the daily news. I donâ€™t.How did Michael Wolff ever get access?Â I find it astonishing that anyone in a senior position in the White House, much less the president himself, would allow a man with Michael Wolffâ€™s reputation as a scandal-monger to set foot in the place, let alone hang out with them for eighteen months. But Edward Helmore has an explanation (The Guardian, January 14, 2018): â€œAfter writing relatively positive profiles of Trump and Bannon for the Hollywood Reporter, Wolff joined the parade of job-seekers and ring-kissers at Trump Tower in the weeks after the astonishing election result. â€˜I said to the president, â€œIâ€™d love to come down and be an observer at the White House.â€ù Thatâ€™s when he thought I was asking for a job. I said, â€œNo, no. I might want to write a book.â€ù His face fell. He was completely uninterested. So I pressed a little. Iâ€™d really like to do it. So it was, â€œYah, yah. OK sure.â€ùâ€™â€ùWhat's missing from Wolffâ€™s reportingOne more thing about the book: in any serious effort at political analysis or reporting, itâ€™s customary to include notes, usually extensive ones, about the sources of the author's information. There are no notes in Fire and Fury. Nor does Wolff date the conversations he reports having had or learned about. This is exceedingly sloppy reporting.And hereâ€™s a taste of how Wolffâ€™s peers in journalism look at him. â€œItâ€™s unsurprising that, as a former colleague delicately puts it, â€˜people really canâ€™t stand Michael.â€™â€ù So wrote Michelle Cottle in the New RepublicÂ more than a decade ago (August 29, 2004). She continued: â€œWhat is surprising is how much of the animus seems unrelated to the content of his commentary. On a meta level, Wolff is resented for not playing by the rules of his chosen profession. He has a reputation for busting embargoes and burning sources by putting off-the-record comments on the record.â€ùAbout the authorFrom Wikipedia: â€œMichael WolffÂ is an American author, essayist, and journalist, and a regular columnist and contributor toÂ USA Today,Â The Hollywood Reporter, and the UK edition ofÂ GQ.Â He has received twoÂ National Magazine Awards, aÂ Mirror Award, and has authored seven books.â€ù (Do you wonder how he managed to win those awards? I do.)One of Wolff's earlier books, Burn Rate, chronicled his effort in the 1990s to become a multimillionaire on the Internet. The book was panned by many reviewers, just as has been the case with Fire and Fury. And those reviews suggest thereâ€™s nothing new in Wolffâ€™s style or approach to his subjects. Here, for example, is Katie Hafner, writing about Burn Rate in the New York TimesÂ (July 26, 1998): â€œWolff spares no feelings. He casts such an unforgiving eye on the people around him that his tone often smacks of vendetta. He depicts his cohorts as fakes and blowhards, arrogant and clueless. He is locked in a hate-hate relationship with one of his main investors, who Wolff believes is out to double-cross him. Wolff portrays his partner as a wealthy, simpering venture capitalist wannabe, and makes disagreeable sport of deceiving him. It is this dark figure who eventually strips Wolff of control of his own company.â€ù

Holy smokes! What I liked about "Fire and Fury" is the unbelievable access and detail of that access. While there seems to be much controversy around the author's methods and the content itself, I found I could easily navigate that dynamic by keeping in mind the book's clear disclaimers and using some common sense, "grain of salt" and, most importantly, the existing facts on the ground. I found this style (some are calling gossipy and tabloid) to be an oddly appealing aspect of the read, refreshing even, but with a strange aftertaste. All told an EXTREMELY riveting yet highly disturbing read depicting an historically troubled administration. I think anyone following this unbelievable saga will appreciate this story. All that said, I won't be truly satiated until a "tell all" from the likes of John Kelly or Mattis comes out or a Walter Isaacson or Bob Woodward type chronicles what has happened here.

Read the published excerpts -- they well-represent the entire book.  Loaded with both quality referenced material and eye-opening confidentially-sourced quotes, the author does a great job at capturing the overall flavor of the Trump campaign and the start of his Presidency.  A true non-fiction page-turner, I find little padding here.  In fact, the many lines of intellectual inquiry that interweave in the complexities of sociopolitical reality have been expertly managed in this book -- no major facets of the Trump era have been ignored, and no significant threads forgotten or untraced.  A literate, relevant, shocking marvel, its place already cemented in world history.

Reading this book was an exercise in fascination, shock, and dismay.  I haven't been a big fan of 45 but I thought perhaps I had missed something.  I ended up feeling vaguely sorry for him but was truly alarmed by Steve Bannon and his rabidly conservative ideals and Jared/Ivanka Trump's level of access and influence as non-elected members of the executive branch.  With all of the vitriol and constant chaos as (it seems, accurately) portrayed by the press, in my mind there was not a clear agenda nor political ideology nor path forward.  This book explains why and the forces that blew DJT into the White House.I found the author to be credible, even-handed, and politically astute.  His vocabulary was a delight.  I am only giving it 4 stars because there should have been better editing.  Too many typos for a national bestseller!I am glad I read it.  We have spent the last year viewing the events from the outside in.  This book rounds out our perspective by covering the inside looking out.

And if youâ€™ve ever worked in a political environment you know how insidious and destructive gossip can be - particularly when itâ€™s â€œweaponizedâ€ù by workers seeking to make themselves look better to the boss by making co-workers look worse. Workplaces like this are really â€œtoxicâ€ù and soul-destroying.This is the workplace environment described by Michael Wolff in his book about the Trump WhiteHouse - â€œFire and Fury.â€ùReaders will sort through his material to decide whatâ€™s true, whatâ€™s exaggerated, whatâ€™s twisted, and whatâ€™s an outright lie. Wolff has pulled together an engaging and reasonably well-written case for what has already been quite obvious to anyone paying attention: the story of the workings, or rather the lack thereof, of the Trump White House is one of warring personalities, each less experienced, less self-aware, and more incompetent than the next. Fire and Fury largely serves as a 'greatest hits' list of dysfunction and scandal, a reminder of just what a long and dark year for American government we've all suffered through at the hands of the Character in Chief and his supporting cast.To be sure, there are tidbits of new information, mostly in the form of the gossip and quotes attributed to (and almost surely sourced from) Bannon that have now been exhaustively reprinted in the press since the book's release. While there has been much discussion of the accuracy or inaccuracy of specific quotes or anecdotes, the very nature of a drama that is more about people and relationships than actions means that the story will, as Wolff acknowledges in the preface, necessarily be coloured by the biases and agendas of the sources doing the telling.Still, the core thread of an unstable and fragile president surrounded by bumbling, infighting, and sycophantic staff has been so clearly and publicly on display that it hardly presents itself as a revelation or a matter for dispute. Indeed, so much of the West Wing gossip that Wolff recounts has been circulating in one form or another in DC for months that it, too, often felt more like a retelling of a long familiar story than a true scoop.Nevertheless, Fire and Fury is very much worth a readâ€”in part, to be sure, because it's the conversation topic of the moment in political circles, but primarily because it serves as both an excellent summary of the first year of Trump's presidency and as an ominous warning of the drama that will surely follow in the months ahead.

A review of Fire And FuryMy initial feeling, from reading the excerpts before Fire And Fury was actually published, was that this was a Hunter S. Thompson, Fear And Loathing On The Campaign Trail style book. Now, having bought and read the ebook version of Fire And Fury, I have to add to that. It DOES cover the 2016 campaign, like Thompsons book covered the 1972 campaign, but it does more. It also covers the first 8 months or so of 2017, exposing in detail the complete unstructured chaos of the Trump White House. As such, I would compare it to Woodward And Bernstein's All The President's Men.Wolff, as has been noted, had access to the major and minor players over an extended period of time. I don't know for sure that all the quotations are accurate, since I wasn't there. Certainly the quotes seem to reflect the individual personalities accurately.I see nothing in this book that is unbelievable, aside from the fact that Trump won the election, itself the most unbelievable event in modern politics.If you are anti-Trump, this book merely connects the dots and fills in the details. If you are pro-Trump, you should read this, but I doubt you will.

I found out about this book when our president claimed on Twitter that it was written by a "total loser" along with someone named Sloppy Steve, who cried and begged for his job when Trump fired him. It sounded intriguing, so I had to see what it was all about, so I bought the Audible version because - like the president - I don't like reading at all. I didn't want to spend the money really, because I get bored so easily when people are talking to me, but wow did this whole thing keep my attention!***SPOILERS***I'm not sure why Trump keep mentioning this book so often because just about everyone in it - from his advisers to his closest friends - basically spend the whole book saying what an idiot he is and how incompetent he and everyone around him is. I mean, even his daughter is making fun of him in this book. Why would he keep mentioning it?Anyway, this is probably one of the greatest stories ever written. At least I think it is. As I said, I don't like to read. But I couldn't stop listening to this it was so intense! I hope Sloppy Steve is OK, and I hope Trump isn't too mad at his friends and family. I hope he doesn't retreat to his locked bedroom with too many cheeseburgers and get sick watching stories about him on his three TV's.If you don't like reading and you are easily bored listening to people, I still highly recommend this book - or actually, just the audio because it's so easy to follow and to listen to.

This must have been a difficult book to write. There is so much story to be told and the principle threads so entangled that it must have been very difficult to tie them together in a coherent story. Wolff mostly succeeds, but not entirely. Then again that is an important part of the very story Wolff is trying to tell, the story itself is about an incoherent presidential administration.Told in broadly chronological order of the presidential election of 2016 and the roughly first 200 days of the administration up to the middle of August 2017. At the end an epilogue focused on Steve Bannon, who has a claim to being the book's main character, brings the story up to roughly October 2017, but the pace of news has hardly stopped there. As I write this in January 2018 I can only be sure that much more will happen. Within its chronology, there are frequent steps backwards as Wolff brings in the various characters and their varying alliances coloring-in their relation to the then forward moving part of the story. Of all the characters brought to the fore, at least among the dozen or more who are in direct proximity to the president by living or working in the West Wing, only a single pair (Ivanka and husband Jared Kushner) keep the same relationship relative to one another throughout. Every other person or cabal-like group changes relationships often multiple times as most of the individuals involved come into the story and then go out!I do have one philosophical matter to bring up. Let's grant that Wolff reported accurately on everything he was told by everybody. He presents a fair picture of that to which he was a party either first, or at most second (and occasionally third) hand. At the same time that which he is reporting is, he points out, the back stabbing testimony of each cabal out to paint the others in the worst light possible. Even if those to whom he spoke were not outright lying to him, at the least they were telling highly selective truths almost surely leaving much out. Our only hope in this mess is that from the back stabbing of all sides towards one another and the occasional more neutral voice (though nobody was entirely neutral) from the periphery, Wolff has put together if not a true portrait, then at least a portrait true to the Kafka-esque nature of the administration! If that is a horrible thought, it is what makes this an important book.This is high class journalism first and foremost, but it reads at the same time like an Elmore Leonard novel! As Sean Spicer began to say "you can't make this s*** up!". Frankly this book would be hysterically funny if it was not so downright dangerous and disturbing.

I rated this audiobook as five stars because of its obvious importance, not because of its entertainment value. I found it tedious to listen to, probably because of the banality and sordidness of the events it records. In that respect, I found this account reminiscent of accounts of life in the upper eschelons of the Third Reich. Anyone who has listened to Trump lo these many months should not be surprised or alarmed that his intimates describe him as semi-literate. The incoherence of Trump's speeches and tweets evidence a lack of the mental rigor imposed by regular exposure to the written word.  What I did find disturbing is the observation of some that Trump has difficulty associating cause and effect. Does this account for his disbelief in climate change? What does such a difficulty portend for his approach to  the Korean problem? Nuclear deterrence theory requires, if nothing else, an appreciation of cause and effect. A must read/listen.

I was hoping for full interviews and first-hand witness accounts, anonymous or otherwise, of the behind-the-scenes action that took place during the campaign and just after at the start of the presidency. Sure, I was eager for a book trashing Trump, but I was also legitimately curious to get a glimpse at his inner circle when the cameras were off and get a feel what the tone was like as it was happening leading up to election night.Instead, the book starts on election night, and had a very fly-on-the-wall, detached feel to it, and was heavy-handed on speculation. Most of the fun, juicy tidbits were brought to light on the talk shows before the book was even released, so there weren't many surprises. I'll let youread to find them.  Some shockers!  And theinsider tone, with conversations reconsructed indetail makes for an easy read.  I'll refrain from saying "fun,"though in fact, on some level, the book is a kind of dangerousfun.  If this were a novel, I would say it was a fun read.Sadly, it is not fiction.I must say, that Wolff is certainly a self promoter throughout,perhaps in the style of the book's outlandish character,Mr. Bannon himself.  Wolff purports to fairly refereeliberal and conservative, tea partyite and socialist opinions.In my opinion, he does in fact do a fair job.But do make a note of this: the author wants to be thefinal arbiter of truth on the story of the first 200days of Trumpworld.  I think one needs to read thisbook with mental filters adjusted to tune outthis Wolff hubris.

I did not like this book  and in  the same way that I won't read books about torture or animal cruelty, I wanted to stop reading it.  I found the behaviour of Donald Trump so distasteful.  Michael Wolff seemed to have a sort of glee in reporting this that I find disturbing.  I was tempted to stop reading because I try to avoid listening to tales when the teller  is enjoying telling on someone. I persisted because Wolff did help me look at the whole long year  His reporting gives a picture  one gets when pulling back from a microscopic view of a germ to a telescopic view of the results.  Not a pretty picture, but necessary. I'm giving it 4 stars because I think it is a review of what has happened to the United States in 2017.My hope is that those who really need to know and need help understanding these events will actually read it.  I'm a university educated senior.  I know how to use the dictionary function on my Kindle.  I have enough experience to appreciate the memes and idioms.  I also know many people who will be turned off by these difficulties and I fear that they are also uneasy about spending money on non-fiction books.  I guess I'm one of the elite Liberals.  I'm likely like most of the audience Mr. Wolff was addressing.  Preaching to the choir is easy.  Someone has to figure out how to get this very important information to those who don't read books like this.Because, the elections in 2018 are only months away.  That is when effective legislators need to be placed in Congress to slow down this run-away train.  The ones who can do that, elect the saviours  need to know who Trump and his supporters are.  Apparently they also are not likely to watch CNN or read actual newspapers, even on-line format.  How to reach them?  Surely there are tech  savvy  reporters who can use Twitter or Facebook or ....  Whoever you are, as you read Wolff's book, consider how to get this information to them.By the way, yes there are a few (less than 10 that I noticed) errors: a name misspelled, an article missed, not enough to interrupt the flow or impede comprehension.Now I'm going to soothe myself by rereading David McCullough's " Truman"  because that was a man who did his bit to make America great .

Nothing is said about females in power in general (but, then again, this is the administration of misogny) other than Diana Welch and how marginalized she ends up being.I either ravage a great book in one day or, in this case, take more like a month to get through it. I'm not far from being finished but was surprised to learn that Wolff alludes to Nikki Haley being Trump's latest perv target. Sorry, but that defies logic and is unnecessary to even put into print.So, you may learn something new if you read "Fire and Fury" but I pretty much already knew the horror story that is the Trump Presidency. Fire and Fury is sometimes sloppy and inconsistent but overall a great read and certainly a mandatory one for anyone following the Trump administration.The sloppiness I found was that sometimes people's errors/lies are corrected in text and other times not.  For example at one point Bannon tried to discredit Rupert Murdoch saying he's not American.  I know that Murdoch is a naturalized US citizen (born in Australia) but the book never points that out.  At another point a negative story paints a picture of Trump walking the White House in a bathrobe yelling at the TV.  The President refutes a story saying he never owned a bathrobe.  I remember at the time reporters found many pictures of Trump in bathrobes, but Fire and Fury does not bring this up.  The book also repeats Trump's claim to have been on the cover of Time magazine more that anyone else, another statement that is completely untrue but not corrected.For a book that uses anonymous sources and calls for a lot of trust, this sort of sloppiness hurts my faith in the writer.  And of course there are the denials and refutations from many of the people quoted in the book and the factual errors found by other reporters.It's an entertaining read but take it with a grain of salt.  Wolff admits that his sources all had their own agenda and would leak or lie to hurt other factions, so don't trust everything written.

I purchased the audio book through Audible and this review includes my experience of the narrator as well, Holter Graham, as well as the book's author Michael Wolff.First, I am a self-described liberal who follows politics closely and keep informed about what is going on in Washington. So I am fully willing to admit I am interested in any book that "exposes" Trump and his White House. Having said that, I do believe that Michael Wolff is not what anyone would call a highly respected journalist and much of his material needs to be taken with a grain of salt. Still, the remarkable thing to me is how closely the information in this book seems to align with the reporting that has come out of the respected mainstream media, and I believe this is largely an accurate account. What I appreciated about the book was how it took all the bits and pieces leaked and created a coherent narrative that gives some context to all the chaos we have seen coming out of the White House.What I was really surprised about, was what an entertaining read it is. Both the writing style and the narrator make this book really flow and much of it is quite humorous. This lived up to the hype for me and I do recommend it--especially the audio book version.

In summary, Donald J Trump unfortunately proves that he should never have become President and just stuck with reality TV.

If you think about it, Michael Wolff, as a journalist for â€œThe Hollywood Reporterâ€ù, is the perfect person to research and analyze the Trump administration.  Trump, his family, and his associates are really the kind of collection of narcissists, fragile egos, sycophants, and rather dumb public personalities that inhabit the lower rungs of the show business and trash media world.  Wolff is both a keen observer of this world and knows how to interview and dig at these people to get at the heart of what makes them tick.Wolff presents a uniquely American tragedy - a man who really didnâ€™t expect or want to be President, his dismayed family, and a circle of hangers-on that signed up for something they didnâ€™t really believe in.  Thereâ€™s the expected back-stabbing and self-serving drama, but Wolff places it in the larger context of the public policy implications of their actions.As a â€œfly on the wallâ€ù, he understands, more than anyone else, that this isnâ€™t the story of a Presidential administration.  Itâ€™s a tv reality show filled with d-listers being played out at public expense.Trump detractors already have a general sense and broad outlines of whatâ€™s gone wrong with the administration.  With Wolffâ€™s book, they can start to get a sense of why and how the past few months have played out on the public stage as it has.  The book clues us into the personal motivations by all the individuals involved that have created the news stories and public image weâ€™re all more familiar with.  What will be most surprising to these readers is that the players are far more cynical, out of touch, and lacking in self awareness and basic competence than anyone ever thought.With Nixon, we had to wait a few years after his administration had ended in resignation to get a book like this that exposed how disturbed, paranoid, and dysfunctional the man was â€œbehind the scenesâ€ù during Watergate in books like â€œFinal Daysâ€ù.  With Wolffâ€™s access to the White House, with Trumpâ€™s personal nod, and the hundreds of interviews from the band of misfits at the heart of the storm, the train wreck is all here, laid bare for anyone with eyes to see.  Itâ€™s raw, revealing, and jaw-dropping.Wolffâ€™s book is a cautionary tale for anyone interested in democracy about the fundamental character of who we elect to office - their motivations, the kind of people they surround themselves with, and their fitness and ability to govern or serve.  It will no doubt be the first of many books that tries to make sense of the Trump years, but Wolffâ€™s account has carved a space in the political dialogue about the trend towards ideologues, hucksters, and celebrities as political figures and style with no substance in governance.

This book about the behind the scenes goings-on during the Trump campaign and first several months in Office is a fascinating read, and it reads as basically true. Are there a few places where Wolff takes some artistic license or is a bit off on certain facts? Iâ€™m sure the answer is yes, but criticism coming from a President who lies outright on an almost daily basis canâ€™t change the basic fact that the book absolutely nails the attitudes of the players. The most important revelation is something of which Iâ€™ve long been convinced: no one on the Trump team ever thought heâ€™d be elected. The outcome of the election was a publicity stunt gone horribly wrong and landed a passel of completely unprepared, largely unqualified people in the White House. Given that start itâ€™s no wonder that weâ€™ve seen the shameful and embarrassing disaster that has taken place over the last year.

However much you think you know about Trump, his collaborators, his family and anyone else along for the ride on this insane roller coaster of an administration, there are stories in this book you probably havenâ€™t heard yet, or at least not in as much detail as you will here.  Trump himself tried to derail its publication, need I say more?  Harrowing, hilarious and an utter wipeout of not just Trump but the Republican Party which enabled and in a very real sense created him.

Journalist Michael Wolff provides irrefutable evidence of what we knew all along, that Donald Trump has mastered his posturing as the President of the United States, but that he is a man completely out of his depth when it comes to the true responsibilities of the job. Many of us have assumed this to be true, but Wolff's interviews show how Trump knows how to control his own narrative and how this preternatural gift allowed him to be elected over someone whose integrity has been a constant source of irreconcilable argument. How far his vanity will go is anybody's guess as he is surrounded by sycophants and turncoats that amount to a revolving door staff. Wolff shows how that loyalty is precarious at best within the Trump White House, and if Steve Bannon is the first to jump ship, he surely won't be the last. The emperor not only has no clothes, he just doesn't care about anything but his self-vaunted image.

I could read this chapter over and over again. Bannonâ€™s assessment of the Trump disaster is brilliant. Itâ€™s the most clear and concise breakdown what what is so wrong with Trump and the family. If even HALF of what is written within the pages of this book are true, it would be worth the cost of purchase.It all makes sense now, those things that left us scratching our heads last year. Why on earth would a rich guy, already famous for the past four full decades, want to run for the Presidency? Trump is clearly not remotely familiar with how things work, politically, and (face it) the White House is a dump compared with Trump Tower.Turns out, he really never expected, nor made serious plans, to win the election. When it happened, he and everyone around him were stunned. What do you we do now?  Well, if you are Trump, you are a winner! You play that hand, keep family close (even if they are dysfunctional) and do whatever you want to do.Of course, there are those boring daily briefings which, for someone with the attention span of a someone sixty-five years younger (do the math!), are pure torture.  So his staff keep it real simple: bullet points...and with a lot of Donald J. Trump within each simplified point. Never one for details, he lets things just happen, allows whoever is his favorite minion-of-the-week do whatever needs to be done, and onward to the next great reveal, the next episode.We probably all suspected this was happening, but Wolff provides the timeline and the behind-the-scenes detail and drama. How did he gain access? Very simple. Nobody was really watching, absorbed in the daily wild and crazy soap opera drama around them. He took a non-denial as a tacit approval and no one stopped him.  After all, Trump is Mr. Reality Television. Publicity is good. Whatever. Roll with it.I was riveted from the minute I started listening to the audio book.

I bought this book because of Trumpâ€™s efforts to keep it from the public eye.There is nothing particularly shocking, if youâ€™ve been following the news. It simply fills in the gaps of what many of us suspected was happening in Washington.What surprises me is how many people are enthusiastic about this book after reading it. Iâ€™ve never read an author who was more in need of a good editor. At some point in Michael Wolffâ€™s Life, someone must have told him that he will get paid per run on sentence. His writing is so tedious it is a struggle to read. I got so bogged down I started counting the commas in his sentences. The unscientific average is 7 commas per sentence. Really?! 7 commas in a single sentence? Multiply that by 300+ pages and you have a good idea what youâ€™re in for.Iâ€™m not sure how he got this far without learning basic sentence structure. A better editor would have made a world of difference.

The most embarrassing parts of Fire and Fury are not the snarky gossip but the transcripts of the U.S. President's actual remarks. Wolff helps us understand the chaotic environment behind these bizarre pronouncements.Wolff reports a White House as divided as the U.S. Congress, with tea party Bannonites on one side, Jarvanka neocons on the other side, and the President bouncing randomly between.Michael Wolff has great advantages in telling this story because he can write well (few in the White House can), he's well-read (few in the White House are), he's well-connected to New York media outlets (he's a writer), and he's a welcome guest in Manhattan society salons.Wolff's biggest bombshell in "Fire and Fury" comes not from "inside the Trump White House" but from a dinner party at Steve Bannon's apartment in Arlington, Virginia, on July 20, 2017 -- source of the "crack Don Jr. like an egg" line and many other apparently tape-recorded zingers (pages 275-282).Other Highlights Include:p. 70 - Trump as Sun God.p. 58 - One paragraph connecting David Bossie, Steve Bannon, Andrew Breitbart, Robert Mercer, Ronald Reagan and Donald Trump!p. 186 - The email, supposedly from Gary Cohn, that begins, "It's worse than you can imagine. An idiot surrounded by clowns." And then gets personal!p. 250 - "...this constant, daily, often more than once-a-day, pileup of events -- each one canceling out the one before -- is the true aberration and novelty at the heart of the Trump presidency." -- Michael Wolffp. 256 - Did Jared Kushner leak the Trump Tower meeting email to skew the Russia investigation toward Don Jr. (a.k.a. "Fredo")?Bravo to Michael Wolff for being able to hit a moving target and keep it entertaining!Review Â©2018 by Steve O'Keefe, Executive Director, Staunton Media Lab.Page numbers correspond to the edition reviewed:"Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House," by Michael WolffPublished by Henry Holt & Co, 2018, Hardcover, ISBN 978-1250158062

For the past year I have felt as though I have been trapped in a Mel Brooks movie gone horribly wrong.  Not so very long ago, the very notion of Donald Trump as President of the United States would have been seen as beyond absurd and a great topic for comic relief.  Of course, in real-life it is not so funny as his unparalleled ignorance has real-life consequences.Along comes Mike Wolff & the present "tell-all" book of what has gone on behind the scenes in the Whitehouse over the past yr.  Perhaps the single most startling thing about the book is that nothing within its pages is particularly startling to any objective person who has truly been paying attention to what has been going on since January 2017.  That is to say, the dumpster fire known as the Trump administration is as chaotic & disorganized on the inside as it appears to be on the outside.Nevertheless, the book certainly has its utility as it penetrates behind the faÃ§ade of the Whitehouse.  While Steve Bannon is quite an odious character, he nonetheless seems to be the one person in the entire Trump cabinet who is endowed with a modicum of common sense.  He tried to talk POTUS out of firing his F.B.I. director & sundry other bad decisions only to be overruled.  Coincidentally, ostensibly Bannon is also the only cabinet member who has ever bothered to pick up a book.Some hard-line Right wingers will cry foul as there are a few minor factual errors in the book in regards to dates / times / places.  Fair enough.  However, there is no reason to reject the gist of the book as much of what has already been written has been corroborated.  It is no secret that Trump is impulsive, has a short attention span, is a control freak and has to be babysat more than any other President in history.  Nor is this a Left wing conspiracy as Senator Jeff Flake has compared Trump to Stalin and Senator Bob Corker described the Whitehouse as an "adult daycare."  Flake & Corker are both Republicans who "tell it like it is" (well, most of the time anyway).Beyond that it is with quite a degree of audacity that people who would call out the present book for errors would @ the same time overlook huge outright lies from Trump in regards to crowd size @ his inauguration, millions if illegals voting for Hillary & his being wiretapped by Obama.  This stuff is straight out ofÂ 1984 (Signet Classics)Â folks!!It will be interesting to read a retrospective on the Trump as President fiasco, regardless of how things turn out.  While it appears that the administration will face the same fate as the HINDENBURG, I suppose only time will tell.  In the meantime, this is a great inside-look at the "island of misfit toys" running the executive branch of our government.  Some of this book is quite funny, but in a macabre sort of way;  just keep that in mind if you choose to read it.

This very engaging book may not be a work of classic journalism and detail, but the over all story is supported by what we already know - and what Trump unwittingly reinforces virtually every day through observable behaviors that perfectly mirror the behaviors described in the book.  And ask yourself this: If the book is "fake" as Trump says, why the rage at Bannon? Isn't Bannon also a victim?  Trump must not think so, since he clearly believes the authors attributions to Bannon.  The book sheds a lot of light on the internal rivalries within Trump' s orbit. And it makes a very credible case that those who fear and/or loath Trump most are those closest to him and who toil to create the illusion of normalcy and decency around a President who is neither normal nor decent. These are perilous times and I believe this books sheds needed light on the dark forces now at the center of our government.

I bought the book yesterday and am more than half way through it.  Itâ€™s an extremely insightful read and a lucid window into the donaldâ€™s head space and entourage.  The negative reviews claiming that it is poorly written, has grammatical and punctuation errors are a lame attempt to discredit its veracity.  As a linguist, writer and grammarian, I can attest to the fact that it is well-writtenâ€”both from a mechanical standpoint as well as that of the syntactical.  Those reviewers attempting to paint the authorâ€™s writing skills in such a glaringly negative light evidently have no understanding of what quotations or direct quotes are.  This runs parallel to their cries that the media spews â€œfake newsâ€ù simply when it reports something unsavory which this administration and their ilk have actually said.Props to both Wolff and Bannonâ€”the latter to whom I never, in my wildest dreams, thought Iâ€™d ever express such sentimentsâ€”for sharing their stories.  This is truly a must-read and a defining moment of this surreal abduction of the highest office in our land.  It is a fascinating glimpse into the wizard behind the curtain, and it provides hope for logical individuals that there is a light at the end of this seemingly bleak tunnel.Buy it; read it; share it with friends, family, colleagues, and acquaintances.  Neither you nor they will be disappointed in the least.

Goshâ€_where to start a review on Fire and Fury? First, a lot of people have criticized Michael Wolffâ€™s writing style. I agree with those people. His run-on sentences frequently forced me, by the time I reached the end of the sentence, to return to the beginning to help me understand what he was trying to say. Slowed me down. He also uses a lot of obscure words. There were typos. It appears to me that he wrote this book quickly so it could be published before the end of Trumpâ€™s first year in the White House. The content is, however, more important than the style.Friends, our country is in big, big trouble. I realize there are critics and Trump supporters who say that the situation at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue cannot be as bad as depicted in F & F. Yes it can be! I thought that President Obama was an amateur and, yes he was. The difference between Obama and Trump is that Obama surrounded himself with good, experienced people and then listened to them. Trump, in spite of his business experience, which is not as great as he makes it out to be, is clearly an amateur as far as managing a country is concerned and has hired a bunch of nincompoops and empire builders to help him screw things up. â€œJarvankaâ€ù as Wolff refers to Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump, have no business in the West Wing, whispering in Trumpâ€™s ear. Steve Bannon, according to the book, was trying to set himself up in the White House to get his agenda in the forefront of â€œTrumpianâ€ù plans. That would be awful in the extreme. The parade of folks into and out of the West Wing has shown that nobody can please Trump for long and that there will be no stability in the Executive Branch of the government until Trump is gone, hopefully in three more years. That assumes we have not gotten into a nuclear war with N Korea before then and given Trump's lack of understanding of diplomacy and the ramifications of pushing his â€œbigger button,â€ù we may be in one before long. I was a bit surprised that N Korea was not mentioned more in the book.Throughout the book Trumpâ€™s intelligence is assaulted by the people closest to him. Certainly they know him better than I do and I have to take their word on that subject. Certainly some of the things he has said show arrogance as well as a lack of understanding about the most basic of things important to the country and the world.While some of what is in the book may be exaggerated or fabrications, IMHO the greater part is true. Certainly a lot of what Wolff writes about played out in the media over the last year. What Wolff provides is the background on how these events got out of the inner circle into the light of day. Scary, sad, really worrisome. It is quite easy to associate what is in the book with the first year history of the Trump administration and Trump himself. Interestingly, the book stops in October, with the departure of Steve Bannon from the White House. Reviewing the three months since then, it is hard to believe just how much other ridiculous stuff has happened. It never seems to stop. A new day, more faux pas and more cover-ups and outright lies.Read this book. You will be both glad you did and scared to death.

Fire and Fury profiles a White House in chaos and a president with serious mental problems who has no attention span or capacity to listen, read, and learnâ€”a man who made four-year-old-bored-boy faces when briefed about the specifics of the Constitution or health care reform or any policy matter, a man who landed the most important job in the world without meaning to, a man whose main concerns are being liked, getting richer, and playing golf.I read the Kindle version, which like the hardback, was launched early in response to Trump's attempt to block publication. It is in severe need of proofreading. (My favorite typo: "Bannon, with mounting ferocity and pubic (sic) venom . . .") As an editor, I am annoyed, however the sloppiness does match its subjects, who have zero respect for care and the painstaking effort it takes to do something well. So there is a certain karmic justice and artistic symmetry to the current picture:(1) This blustery self-promoter with no scruples rides the free publicity of the media's fascination with his insanity, and he uses the coverage to stoke self-righteous rage and promises to use the loopholes and outright illegal tactics that made him wealthy to benefit the little guys, so they vote for him.(2) Once in office, his lack of knowledge of, let alone care about, the law as well as his self-involved rage and inability to understand anything other than winning/losing or praise/criticism throw the White House and the world into chaos.(3) A well-known "slasher" writer uses the open access granted him by an administration who loves attention and has no understanding of who the writer is (because vetting is not their style), not to mention the difference between on and off the record, and he hangs out, amiably observing and making nice, then succeeds in weaving his observations into an addictive storyâ€”an almost impossible-to-accomplish narrative given the a level of insanity, chaos, and its myriad participantsâ€”and it all goes into a sloppily made book, rushed to publication to cash in on the free publicity of its subject trying to quash it . . . and hopefully it eventually does the job the Trump voters wanted: blowing up the swamp.

America was to be a nation defined and formed by its people - not a monarch - not a dictator â€“ not bullying lawyers, and not self-serving politicians who incidentally donâ€™t have to worry about social security since we have set them up with lucrative benefits and retirement packages paid for by us â€“ their tax paying employers - the People of the United States, the people to whom they should be answerable.If this book and all the other reports and events surrounding this presidency and indeed the GOPâ€™s machinations and self-interest were a report on the status of a corporation for which the average manager had responsibility â€“ heads would role!We the People need to stand up, be informed, be heard and find responsible, accountable leadership for better choices in future elections â€“ to regain and preserve what was once the dignified, respected and progressive United States of America â€“ not the mockery and lie this administration has made of this country and democracy.Based on excerpts, the book will likely make me ill, and will require some skepticism for embellishment. Wolff is no liberal, and Fire and Fury is not particularly well written or analytic (the basic structure is chronological). Yet somehow this makes his portrayal of a White House in perpetual disarray all the more disturbing. The portrait of the president that emerges is that of a needy L'enfant terrible who never expected to win and is unable to attend to even the most basic tasks of governing for even a few minutes, but incapable of delegating even vital responsibilities to others in an organized way. Instead the President plays off one feuding faction against the other as if in some kind of reality tv show based on whim, deep insecurity, and the habitual need to always blame others when something goes wrong.The White House is seen as a scrum of feuding factions each less competent than the other. Jared and Ivanka, â€œJarvanka,â€ù are seen as the driving force behind firing Comey. Wolff sees Bannon as itching to infuriate moderates and liberals under a theory of change that radicalizing the left will drive the middle into his hands. Yet a more likely hypothesis is that he and Miller successfully burned and bridges to moderates before they could be built to isolate the President from more moderate elements within the White House and his own party. Indeed, Wolffâ€™s Trump seems like he would be just fine with a single payer health care system as long as Trump got the credit and the love and adoration that he perpetually craves.One is tempted to think that surely things canâ€™t get any worse â€“ until you remember that the president has his finger on the button. If even half of what Wolff wrote is true we are in deep, deep â€œstuff.â€ù

The only thing more difficult to get through than this book is Trump's presidency. There are far too many spelling errors and sentences that just don't make sense at all. To the actual content of the book; many statements are preceded by a disqualifying statement, like "She often thought, though perhaps she didn't", or "His view of Trump, though he never said so, was".... Really?This book is just not worth your time.
