I'm one third through the book.  The book gives a quite convincing explanation of who Donald Trump is, how he operates, and how those around him operate. It's extremely readable and interesting.  Michael Wolff is not a 100% reputable journalist.  He's previously been criticized for inaccuracies.  He appears to have spent a few months writing articles praising Trump and attacking the media as a way of getting access to Trump.  With that said, if had not done so, he wouldn't have received the access to write this book.  He quotes a number of people in the book.  Very few of them have later said that he misquoted them.  Steve Bannon, for instance, just recently said that he didn't intend to refer to Donald, Jr., in criticizing the meeting with the Russians.  It appears that the account is mainly accurate.  The people who have criticized it are mainly the people least likely to be believed.  I would not be surprised if this book establishes in people's mind the identity of the real Donald Trump.  The most reputable journalists will now attempt to confirm the accounts in it and the general substance of the outline he has portrayed.  Unfortunately, this book does not provide any information as to how to counter Trump.  It shows the Emperor with no clothes; however, it's always been obvious how much of a huckster Donald Trump is.

Most of what's in this book shouldn't come as a surprise to most people. However, will that stop you from devouring the contents in glee? Likely not. Or you'll denounce the book as "fake". Either way, this book will be polarizing and at the end of the day, I hope it doesn't impact your ability to be objective and skeptical.I typically do my reviews in a Pros/Cons format which is hard to pull off here. I can't really do that here: no winners or losers. Just people suffering from the current state of affairs regardless of who voted for which side and who didn't. Or who couldn't vote. If you dissect any person's life or approach to life like the author has done in this book, it's not hard to portray said life in any sort of outlandish manner. However, Trump makes it easy.Do you really want to read  about Gawker, Louise Mensch, WWE, Ms Universe and Trump? If so, you're in luck. This book has it all but I really recommend you pace yourself and put the book down. Or else you'll feel gluttonously disgusted with the contents you've gleefully gobbled if you chose to go that route. I mean do you really want to reminded of the blank sheets and empty binders? Do you? Well, you're in luck!I've docked a star because the sensationalist and outlandish tone of the book makes me wonder if what I've read is true. I'd have liked the author to have presented as bulletproof a publication as possible. However, as the author himself mentions, this book wasn't supposed to be: his initial effort was to catalog/keep an account of the administration's first 100 days. Turns out he got a bit more than he bargained for. Still, in the interests of "journalism", would be nice to see fewer author claims and more concrete references/proof, if that's even possible for something like this...

In spite of the co-ordinated push back against this book â€” from the pro-Trump media and from orthodox journalists who refused to burn their boats with the White House â€” this is a very good book. It is psychologically insightful about Donald Trump, his salesmanâ€™s mentality, and his obsession with his only saleable commodity - the Trump brand itself. The Donald has a New York real estate dealerâ€™s conception of a deal: you work the phones, schmooze, and get the suckers to like you. If a sucker doesnâ€™t like you â€” no sale â€” then a ton of invective and opprobrium is dumped on their head. If that ever worked in the Big Apple, it is not how you run an administration nor conduct diplomacy. If Donald were happy watching TV and tweeting while someone else ran the show, that might work. But he cannot bear being overshadowed and, one by one, anyone who gets more or better Press than him is out. The book concludes with Steve Brannonâ€™s assessment of the odds: 33% impeachment; 33% resignation following cabinet pressure; 33% the chaos continues to full term but The Donald does not seek re-election. While I am not temperamentally inclined to agree with Bannon, those odds look right to me.

Michael Wolff is an able story-telling talent that can take a vanilla story and chronicle it as a worthwhile buying composition.  In Fire and Fury he penetrates a tight, self proclaimed towering group, and unlike other reporters, delivers the American public a detailed account of the inner workings of the White House.Michael Wolff's Fire and Fury as well written as it is, is an even greater display of strategic thinking.  To craft it, he penetrates the White House, and gets a President's inner circle to reveal unprecedented non-flattering details inside White House grounds. Startling!  One must ask, who else would have the intuitive thinking to pull it off?  And equally important, who could time a book release better or more fortuitous withing the context it plays?Michael Wolff not only is uniquely talented as an "investigative information" collector, he shows superior writing skills when it comes to transforming the raw data into a captivating narrative.

What is surprising about this book is that it's not all that surprising.  Michael Wolff has just put together the most comprehensive narrative about the complete disorganization in the Trump White House that has been obvious from Day One.  Although some of that may have improved with Bannon out and Kelly in, nothing will ever rein in Donald Trump, so the dam must constantly be plugged.  Just as the staff stamps out one fire, their boss fires another flame in another direction and they rush off to damp it down.  His inflated ego coupled with his childlike personality must be exhausting for those who find themselves, inexplicably, working for him.Were he not in a position which demands leadership skills coupled with a command of complex subjects, this book would be the political version of the Kardashians.  He's like an actor who managed to play the part of a businessman on t.v. but is finding playing the President more difficult, especially when others expect him to listen to them instead of hearing his endless stories. Thankfully, probably against all advice, Trump demanded that the publisher withdraw this book from publication which absolutely ensured it would be an overnight best seller.  As evidenced by the stunning number of reviews posted for a book published less than 36 hours before, even the most strident Trump supporters must know that freedom of the press is a bedrock of American democracy and that someone who is, like, very smart, should surely know that his actions would have the absolute reverse of what he intended.Of all the scary details in the book, none are as frightening as the thought that the guy at the top might throw a tantrum that could lead to far more serious consequences.  If Mr. Trump wants to prove he's, you know, like a genius, maybe he could volunteer to take a standard Scholastic Achievement Test and, if he can't score at least average, well, he should, you know, take a few classes and let some adults fill in for him until he learns basic sentence structure, what uranium is, and how to find, say, Kansas, on a map.  Or perhaps, like Barack Obama and Bill Gates, Mr.Trump could make a list of the ten best books he read in 2017.  As if.It's possible that in his former life, he made promises all the time that he was never going to keep.  He probably forgot within minutes that he'd made the promise, leaving bewildered people wondering what happened.  If they became an aggravation, he could sue or just block their calls.  He is, no doubt, doing the same thing to members of Congress and his own staff, some of whom may remain ever hopeful.  Good luck with that.

There is something that feels slightly off in this book's narrative.  It's 'fly-on-the-wall' feel, especially regarding the period from the nomination to the election, is too cute by half.  The narrative of the author (and by obvious extension, Bannon) is designed (and feels contrived) to get us to believe that Trump and his people, couldn't have possibly colluded with the Russians because a.) they were massively inept, and b.) not one of them believed there was a chance in hell, that they could win.This narrative is tightly and systematically woven into the entire book.  It feels designed to re-direct our gaze away from even a possibility that Trump's entire team, as well as the Mercers' and Ailes, participated in, or had knowledge of, Russian collusion.  But this is not credible given the "surprise" primary wins.  Why wouldn't they believe that there was a path to victory, or at least a small possibility of one?This book feels like a carefully and surreptitiously crafted effort to throw shade on Russian collusion.

How did we get to this point?  Like so many other reviewers, I had no intention of buying this book until the President tried to suppress it.In this country, we have freedom of the press.  Prior restraint is suppressing written material before it is disseminated.  It is only reserved for violations of trade secrets, sensitive medical information or matters of national security.Only Nixon, among modern Presidents, ever tried to suppress publication of events pertaining to the White House.Trump has not only shown himself to be an unstable and dangerous leader but truly a dictator who believes he can take our First Amendment rights away from us. Even if nothing in this book is true, Trump's actions in trying to suppress the book speak the most loudly. And I certainly suspect that much of the material in this book is true.Shame on Donald Trump and shame on us for electing this individual when we should have seen what was coming.Five star kudos for having the guts to write this.  Hopefully, this is the beginning of the end to this tyrant.

Reading this is basically reading a CliffsNotes for 2017. If youâ€™re an avid news reader like me, youâ€™ll remember each and every one of these events, with the added bonus of the behind-the-scenes context Wolff provides.What I find most interesting about this book, which Stephen Miller decried as â€œa pile of garbage... poorly written fiction,â€ù is how plausible it all sounds. Thereâ€™s nothing here that strains credulity. The issue of Donald Trumpâ€™s mental stability? Weâ€™ve all been watching him ramble, repeat himself, and get lost in asides that go nowhere for two years now. And letâ€™s not forget the early morning tweets threatening nuclear war with â€œlittle rocket man(?)â€ù and bragging that DTâ€™s nuclear button is â€œbigger than his.â€ùThe stuff about Mueller investigating the Trump familyâ€™s money? We already know for a fact that he is, and we know because he brought a prosecutor onto his team who specializes in prosecuting money laundering . We also know he brought that prosecutor on not long after Trump said investigating his or his familyâ€™s finances would be a red line that would cause him to dismiss Mueller. Jared Kushner recently beefed up his team of lawyers by hiring one adept in defending people accused of white-collar money crimes. Coincidence?Especially galling is the constant bleating of â€œfake newsâ€ùfrom the White House. Whatâ€™s fake? The fact that DT Junior met with Russian operatives in Trump Tower, along with Manafort and Kushner? Their own emails confirm it. Is the claim that Trump wrote Juniorâ€™s statement about the meeting, which potentially obstructed justice? The White House acknowledged that he wrote it. The voice on the Access Hollywood tape-was that faked? Oddly, Trump now claims it was.It goes on and on and on and on and on. The statements made to Wolff during his interviews ring true, despite the claims of his sources. He may have printed off-the-record comments, according to what some have said, but since he wrote a couple of seemingly pro-Trump (or at least anti- anti-Trump) stories over the past two years, it seems more likely that Trump & Co. thought Wolff was looking to write a friendly book, and therefore he was given full access and carte blanche. Yikes.We all remember Trump defending white supremacist rioters after the debacle in Charlottesville cost a young woman her life. We all remember the so-called â€œtravel ban.â€ù We all remember the birther conspiracy Trump pushed (again exposing his ignorance of the Constitution; citizenship is automatically granted to the children of American citizens, regardless of what country they are born in.) all of this stuff happened, and to claim otherwise is gaslighting on such an enormous scale it literally boggles the mind.The biggest story here is that the Presidentâ€™s inner circle doesnâ€™t think much of him. Some wondered aloud to Wolff whether DT is only â€œsemi-literateâ€ù because of his aversion to reading. Others mention his propensity for simply leaving the room if an explanation becomes too detailed. Still others believe that he is senile, and point to the way he speaks. Many of his friends just call him stupid(!).On that note, itâ€™s best to acknowledge that anyone who said what these people said to Michael Wolff would of course try to deny or walk back their comments. Trumpâ€™s entire team, from Paul Manafort, Stephen Miller, Kellyanne Conway, etc.- including his kids-are nothing but a bunch of B and C team flunkies who latched on to their only ticket to the big time because no one else would have them.â€œFire and Furyâ€ù paints a picture of a president who is hypersensitive, angry, ignorant of his office and the Constitution that empowers it, and potentially senile (statistically possible, as by age 71, the odds are pretty high even when not factoring in his well known affinity for fast food, aversion to excercize, his obesity, and his own fatherâ€™s Alzheimerâ€™s diagnosis). At the very least, the fact that such an incurious and egotistical person could be elevated to our highest office must give us all pause.Update 1/14/18- Since this book was published, a number of people have questioned Wolffâ€™s credibility, accused him of making it all up, and claimed he published â€œoff-the-recordâ€ù quotes and information. But almost no one named in the book has stepped forward to dispute the broad outlines or their own comments as featured in the book; any that have, have done so only in the most half-hearted manner. That alone tells us a lot about Trumpâ€™s â€œteamâ€ù. #Winning

Perhaps the most surprising thing to me about Fire and Fury is not that Trump apparently lost some his marbles during his scalp reduction surgery but that that Michael Wolff is actually a terrific writer.  After all, the book's main points are hardly revelations. But Wolff's sharp focus has somehow managed to create an emperor-has-no-clothes moment.About the writing:  One hears gripes, of course, from some reporters from major papers that Wolff does not follow their procedural conventions.  He never purported to do so.  But I wonder whether part of the reason for sour grapes is that Wolff can write circles around most of those reporters.  His prose is full of nuance, with detonations of diction that vacillates from the profane to the erudite, and with a vocabulary that no doubt is well beyond the reach of our semi-literate "stable genius."Another thing worth noting is that Fire and Fury actually is not about Trump; it's about the people around Trump.  Many of them are backpedaling from the book's content, even if they supplied that content.  But imagine that both Wolff and those West Wingers were subjected to a broad lie-detector test about the books content.  I have little doubt that Wolff would fare better.

Like others, I wasn't planning to buy this book until Trump tried to stop its release. I was surprised to find, however, that it is well written and thorough, and it is clear that the author was meticulous in documenting all his interactions and interviews. Although we are all too familiar by now with Trump's character, this book is interesting because it shows how his inner circle operates, reacts, and plays off his simplistic and predictable behavior. Frankly, I am sick of hearing about the antics of Trump every single day, but I did enjoy reading this book to learn about the people around him. On a technical note, there were a few typos in the text (missing verbs, misspellings of names, etc), and I wish the editors had done better so it didn't undercut the credibility of the manuscript, but I do appreciate how quickly the book came out.

Whether all the information in the book is 100% verifiable is probably not the point. Most of it rings true to anyone who has a wide view of politics and the news. Mr. Wolff's narrative style and choice vocabulary made this book a most enjoyable read.

I found "Fire and Fury" to be a very entertaining and enlightening look inside the Trump White House. Although I knew about many of Trump's *ahem* character flaws, the book sheds light on the ways he thinks and operates that still blew my mind. Although Trump and his team have been actively attempting to discredit and dismiss this book, you can tell very quickly as you read it that it's largely true. The level of detail and preciseness of the claims feel authentic and factually match most of what has been leaked and reported the past year. Anyway - a great read - highly recommend.

This was a riveting look "behind the curtain" at Trump as president.  Well written book (hard-bound or Audio Book version) is one that I found difficult to put down.  So much to learn and discover, I think even an 'outsider' would be amazed how much turmoil occurs, hidden from the public, within the Whitehouse and at off-site meetings (often during working lunches, dinners, while on Air force One), and at myriad other venues.  It makes the reader dread what other shenanigans POTUS will pull as he staggers to the end of his term (unless he's impeached or convicted of a crime or multiple crimes) which would bring an immediate end to his lies, obstruction of justice, adinfinitum while 'acting' as POTUS. One can only hope it will happen.

If you're looking for an analysis of Trump's policies, don't waste your $. If you're looking for a book about the people in the WH in the early days of the Trump presidency, you found it.The author writes well, a fact overlooked by most of the media The press releases hinted @ a vengeful author, but that's not accurate. It isn't  that he forgives the errors made by the inexperienced Trump WH, it's that he understands why they could have happened.The teasers in the press release are all here, but they're surrounded by back story & front story & seem less harsh. This is a story about bumbling, prideful people who never expected their candidate to win. They all (including Trump) hoped to become rich(er) & famous from the campaign & go on with their improved lives when he lost.  No one had a policy on anything.By no one, I mean no one except Steve Bannon. There are no back stories or explanations softening Bannon's image. His takeover of the WH is astonishing & its no surprise when a bewildered Jared Kushner asks, "What happened to Steve?"The media gets their share of fun-poking criticsm.  His description of small New York newspapers catering to the actions of the wealthy is spot on; you can just see the smugness radiating from the page. Disclaimer: I'm 1/2 way through the book & will update. I wanted to start a review to encourage Trump haters& Trump lovers to consider reading the book. It is NOT a book on policy

I've read a good deal of this so far.  The first thing the reader MUST do is to put aside the fact that Wolff and Bannon have very serious conflicts with Trump.Do yourself a favor and avoid taking sides while reading Fire and Fury.It is NOT about how terrible Trump is (although, he is indeed a man with some disturbing self-perspectives)  It is NOT about why Trump shouldn't be where he is today, though he most certainly should not be.What it IS about, is how he got there; how he and his campaign literally scammed 62,979,879 voters with one goal in mind simply to improve his global standing - he didn't even want to win the election.  Rather; it was about the Trump brand and identity he would vastly improve upon had he become close to winning.If you do, I promise you that you will gain some extraordinarily disturbing and frightening facts about our election process and the insight into those who actually run this nation.Fire and Fury book is a dead serious look into the extreme delicateness of what we like to call "our democracy." It will shake your faith in our system; in humanity; and most of all, it will utterly destroy your false sense of empowerment in our current election system.You will walk away with a deeply disturbing reality that, due to big money, gerrymandering, and the Electoral College, just how unimportant your vote truly is.The book is extraordinarily intriguing and informative. As you read, remembering many recent wild and historical events, the ups and downs of Trump's behavior, his ever-changing policy directions and acidic remarks directed at all who don't kneel in praise of Donald J Trump SR, you begin to see the man who, with a complete lack of understanding of the global and domestic politics alike, Trump's vision, or utterly absent vision, one gets the very clear picture of the chaotic White House we've seen for now almost a year and the single most attributable cause for that chaos; Donald J Trump.You know?  We are constantly bombarded with cliches, one in particular; "Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it".  I cannot think of another example, living or dead, that the scenario in which we find ourselves today is more applicable.  If we fail to learn from this disastrous event, we, as a freedom-loving Republic will repeat it until we too are a page in history.

It's the right book at the right time, and I wouldn't have bought it without Trump's enthusiastic non-endorsement. But let's face the fact that it's not great literature and probably will be forgotten shortly after Trump leaves office.

Much has been made of his excerpted quote that Donald Trump Jr. was treasonous in meeting with Russian agents in Trump Tower in June 2016. Difficult to read. His writing is awkward. An overuse of obscure or rarely used words, such as: aphoristic, shambolic (which I found is a Briticism), voluble, cosseted, solipsism, indefatigability, and a real corker, one I've never seen, PERSIFLAGE. For a book dealing basically in what I consider to be gossip, these are fancy words. I'm guessing he thinks this lends some kind of intellectual aura to his "writing"...IN MY OPINION. I don't mind turning to the dictionary for unfamiliar terms, but his use of  bulky terms where plain English would work better and have a better effect for the reader is unfortunate, and frankly tiresome and distracting. I'm sorry I bought this book, which at this point is more historical than current.

This book was worth every penny. I read it in 2 days. A really detailed narrative of the Trump White House. Couldn't believe how much i had already forgotten. The Jarvanka fans will not be disappointed.

Book was different than I expected. Initially I thought it would be a typical political type book with lots of inside gossip. This book is a devastating indictment of Donald Trump. It captures at a granular level the rot of Trump, his family and his administration.
No matter what you think about Trump, you need to listen to this
Awesome book  wasnt really  shocked by most of the things  that were written I bought this book to exercise my 1st  admendment  right

I just purchased this book to ensure that it gets out into the wild. The man who has no clothes in the WH does not get to shut down publication of this book. I will read it tonight, and be back to finish up my review.

Fire and Fury dominated the news cycle last week and I succumbed, not knowing if the book would be readable. Wolfe clearly got the bulk of his information from Bannon (Iâ€™d be interested in knowing whether Bannon is receiving a cut of the profits), but it is also clear that the author had access to the White House during Bannonâ€™s tenure. Ultimately, this book brings together all the prurient details that kept us interested in the Trump presidency during its first several months.
Really liked the clear and concise explanation of events and relationships. Written in chronological order, very easy to follow. Worth reading as it very well may be part of history.
The Truth must come out like this!

Written a bit chaotically.  Seemed to be mostly about what Bannon thinks of Trump.  Both, as well as the rest of the characters, and they are characters, came across as self aggrandizing loonies.  Which, by the way, is basically how they have been portrayed all along by press and other reports and themselves.  I found little new information in the book which I had not already gleaned myself.  But still horrifying, none the less.  How could this have happened is a question we still need to figure out and do something to keep it from happening ever again.
Excellent  read.  If you want to understand what you read in news about the White House - read this.  The personal dynamics are fascinating - and appalling...

I thought the book is an important contribution to the analysis of the competency of the president. It portrays Trump's weaknesses in all manner of things: temperament, intellect, morality, judgment, balance, motivation, and so on. It also portrays an incredibly dysfunctional White House with competing factions and astonishing ineptitude. Clearly the president is woefully unqualified to be president, his staff is similarly out of its league, and the result is an ongoing catastrophe. The author is a decent writer. My main criticism of the book is that it is often unclear whether Wolff's assertions and quotations are literal or deduced. Nonetheless, it is impossible to dispute that Donald Trump is grotesquely unfit for the office and the people around him are no better.

Amazing and horrifying. People, I remember Dwight Eisenhower! The GOP would sneer a  t him today, he was an honorable man. Nixon was weird and paranoid, but he was intelligent; a statesman. The Bushes? meh. Too embroiled with the Saudis. And now we have a demagogue, an infantile out of control manchild, and America seems to be stuck for the moment. This book has its hilarious moments, but underneath it all is the sadness that dementia rules DC now.  Anyway, read it. Then read Sinclair Lewis' "It Can't Happen Here"........(quote) Doremus Jessup, the protagonist of Sinclair Lewis's 1935 novel â€œIt Can't Happen Here,â€ù sees something dark and terrible brewing in American politics â€” the potential for â€œa real fascist dictatorshipâ€ù led by the up-and-coming populist candidate Berzelius Windrip. ... â€œThat couldn't happen here in America, not possibly!â€ù  (unquote)Oh yes it can.  And has.

I have watched the events described in this book unfold over the past two years.  Reading this account of these events in sequence with some insights into why and how many strange and unacceptable actions took place was helpful.  Nothing was truly new or surprising to those of us who have been following the Trump phenomenon but might be to many.  It's an easy read although a bit of a horror story.  I think we need a second book to cover the next year of this unusual presidency.  It might be titled The Fall of the Republican Party.
Another book that tells you what you can see for yourself and backs it up with fact.  If only people would stop making excuses for this behavior and start demanding a correction.

The fact that this author was able to sit in the White House for so many months without anyone checking his past books is enough to convince me that the White House is as one republican senator put it, â€œAn adult daycare centerâ€ù. Interesting read, but I also probably would not have bought it if Trump had kept his mouth shut about it.
An interesting and insightful look into the inner workings of the Trump campaign and presidency, focused on the dysfunctional team surrounding the president and of course Trump himself.
Every voter must read this book. It provides the information about how the White House actually runs. It is not pretty. You will never ask why the US is like it is, you will know why.
It's worse than we imagined. There is no joy in being correct in our assumptions regarding the Trump White House. Will our democracy withstand this administration? Stay tuned...
Bought this just because it pissed of the President so much. Even bought my brother a copy. Havent read it yet. But the passages I have seen are hilarious. I will enjoy this tremendously.
The Portrayal of the dysfunction

Fire and Fury reads well as a contemporaneous report of the early Trump presidency.  Most observant viewers of current events will have reached similar conclusions, Donald Trump is a simple minded narcissist incapable of higher thought processes, a juvenile personality who managed to fool twenty five percent of registered American voters and win the office.  If the quotes sited (There are few actual quotes footnoted, unattributed sources abound.) are to be trusted, Trump is every bit the buffoon caricature that he has presented himself to be through his tweets, and public rambling speeches.Michel Wolff has written a concise account, but not a deep cover expose.  It may well prove useful in the future to chronicle the Trump years to those too young, or too naive to understand what they see in current news cycles, but for others it only adds to their contempt for the President by adding more noise to the anti-Trump echo chamber.I am pleased that I bought and read this book, I am not sufficiently impressed that I will follow Michael Wolff and buy other books that he may write.  Had the President not made the book noteworthy by his attentions, I doubt that I would have bought it.  I never bought any of Kitty Kelly's tell all books and discounted her work as yellow journalism unworthy of support.
The book details all of the issues we had imagined but werenâ€™t sure of that makes Trump tick. It added a sense of veracity to the thought that our government is running on very thin ice.
From the inside what we've all known and suspected by watching from the outside.
Excellent book and a lot of information.Thanks to the author. Bought two , one for mySon.
Michael Wolff really has an extended vocabulary.  He uses many big or seldom-used words.  I'm enjoying the book, but not the fact that I have to have a dictionary close by.

Delicious. I certainly hope someone has purchased the rights to produce the film -- going to be a hoot! Bought the book to pay homage to the First Amendment. Validation of our experience in this first chaotic year of a reality character, not presidential, this book is perfect because it is not heady, or an intellectual rendition of a man -- it matches quite well in a style that mirrors the ego driven, insecure tweeting child. Madmen era, indeed!Then, there is the moment when one realizes he is the president. Pray we make it through without too much damage and embarrassment.
Excellent book about the disgusting child who continues to ruin our country daily. I am so looking forward to his impeachment!
I worked at a bookstore through the Obama years and had to deal with inflammatory trash reaching the best seller list because of Republicans. This book makes me happy
This book articulates what we all knew:Trump knew very little, could analyze or synthesize even less and his presidency a fluke.
Engaging, entertaining and mostly terrifying. A quick, easy read. Hard to put down, especially if you've been glued to the chaos and dysfunction since Trump's inauguration.
Didnâ€™t need to read. The major points had all been stated on tv. But thatâ€™s ok. Iâ€™ll support anyone who realizes tRUMP is a zero. Would have paid twice what I did. Thanks!

I had already pretty much figured out Trump from the first day of his "Presidential campaign".But my question is: how could so many people possibly think Trump would care about anyone else but himself? The Grab 'em by the **** revelation didn't phase his voters, or not releasing his tax returns, while CLEARLY not knowing or caring how the US government works much less what the Constitution says or the rule of law.When he WAS elected he was mortified. All Trump really wanted was to finish 2nd and to continue his money making endeavors with his own cable network - Trump TV.This is a crook and con man with DEEP financial ties to mob figures and Russia. Somehow, in his unimaginative 8 year old mind, thought all this would not come out. Or if it did, as President (he thinks Dictator/King) he could order citizens to ignore it all - it was a great big nothing burger.Trump also thought he could sue, even jail journalists and shut down the press. Trump thought he could order the DOJ and FBI to bend to his every desire. Those agencies work for the United States people NOT Trump.I purchased this book because I am a very concerned citizen. I am a Veteran and find Trump being in the Presidential office to be abhorrent. I believe in freedom of the press and no one is going to tell me what I can and can not read.Since he makes my head nearly explode every time he tweets or even speaks - I hope my book purchase contributes to paying him back in kind.
a must read for all americans
WOW....  CRAZY...  SCARY...

OK, so this is a no-class indulgence read and not a book you should rely on for accuracy. Wolff writes a lot of speculation and innuendo worded as if it is the truth. Read with a big dash of salt if you don't see quotes. Some of his news interviews after the book release were telling - he gets as slippery as Carter Page when pressed on some issues.I treated it as entertainment and enjoyed it for that. No particular earth-shaking insights, except how crazy the current White House must be.

It's marketed as a gossip book, but it has an INDEX and had three fact checkers. He is a master with language. Nikki Haley for example, is described as "as ambitious as Lucifer". His taste for publicity does his excellent work no favors.
Very interesting. Well written.

Like many, I have followed the months since January 20, 2017 with increasing horror and despair. I'm no more of a political junkie than your average bear, but immediately became intrigued as soon as Trump denigrated Wolff and even tried to staunch the book's release. Also notable to me is the curious lack of any specific denials from Trump's camp about the specifics of what was said. (Billionaire Mercer denying a quote or two is about as specific as it gets.) Clearly, Wolff collected a lot of smoke, and that smoke is somewhat analogous to a fire.Amongst journalistic circles, Wolff is regarded with suspicion, and unlike Trump, I heed the words of journalists, so I read taking any revelations with a grain of salt. However, anticipating the charge of "fake news," it appears Wolff also has hours of recordings of his subjects. Lordy, there are tapes.The book is engagingly written, with an air of can-you-believe-this-shit (no, most of us can't) and oodles of palace intrigue. I was fascinated that Melania was briefly mentioned - she desperately didn't want Trump to win - and then was a non-starter for the rest of the book. It's clear she isn't truly part of that world. Hope Hicks, Trump's now-28-year-old assistant, gets quite a few mentions in the book. Who is she - what's her deal? I found myself wanting to know more.Much of the book is spent on Steve Bannon, aka "Darth Vader," and the revelation at the end that he is seriously considering a 2020 presidential run? In the words of the ill-fated Sean Spicer (whose demise is chronicled in this tome) "You can't make that shit up."The biggest reveal of the book (and there are many) is that it's worse than we all thought - Trump is the Chauncy Gardner president, Caligula on steroids. He's a cipher - a nothing. There's nothing to analyze because there is nothing there. The book truly made me wonder if the 25th Amendment will get dusted off anytime soon, complacent Congress be damned.It's worth a read for the palace intrigue alone.God help us all.

I bought this book solely because of the threat to keep it from being sold. The book itself is OK, and many of the claims Wolff makes are not specific and unsubstantiated. However, if you like palace intrigue and gossip columns, this is the book for you. It's like game of thrones, but the decapitations are metaphorical.

Fundamentally important. The ring of truth as loud as the liberty bell -- what we've known about DJT from the tweets, we now know from the voice of a man who sat on a couch, observed, and wrote everything down. We're in uncharted territory -- whatever your political leaning, the chaos of the man at the top, the lack of executive functioning, has placed us all in peril. And Michael Wolf has detailed it all, admirably.

Having lived through the news cycles, it was good to see this all put together with insight.  The book was put together hastily and could use some editing. The many run-on sentences made it difficult to read at times.  However, I was fascinated by the book. I encourage the author to keep writing and publish a sequel.

A real revelation regarding the madness in the White House.  It confirms that some people will do anything for fame and money.  That wealth, power, fame come before country.  The book confirms my fear for the destruction of American  values and humanity and respect around the world.  The book is a hard read as there appeared to be purposefully placed words and jargons that did nothing to get the point across.  They were not cohesive with the overall language used.  They did not enhance the meaning or clarify the ideas or thoughts of the author.
Range...explicit wording...surprisingly number of people included...and to my belief, its authenticity!!

"fire and fury" paints a disturbing portrait of the Trump White House and it's cast of characters. Though much has been speculated on, Wolff seems to confirm the idea that Trump is a ranting, reactionary fool, while those around him are equally deluded opportunists.Most of the material appears to come from Bannon, a smug blowhard who cannot help but let those around him know hes smarter and more self righteous than they are, a predictably combustible attitude. The book does not, however, delve too deeply into the reality of Bannon's influence. Is he an architect of alt-rights populism and racial hatred? Can he effectively persuade and channel such energies? Whatever the case, the book portrays his almost-year in the White House as the inevitable rise and fall of a second-rate provocateur, one who fell into the trap of believing their own hype...much like Trump!That story is compelling. But it is not quite the tale the book promises. the gross dysfunction  of the  Trump White House is too often glossed over, without truly shocking details save for a handful of hissy fits. Readers will come away with characterizations of the "mysterious" Bannon, the banal ambitions of "Jarvanka", and maybe Hope Hicks (she comes off like a naive dope). But the backstabbing and dealmaking and temporary alliances-the kind of stuff that might make the Trump administration a sadder stupider version of "house of cards" or even "game of thrones"-isnt quite there.
Fire and Fury is Trump's mysterious "COVFEFE" tweet defined -Come-Over-Very-Fast-Everything's-Failing-Everywhere

Like others, I had no intention of buying this--what could it possibly add to the public record made by "the man" (and, come to think of it, the song of the same title by The Killers does come to mind), himself.  But, yeah, prior restraint?  Really?  It almost makes you wonder if The Donald and Wolffe had an agreement to split the royalties!  And...Flat Earth Society Members...Go!  Enjoy your cut of my $15, Mr. Wolffe.  You seem a little sketchy and I may not agree with your approach to narrative without attribution, but I'll defend to the death my right to read and decide for myself.  During my "executive time".  LOL
Anyone interest in politics and the strange bedfellows sucked into a campaign and, if they win, into office! We await the future of THIS one.

Excited to read Fire And Fury, it fairly weeds  the garden of Trumpism, creates a salad of personalities trying to sell the taste while being the seeds that get stuck in my teeth. This book is one to sink your teeth into, a delightful and oddly humorous treat.

I like his writing style, but I must admit I have to stop and look up word definitions here and there. Guess my vocabulary needs a little work.I'm only a few chapters in, and yeah, our president is insane. Like really, truly, incompetent. SAD!

Trump is like, really smart. He won the Presidency â€œon his first tryâ€ù most other Presidents needed 5 or 6 tried. Losers. Heâ€™s a super genius and really, really stable. Just ask him. You canâ€™t make this stuff up. Thatâ€™s why I think this book is right on the money. We elected a reality â€œstarâ€ù President of the United States. Weâ€™re one REALLY BIG button push away from total catastrophe. Thanks Trump voters. Everyone should read this book and buy one for your Trump voting friends and family.

This started out sounding like a Facebook post. Flat, subjective, created for gossiping interest. It developed into a fair tell all of behind the scenes machinations. It is still full of holes, many questions insinuated instead of answered but it does try hard to be unbiased in its lack of respect for both sides. What it does lack is the importance of risk to the country with this unstable White House. Maybe things needed to be shook up but hopefully it will not be destroyed by this particular group.

The book's well written and pulls together so lot of documented and well established information about the Trump operation.  It focuses pretty much with recent activities and not the earlier alleged financial ties to a variety of underworld groups, especially several in New York.  There are a few minor errors perhaps because of haste in getting it out in print.  Those are unfortunate but hardly significant in light of the facts reported.  Just gives critics a something to snip about.Overall, my view is that the book is valuable in pulling a lot of things together in one place, and providing a lot of documentation filed away in notes and tapes from interviews.  It does present a relatively negative picture of Trump as a person and much more as someone who lacks the intelligence and skill set to be President of the United States.Guess the whole read makes me a bit sad to see our politics slide down to such a low point, but finding just Trump.  Too many members of the Congress,, Senate and House, fail to measure up - and the leadership of both Houses really appears the worst since at least WW II.Didn't want to digress - but I guess the digression reflects a lot of the feelings the book has left with me.  It is a real shame we've let the divisions within get us to where we are.  Just hope we have the heart to get us back on track
Good insights into what is going on in the depths of the White House. No surprises, connected some dots. Worth reading.

As others have said, I could not stop reading. Shocking and disturbing, even if only 5% of what I read is true. Trump is an embarrassment to the American people and a danger to the world. I love to read to read and verify what I thought about our President

Whether this is a blessing or a curse, depends on your politics. Well written, pretty well structured,  it needs only more details of the  actual thinking of the principals, if any, to be complete.

The Republican Party. The party of Lincoln was "founded by anti-slavery activists, economic modernizers, ex whigs and ex Free Soilers in 1854" (Wikipedia). Nineteen of our US presidents have been republican.  Whether or not you admire them or support their policies, they are one of two of our political parties...our Grand Old Party.I don't usually review books. Here on Amazon I only occasionally review such things as ice makers and iPhone covers.So why do I feel compelled to enter the very treacherous waters of our current political insanity by posting here?  Because tonight our Grand Old Party sent out a ridiculous tweet that mocked up a cover of this book replete with "reviews" that disparaged (perhaps correctly...I don't know) the author.It isn't the mock-up itself that disturbs me as much as the fact one of our two leading political parties has stooped to trashing books. This is beneath us. Or it should be beneath us.I apologize that this isn't a book review. I'm only 1/4 the way through. But from what I can tell so far this is a gossipy, somewhat breezy, breathless impression of the early days of this administration. It could be called a "romp" if it weren't true. If true, it is both disheartening and a bit scary.  But it doesn't require an entire political party to make fun of it. Instead it requires an entire political party to fix it.(Amazon deleted my earlier review so I'm reposting it.  Not sure why they removed it but I might have, in error, linked to Wikipedia...so let's see if this one sticks!)
Great gift for GOP and trump voting relatives.Others will learn little but be amused.Goes best with a glass of Mueller Noir

I don't really know what to make of this book. One thing I will say, it is deliberately written so that Trump can't read it (not that he reads anything), even though he "has the best words." The vocabulary exceeded my own and I pride myself on my vocabulary. Also, there are references to people or events that I am not familiar with.Other than that, isn't this what we all thought was happening anyway? I guess it's good to get it documented and all in one place. Make this insanity more coherent, put a timeline and the players in order. There were several interesting interactions and the backbiting was more pervasive than I would have imagined. I'd say the people most surprised by it are the people in it. Apparently they never though this stuff would come out, even though so much of it came out as it happened.Three stars for being difficult to read and more hype than it probably deserved.

I try not to keep up with the news, but it's hard when the President keeps Twittering about things. I do use Twitter so when he says "don't read it", I'm going to read it! I have and will always hope the best for the President. He's done some good things and then there's the question marks.
