I was reluctant to buy it at all but now after reading the first couple of chapters, I'm thinking I should get a Hard copy as this will definitely be an historical record of the drama that has unfolded in this country. Michael Wolff made a brilliant move when he became and insider. He should get a Pulitzer prize for this book. Trump is the ultimate con artist and his job is done. He conned 65 million Americans. How sad. But in some ways it had to happen and this book helps to expose the rot that is throughout the American political landscape. Good luck with the future America.

Exposes the chaos of the Whitehouse and some of the many flaws of our current dimwitted dotard of a "president". I was going to wait and borrow this book from the library, but the orange moron's tantrum and efforts to stop it from being distributed made me decide to shell out the money and buy it today. It is worth it. If you have never been an Audible subscriber you can get a 14 day trial and purchase the audiobook for free with one of the 2 credits you receive.

As anyone who has kept up with politics this last year will agree, this is a complete s*** show. Happy to spend this money buying a book to prove to trump that in America you cannot (even as president) silence those you disagree with.
Frightening details throughout.  When are we going to impeach this Fascist president?  He is attacking our democracy.

We know what a bombastic person Trump is, but this book gives some insight into why he is the way he is.Neither he nor his entourage really expected him to win the presidency.  They were not prepared one bit for him to actually win, saying they would handle problems later, thinking that there would be no "later" as president, because he wouldn't win, right?  He was prepared, however, to claim the election was stolen (and he even made reference to it that in one of his evangelical-type speeches when he warned everyone that the election would be rigged---which it was).  Trump went from not wanting the job to believing that it was his destiny.I love that this book is written by the proverbial fly-on-the-wall because Trump gave the author full access to the West Wing and his myrmidons, apparently thinking that Wolff would find no dirt, just adulations.
Great book.  Worth it!  What a year.
Seems like a president not treated with respect.  He has done far more than other presidents have even tried.  A book of shame.

Yup ... we've heard much of it without reading the book ... but ... this read is a "head shaker"  At the risk of erring towards politics ... it's shocking that Trump is the "face of our Nation" and our representative to the rest of the world

Kind of a waste of money. Just watch the news and read the tweets, you'll figure it out for free.It would be more interesting if it had some notes on sources, but there is no way to determine 1st hand info, 2nd hand info, and third hand in a mirror info.

Fantastic Book - Great ReadMr. Wolff writes with a great style and the words flow off the paper very beautifully.  The story in itself is amazing. The story is a great insider tale of how one man's ego got the best of him and he was elected to an office he did not want. The ultimate con job on the American people.I especially enjoyed that Trump did not want this published.  He wanted to stop it from being printed. That in itself is reason to purchase the book.I am only 1/4 of the way through the book, but it is evident that America has someone in an office he was not prepared for, not deserving of and incapable of handling even the smallest of things with style and grace.

I did not read this book for the joy of it, nor did I expect it to reveal anything other than salacious gossip. I read Fire and Fury as because I strive to be an informed citizen. Love it or hate it, let's face it, the book itself has entered the national political discourse. It was apparently the final straw in the political ex-communication of Steve Bannon, and much ado is being made about it. In order to have an opinion about it myself, I had to read it. I encourage you to do the same. Keep a bottle of Bromo next to you and tuck in for a wild--if predictable--ride.
It just ended too soon.

Just makes you even more depressed that people voted for him. Confirms everything you figured you knew.  I couldn't get through it, had to read like 16 sci fi books just to clear my palate.  But worth buying because this is the kind of information that needs to be global and very available.
I like most everyone here, bought this because of the threat to the first amendment, not in MY America Mr, Trump.
I just downloaded it onto my Kindle. I havenâ€™t started reading it yet, but $15 is a wonderful price to protect the First Amendment and to make Mango Mussolini that much more peeved.

Amazing story.  So many things have happened in the last 100 days you tend to forget the dramatic details.  But wow...what a side.  I loved the personal approach as the front of the scenes have all been told.  I am so curious the reaction to this book...

The book reads like an excellent White House fanfic, which is great fun at first. But then you remember "this all actually happened, and continues to happen", and it's more than just a bit terrifying. If that wasn't enough, a sitting President of the United States actively attempted to silence the free speech of a citizen by suppressing the release of this book. That should be reason enough for anyone who considers themselves a true patriot to purchase and furiously read through it.Regardless of your political leanings, we now have a clear, referenced exposÃ© of how this attempt at "draining the swamp" ironically consisted of dumping 1000s of tons of toxic waste right back in, then letting it sit stagnant because the Command-in-Chief didn't even want to be there in the first place.

Factual? Maybe. Interesting?  Certainly.Even if you regard the lack of attribution and other journalistic basics as cause to be skeptical the book is very entertaining. All of the anecdotes are unlikely to be accurate but the overall themes and impressions are damning enough. A largely disinterested and uneducable president surrounded by three warring factions all out for themselves. Deep concern voiced by all factions concerning the lack of focus and gravity given to the most serious issues facing the country. Wether or not you choose to believe it on face value it was a quick and interesting read. If even 10% of it is true itâ€™s still the political read of the decade.

Most of the time I laughed because I'm exhausted at being infuriated at the madness occupying the White House. Highly recommend especially for those that voted for Trump and are tired of the losing battle of defending that horrific error in judgment

As I read this book, I kept thinking "When is he going to get to the shocking stuff we don't already know?"  I'm still waiting. It was mildly amusing, like watching a soap opera. The author's writing style struck me as extremely tabloid. For me, the best part was the claim that Sean Spider's daily mantra was "You can't make this sh*t up." The rest was just a rehash of the first nine months of the Trump presidency.

The writer uses convoluted sentences with unusual punctuation.  Most of the more interesting, scarier bits had already been revealed.  I bought the book mainly to show Sarah Sanders that the American people ARE interested in the chaos within the Trump administration.

While there are issues with this book that will be litigated in the courts of law and courts of public opinion, the intrinsic value, importance and bravery of this tome is not to be understated. May  the compassionate, educated masses  be inspired to take a collective breath and continue working steadily to return our nation to a progressive path. Spread the word and remain wary- He is changing offshore drilling laws and worse as we are distracted by images of this book being read to him. Stay woke.

This book is an entertaining, humorous and gossipy read. As all good gossip, it contains true and false stories. I know a lot of the book is true because it has been well documented, e.g. the often bizarre tweets, speeches, decisions and performances of Trump. I'm sure not all is true in the book. Overall, a fun book to read. Can't wait for the Trump story to unfold more, each day is more hilarious and bizarre.

As a concerned Democrat, I didn't want to read a book about more Trump revelations - already heard more than enough. But his attacks on it convinced me and my wife, and we're glad we read it. Riveting and frightful.

Although Wolff confirms most of what we already know, there is one glaring nugget thatâ€™s new.Trump and crew ran for president wanting to lose...losing was winning for Trump.Wolff provides good evidence of this:  (1) Trump LOANED the campaign about $10 million, when presidential campaigns usually cost about $130 million minimum;  (2) Trump never staffed up his campaign; (3) everyone on the campaign knew their goal was to lose, so Trump would become the hero to â€œcrookedâ€ù Hillary; and (4) Ailes, Oâ€™Reilly, Hannity, Trump, and Bannon were discussing Trump TV as a foe to Murdochâ€™s Fox News.The biggest conâ€”Trump conned his supporters into voting for him, when in reality, Trump had no intention of winning.  SAD!
Not much new. Already heard most of it.
If half of this is quarter true...Hooo boy.

I am an avid viewer of Rachel Maddow & the whole MSNBC team, therefore this book solidified the good journalism by them and their brilliant sources. A tip of the hat to Mr. Wolff and his courage to inform the public of this comedy of horrors in the White House.
This book is a must read for people that want the truth about what a mess this administration really is.

I had no intentions of buying this book. I didn't think it would really have amazing insight as to who Trump is. We already know who and what he is. But the simple fact that he's so hell bent on not having this book out to the public made it a no brainer for me. Well worth the money to make sure this book didn't get silenced!
This book only verified what I already believed to be how Trump is and acts away from the cameras etc.

This is a really petty book! Unfortunately,nothing in it is so incredibly unbelievable. Iâ€™ve read about 100 pages and in my opinion Wolff is sympathetic to Trump. Kinda in the same way our media is sympathetic to â€œAmericanâ€ù terrorists. I bought it because the President said not to. Thereâ€™s no way itâ€™s reverse psychology because the book is too long and filled with â€œbigâ€ù words.

The author quotes Steve Bannon as betting things will end one of three ways:1. 33.3% chance Trump will be impeached.2. 33.3% chance Trump will resign rather than be removed via the 25th Amendment.3. 33.3% chance Trump will lose the 2020 election.My money is on the 25th Amendment because of this book, which exposes the Cabinet's collective sin of propping up an increasingly unstable puppet.Author Michael Wolff will go down in history as the journalist who finally drove Trump over the edge.
Still difficult to wrap my brain around the fact that the author is writing about the leader of the free world. At times I found what was said breathtaking.
Michael Wolff shows what an unstable person Trump is, our  freedoms are lost  if Trump is able to stay in office.

Where do I begin? Wowsa, I dunno if I'm ready to comprehend Wolff's sobering, and undoubtedly horrifying, revelations regarding this joke of a presidency. However, knowledge is power and I will NEVER allow an illiterate, orange man dictate what I CAN and CANNOT read. I don't know whether or not he got the memo, but the U.S. is NOT North Korea. We may not be perfect, but I know for darn sure we will never let a dictator control our lives.Best $15 bucks ever spent! You can't silence our country, President Chump!

Confirms what the press has been reporting all along!  Thanks to the dedication of the press.  I think it is hilarious that the White House allowed the author to walk in and take a seat, for a year, after all of the complaining about the press, and have no clue!  !  Makes me feel so much safer with this inept group is running my country.  Common sense is lacking and all of DT tweet storms illustrate a man-child who never learned basic social skills in school.  If I have to hear him utter another put down, I think I will puke. I realize that it is a minor thing compared to the racism of this administrations, but his daily name calling only confirms DT doesn't understand the basics of being a contributing member to anything, much less the human race.. He doesn't respect others - because underneath his verbal outrageousness, is a man who is painfully aware at the core of his being, that he is unloved for good reason.  The sad part is he has used hate to elevate himself at the expense of our country.

This is the book that Donald Trump deserves. He has earned it with every single day of his presidency.And the author will become disgustingly rich with it. I don't mind contributing to that. It's for a good cause.Not because it's the truth. Just because these are the alternative facts that balance the scale.And nothing proves better the truth within them than Trump's attempt to block it.It's beautiful to watch the Streisand effect.
I hope Trump and his like go away forever.  This book tells a story, and it's not a pretty one.

I recommend this to all who want a handle on the strange things going on in our White House. It is much worse than I thought but I feel I know the players better and feel rather sorry at times for this man who is Ill-equipped to be President.

Simply put, thank goodness Mr Mueller will end this national tragedy before there is anything left to end.  Don't count on this destruction to end in the next decades, if ever.  However, the book is worth reading and I an glad nobody at the White House forgot to give him permission!

So I love this book but also kind of hate it.  It was fascinating but also kind of put me down because I know how messed up our politics are nowhere days.  I personally would not stand reading the book, so I got it on Audiobook  instead.
Wolffâ€™s book is well written and documented. It is entertaining but also frightening when you consider the notion that America may be led by an incompetent narcissist.
The book may have some factual inaccuracies but it portrays a president who is more akin to George III than Washington
Incredible. Not surprising. About time a journalists named quoted sources.

The book did have some grammar issues, and not everything is a direct quote. But enough is direct quotes, from named sources, to make me think that the general idea of the book is solid. Direct quotes can usually be verified by recordings or a the moment notes. I also thought that many of the more insightful comments are not ones you hear about on the news. Now I am not seeing signs of dementia in Trump's actions, which I am very familiar with, it seems more to me that he may be feeling his age, or even more, he is has the personality of the guy who is forever a teenager. Everyone knows a guy who is locked into his image of what he was when he was 18. He acts just like the dumb jock, which is not a crime or a 25th amendment thing.Reality is that the country elected a 70yr old guy trapped in his dumb jock view of himself. Until we make a law saying you have to act like an adult to be president, his day to day behavior is not enough to get rid of him
Trumo said he wanted to block its publication so I bought it to support free speech.  I find the passages and scenarios to be believable and likely.
Extremely insightful; all the pieces now fit the puzzle... brace yourself!!

Finished it in less than 24 hours. Nothing was suprising but seeing behind the curtain is astonishing. I finished this book feeling a lot more pity for Trump than I had in the past. The guy is just an insecure ball of putty. Able to be molded by anyone in proximity. Yikes. Bannon 2020? That is even more terrifying. The most heart wrenching take away I felt is that not once in any of these quotes and discussions was the will or the need of the American people ever mentioned (even as leverage) by anyone. #feelthebern

So which is it? Is the book totally false, or is Bannon a backstabber? Because you canâ€™t have both! If the book is false then Bannon didnâ€™t say all the juicy things that peppers this book, and if Bannon DID really say these things, then the book must not be so false after all!  With all his bluster and fight to dismiss this book, I had to buy it! The fact that he tried to stop publishing, and the fact that the publisher, in defiance, moved up the release date, made me buy this book immediately!  Iâ€™ve been reading it for a good part of the day and Iâ€™m about 1/3 of the way through. As the previous reviewer stated, you are surprised but not surprised, it just confirms what weâ€™ve all been thinking the whole time, but I canâ€™t put it down! Itâ€™s like a car wreck, you canâ€™t help but look! It confirms the mental instability and total chaos that are the hallmarks of this crazy time weâ€™re forced to live in. The book itself is engaging and entertaining, but then you remember that this is who is running our country, and becomes scary. This book causes both laughs and nausea at the same time. There are a lot of long, run on sentences, and the author does go off on mini-tangents sometimes making it hard to follow his main thought. But still, it deserves nothing less than 5 stars, to do my part to get it on and keep it on the best seller list! Got the Kindle version, because I didnâ€™t want to wait two weeks. But I plan on buying the hardcover, too.

I ordered as soon as the Orangutan in Chief started tweeting about it, originally said it would arrive in 2 days, then said it would be 4-6 weeks, but I got it a little over a week later and in one night I read the first three chapters.  I can't say that I know that every bit of the book is factual, but with the level of insight that Wolff has into the inner workings of the WH and the campaign, and a common sense look at everything that transpired, I have to say that Wolff seems to have written a legitimate representation of the events that occurred.  I recommend reading this book if you want to make it a NYT best seller and annoy the hell out of Donald or want some insight into the workings of our current executive branch, but definitely buy this book if you want the former
This book gives a good insiders view of whatâ€™s been happening in Washington.  The writing is so so but I could not put it down.

Even if some of this book is embellished, it's exactly what most people believe  happened. Honestly, I was not too shocked to read about Trump and co. Even just following normal news you can get the picture that these events are like what this book is about.I have no doubts that this book is a pretty accurate telling of this White house. It just makes me sick to think these people are in charge of our country. That they are making the decisions that greatly effect my life. I truly hope we can survive this horrible man and his people.
Interesting info on the split among the wh advisors. Obviously vetting the author's sources is key to what you can learn.

This was an interesting read.  Every detail doesn't have to be true because the overwhelming amount of information in the book, and the lack of denials from those quoted, is convincing.  It tells the story of a White House with horrendous infighting and not much competency.

I bought this because trump tried to censor the book. I read it in one sitting. It confirms every single impression that I have of this Ronald McDonald presidency. And the complicit jaundiced cynical Republicans that prop him up because "he'll sign anything we put in front of him". History will be harsh on these shameless traitors to our democracy.
The book was interesting, confirmed many news stories butWas really nothing more than what we have already known. Worth reading

Congrats to Wolff who struck gold on a book of historical significance thanks to a cease and desist order from the POTUS.  Every American should read this book and judge for themselves what hidden truths that warranted such an attack on the 1st Amendment.
Seemed rush to publication. But reveals Trump and Jarvanka for their bad management.
I bought this book just to make #45 mad.  Can't wait to read it.
I just like the book he was so honest about what he WROTE TRUMP IS A JERK

If only a FRACTION of the stuff in this book is true, it's very depressing and also infuriating.  As someone who despises Trump, this book only served to make me more angry.  What incompetence, what buffoonery, what an unfit, uninformed nightmare of a man and president.

Self-serving, despicable people are in charge of our government! This was a tedious but very worthwhile read. The author took most of the major events through August and described  what each of the three competing White House factions were doing. Horrifying to think Jared and Ivanka, with no experience other than schmoozing and self promotion have such a big role in our countryâ€™s future. The nepotism law should be strengthened!  Trumpâ€™s vulgarity, stupidity and lack of work ethic are appalling.  He has made our country the laughingstock of the world- far from the greatness he promised. I canâ€™t believe the Republicans are such lemmings.

I bought the kindle version and have only read up to the initial inaugural address and the comments about Spicer turning into a laughingstock.  Goes beyond expectation and shows the administration as even worse than what we have all seen in the news.Our â€œdear leaderâ€ù has done real genuine harm to our country and democracy as a whole.  Iâ€™m sad and angry it had gotten to this point and can commiserate with another reviewer thinking we had to do better for our kids.

1) I'm not even American. I can't believe I was just intrigued enough about American politics to have purchased this book at 09:01 on the day of release. But we are living in a whole new world, there is a lot of hype about this book, and this guy might start a nuclear war that would kill us all. 2) I have literally never been more excited to be going on a long-haul 24 hour flight now that I have this book in my kindle. It might make me sick, but at least I'll be entertained.

I was going to review michael Wolffâ€™s new book, Fire and Fury, rather than the political agenda that caused it to be written, but the reasons behind the writing makes it the great book it is. Iâ€™m a long time political junkie and read books about every election as my â€œhabitâ€ù requires. Wolffâ€™s book is the most explosive since the Halperin and Heilemann book Game Change on the 2008 election.Whether you have been depressed since November 2016 or been elated at the election of Donald Trump, you owe it to yourself to read Wolffâ€™s book.

This book is well written and compelling, the author believable and elequent, and it reads like the horror novel I wish it were. Reading this will give me nightmares, but when I wake up, the nightmares will still be reality. Trump is actually even worse than I believed possible, and I have an excellent imagination. These are dark times indeed. Read this, and know the enemy that we must fight against!

Great insight into the Trump Administration and at the same time very entertaining. I would recommend this book to anyone that cares for and loves America. Wolffâ€™s narrative is compelling and a page turner.
I went into a binge listening mode when this audio book arrived. Highly recommended.

I think most of us always suspected that Trumpâ€™s White House was a pretty crazy place, but this book basically provides (mostly anecdotal) proof of that. Full of fascinating stories, if nothing else â€œFire and Furyâ€ù is just a damn good read - whether you choose to believe everything or not. And weirdly, I found that knowing more about the â€œbehind the scenes Trumpâ€ù made him more human somehow, more genuine â€” yes, hate to say it, more sympathetic! Canâ€™t believe that this die-hard liberal Democrat is saying that...
Great read and I love reading the failed presidency of failing Donald chump

I enjoyed the pace and the insights. Hard to know for sure what is real and what is conjecture but based on what we've seen from this administration day in and day out none of it sounds like a stretch. The book was clearly rushed (typos abound) and needed some time and editing but I accepted that early on. This is a gossip rag merged with a long form New Yorker article. Very entertaining.

First I chose 5 stars because according to the book this would absolutely make the President livid.  This book was shocking and eye opening, it also makes me worried for future dealings with other countries.  It was an incredibly fast read for me, mainly because of the shock and disbelief on how the administration is run.  Getting my popcorn ready for the movie and musical.

300 pages with 50 of content. That being said, if itâ€™s even 1/2 true, this country has sold out to special interests, highest bidders and lowest denominators of common sense.  We seem to be an empire ending... and not ending well.
Based on first hand insights, the author paints a picture of chaos, infighting, and vindictive media leaks from the White House and a President totally consumed with his image.
It is hard to determine what is true from Fake.  It is sad that our country has come to this daily onslaught of drama from our government.
The subject of this book needs ALL the negativity we can provide to awaken his supporters to his selfish evil!

While I doubt that every aspect of every story in this book is literally true, I believe it does paint an accurate overall picture of the Trump White House. Just as dabs of paint on a canvas do not literally represent Mona Lisa or a landscape, the paintings likely give you an accurate representation of the subject. Given what we know about Trump from a variety of sources, this book doesn't come across as the equivalent of modern art.

I didn't want to buy this book. But, you know, I just sort of had to and I was pleasantly surprised. The book is written with language and style indicating the author is a sober grownup and his target audience are grownups as well, not the hungry readers of snarky blogs. Make no mistake, it is eviscerating the Trump image even further but it's doing it in a sublimely cool, rational and, presumably quote-driven way which is hard to put down and is likely to woo some fence sitters. It's a fascinating look at all the players behind the scenes and a bit of pertinent backstory on who they are and what they stand to gain or lose in this Coney Island Side SHow.  Trump orcs themselves won't read it because it's not written like the grade school invective-laden screed that gets their sweat flowing one way or the other.

I'm only through the first chapter, but I'm dismayed at how many people surrounding Trump all thought it was a joke and that he should never be President, nor given any responsible political voice whatsoever. It's like everybody around Trump just stood around watching a house burn but didn't do anything because they could sell tickets to the fire (Bannon, Flynn, Manafort, or make their names as having witnessed the fire (Conway, Pence, Trump's kids), or literally just wanted to watch the government break for their own benefit (Ailes, McConnell, Murdoch, Ryan). I'll update this as I plow through the Kindle version. It's a heartbreaking read for a patriotic American.

Anyone who has been following politics the past two years is not going to be surprised by what is written in â€œFire and Furyâ€ù. Confirms what many had thought, Trump had no intention of getting elected. He was building his brand, increasing his base for the new Trump network, without costing him a dime. It is interesting how Michael Wolff gained access to Trump Tower and then the West Wing, being the fly on the wall many of us at one time or another wished we could be. While this book has been pushed to the press because of tRumps threats against The First Amendment, it has a some style and editing issues. Those do not get in the way of what is a well written chronicle of events. We are just days into 2018. Already, itâ€™s heating up. Meanwhile, in Washington, tRump stamps his feet, waves his hands and sputters about stopping the publication. Remember tRumpâ€™s use of the slight of hand. Yells and screams about one thing to distract us from something else. Sure enough, while we have our heads buried in our iPads, Kindles and books, the deceiver in chief is proposing opening up all our coast lines to oil and gas exploration. Gee, no conflict of interest there. Sessions interfering with states rights and more.Read, evaluate for yourself, keep aware and engaged. Vote in November 2018.

Fire and Fury by Michel Wolff is not the best-written book, nor does Wolff reveal anything that we can't see by observing Trump in any media, whether deemed real or fake news.My first impressions were that Wolff's prose read like an OK true-crime book.  Then I thought, oh wait, it sort of is just that. I am giving the book at least one more star than I would normally because I do not appreciate any feds, especially a high profile and powerful one, issuing a Cease and Desist threat against an author and publisher.  Hello????? Isn't  (or wasn't) the Tea Party line all about the'Federal Government butting out of States' Rights and The  Individual's rights? Like the right to bear arms? and, oh I don't know, like The Freedom of Speech?

Obviously hastily written, and who knows what is true, half true, or false, it paints a mesmerizing and horrific picture of the Trump Whitehouse. If even 5% of this book is true, our country is in grave danger.

Parts of the book were interesting but for the most part if you had been paying attention to what had been going on for the last few years and done any kind of research then the book was pretty boring. I kept saying to myself maybe the next chapter but that just didn't happen

Half way through, but total proof of what we all know to be a reality show of a presidency.  I believe that Trump is stupid enough and narcissistic enough to have let Wolff have free reign of the West Wing.  It's like a bad dream.

Reading the Kindle version.  Anything worth trying to legally block is worth reading and knowing. It is sad that there are no surprises. Also to know that the sinking feeling we had in our stomach for the past year was justified.

Such a well-crafted and highly readable (and highly entertaining) tragi-comedy.  It really is such a good book - it amasses the chaotic flood of information we have heard over the past year into a fun and educational narrative.  We already knew or suspected these things about Trump but have all been so exhausted trying to piece together so much insanity into some coherent story, something we can grab onto and understand better how we ever got to this point in U.S. history.  This book brilliantly crafts all of the flotsam and jetsam of the insanity of Trump and his White House into a narrative that just lets us breathe and be entertained for a while, just for a brief moment before we go back to being horrified and exhausted by Trump's next shenanigans.  I love Wolff's quote on Trump lambasting his book:â€œMy credibility is being questioned by a man who has less credibility than perhaps anyone who has ever walked on earth at this point,â€ù he said.
What a relevant piece of work. Lots of insight.

A big disappointment. Much more hype about the book, then it actually contained. We know already that Trump is a moron. The book didn't tell us much more. It "hinted" a lot, but didn't follow through.

This book is confirmation of what most of us thought of this sham of a president and his staff. Love Wolff's openness to put this out for the world to see. Let's hope the next chapter involves impeachment and removal of the subjects in this book.

I wasn't going to buy this book, but was able to read several chapters from the Wikileaks link before it was disabled. Now I have to finish it because it really only confirms what is blazingly obvious - there's a hella-crazy amusement park ride going on in the White House.  From only 3 chapters, I can see why Trump wanted to try and stop the publication of this book. If it were really based on nothing but lies, he wouldn't care. But, everything I've read so far just confirms that we already knew this guy and his pack of nutcases are an embarrassment. It's almost hard to believe they're all not really just the cast of characters from a Mel Brooks movie. This book deserves to be the best seller that it already is. The real sad thing is that there are still a large number of his voters/fans who will love him even more after reading this book.

Fire and Fury does not disappoint. I was skeptical; I thought this might be just a tabloid romp. It is not-it is well written, well sourced, and just plain fascinating. At times it is funny, and at times very sad. I came away from the read, with the sense that almost all of the contents were genuine, and a feeling of dread for our nation; we have elected a man to our highest office, who is small, empty and full of spitting rage.

I really wanted to like this book, but it is SO hard to read.  Poorly written, and was not edited appropriately.  Words are missing, misspelled, and poor sentence construction is rampant.  In addition, the author rambles on. adding information that could have been left out.  He often gets off track on the subject, which makes it difficult to follow the subject matter.I ended up skipping through the book to chapters I really wanted to see, and left it at that.  All in all, I probably read 2 chapters in their entirety.  In my opinion, they rushed to get it published. regardless of content and errors.

There are some very interesting in-sites into the Trump presidency and into Trump in particular.  One should, however, take a cautionary note when reading the book.  Author Wolff appears to embellish his work not in favor of the president or his disciples.  One has to question how he gained and ...maintained access to the White House and was not questioned about his purpose for being there.  It is hard to imagine such a thing considering the security involved with protecting the president and the presidency.

A compelling read...if you already hate Bannon and Trump, this book will give you more reasons to do so.. Wolff must have interviewed dozens and dozens of people and the writing is good enough so that you have to believe he is credible. This book is like being a fly on the wall of the Trump White House. Total dysfunction and incompetence on display on a daily basis. Book is well written and should be read by all voters. The author of this book needs to learn how to write. It is loaded with run-on sentences, bad grammar and difficult to read context. It's written like we are all Washington, D.C. insiders that have been privy to the inner workings of the Trump Whitehouse. There are juicy tidbits throughout but it's so hard to read, I can't make it through a whole chapter at a time. It will be on the best seller list only because of the promised context.Having said that, we are told over and over that he doesn't understand politics, his eyes glaze over during security briefings, he just wants to be liked, his daughter and son-in-law are acting more like New York Democrats than Washington Republicans, he airs his feelings about everyone in D.C. to his friends on the phone every night, he talks too much and never listens to anyone else, he can't handle any type of criticism, he has no idea what he is doing, he never expected to win and was just running to push the Trump brand name, and well, you get the drift. If ten percent of the content is true, the swamp will not be drained anytime soon. As citizens of our nation, we need to stay focused on what is going on in politics, question our elected officials whenever we know something is not right and be more involved. I have actually started writing letters to the elected officials in my state. It will be interesting to see what the responses are, if any.One more thing, when I saw this book being talked about on the news, I understood it to be a Steve Bannon and Michael Wolff co-creation, at least that was the way it was being presented. Steve Bannon is just one of the many characters being talked about and not a co-author. Believe me, Steve Bannon is one small piece of a very strange, out-of-control hot mess, according to Michael Wolff. I am a third of the way through the book and I don't get the fire and fury thing. Who has fire? Who has fury? Everyone? No one? I am sorry I bought this thing because the end result is, it's hard to read and poorly written, I can't make it through a whole chapter in one sitting, I would have to subscribe and read daily all of the major east coast newspapers (to be able to get all the "insider" references and hints), and the subject matter is repetitive, sometimes scary and sometimes boring. Buy it if you must but I suggest you wait for your local library to get it and check it out from them.

I mainly purchased this book because our Dictator in Chief tried to suppress our first amendment rights by banning it.  Then, I started reading it.  It's far from fantasy and does a great job of painting a picture of Trump and the people around him.  The only reason I gave this book 4 stars instead of 5 was the constant fractured sentences, paragraph long sentences, and the unnecessary over use of AP English words that most will not comprehend.  I fear the extreme flowery language will turn off the very reader that NEEDS to read this book.  You know who you are: The Trump Base.

Wolff provides insight and clarity into the mental illness of this president. "Fire and Fury" helps a now-weary American populace better understand what motivates Trump's tweets and diatribes. There's a certain solace that comes from the book, to finally have some understanding as we watch the train-wreck that is the Trump presidency.

A look at the people surrounding Presidential candidate Donald J. Trump after he inexplicably wins the election, what they think of the man that they hitched their careers and reputations to., and the infighting between the factions in the White House: Bannonites, Jarvankas, and the few sane and sober professionals struggling to keep the place from imploding.Thanks to provocative excerpts shared on cable news programs and a poorly thought out Cease and Desist letter from Trump's attorney to both the networks as well as to the author and publisher, the book's publication date was moved up from Tuesday to Friday and it shot to the pre-order bestseller list.QUOTE:  "[Trump] was what he was.  Twinkle in his eye, larceny in his soul."The author appears to have had access primarily to Stephen Bannon, although based on other direct quotes used, others in the White House were either interviewed or overheard.  Yes, this is an anti-Trump book, but it also spreads the responsibilities for where this country currently is perched to those who either support or enable Trump as well as scrutinizing the media for their coverage.  But it is also clear that much of that is due to Trump's own actions, reactions, and verbal diarrhea on both Twitter and to reporters he considers supporters and friends.QUOTE:  "Here was another peculiar Trump attribute: an inability to see his actions the way most others saw them."Much of what is in the book rings true, based on past public interviews and on-air commentary by those who either were or still are advocates.  I am not saying that it is 100% accurate.  Even I can see the author's bias.  I do think it deserves a critical read by both pro- and anti-Trump readers.  Big warning, at least for the Kindle version, there are quite a few typos.  Some are humorous, such as "pubic" instead of "public".  However, as a former proofreader and still active grammar cop, I found it annoying.  4 out of 5.

The federal American government consists of three tiers: Congress, the Supreme Court, and the White House administration.  The three function like a tripod upholding the "united" part of the United States. If one fails  the other two might not be able to maintain the federation of the States, rendering the Constitution irrelevant. The 50 States will become an association of States, falling back on their respective State constitutions, thereby protecting their pertinent ethnic and historical practices free of federal meddling. It is the decline and fall of the American Empire....

Like several million people, I don't like the idea of some rich, spoiled, crooked politician saying what I should not be allowed to read.  But, actually, even before the effort to suppress came out, I had heard enough to place this book on my must read list.Like most people who have been following the news, I knew that the infighting in the Trump White House was vicious enough to make the Night of the Long Knives look like the meeting of a mutual admiration society.  This was my chance to get some idea of who was allied with who against whom, and that is just what I found.Have you ever heard someone say, "I'd like to be a fly on the wall in that room."?  It turns out that there was, for a while, a literal fly on the White House wall, and this is the book he wrote.You have probably heard quite a few of the outrageous quotes from the book, but this is not just a book of sound bites.  It is a serious, in depth description of who did what to who in which room with what.  Overriding it all is the attempt by three gangs of incompetent bunglers to try to hold a spoiled, lazy, child-man's attention on the business of running a government for even a half hour at a time.The book is engrossing and well written.  Once I started reading, I could not put it down.  I have to admit that everything I read was filtered through my loathing for Donald Trump and my disgust for the nest of sycophants with which he has surrounded himself.  This book has done nothing to change my mind.

This review is for the Kindle edition and does contain some spoilers, but unless youâ€™ve been living under a rock youâ€™ve probably heard of most of them already. Because the Trump White House lawyers tried to block the publication of this book it immediately became a best seller and was rushed to publication. The author appropriately expressed his gratitude for the publicity. Because of the rush, there are some minor editing errors and typos but they donâ€™t really detract from the overall quality of the book. The main premise is that Candidate Trump ran primarily to increase the value of his â€œbrandâ€ù and hoped to capitalize off of losing to â€œCrooked Hillary.â€ù When he won, his team was ill-prepared and in-fighting between warring factions inside the White House resulted in chaos. Anyone reading the news knew about the chaos, of course, but reading the details was interesting. The interplay between the various personalities is discussed as well as their implications to the investigations.  While I do think it should be read with more than a â€œgrain of salt,â€ù I enjoyed it and have recommended it to my husband, numerous family members and friends.

First, my declarations: I am an Independent who tends toward conservative views. I am not a Trump supporter. In fact, I am so regularly embarrassed by him that I sometimes forgo watching the news.I thought I would enjoy the book, but this author's writing style is so off-putting and exasperating that I was unable to finish reading it. He is so clearly full of himself and seems to be spending so much time trying to show how intelligent he is that he forgets that the goal of writing a book like this is to communicate information to people, not tout your own inflated sense of intellect. I have a graduate degree and I found myself using a dictionary to look up the obscure words he was using.  They didn't add to his message; they detracted from it.To make matters worse, the editing was also really, really bad. If I recall correctly, there was one "paragraph" that was about 7-10 lines long that was really one giant run on sentence. The inflated writing style, coupled with the bad editing, made this a laborious, unenjoyable read. I had such high hopes...
Although at first it seemed a rehash of much we already know or suspect  the insight grew especially with respect to Bannon and WH inside power struggles.

Reading this book is like watching a giant pileup on a highway...  One by one cars get smashed into each other, everything is in flames but you can't look away.  Then a school bus... Then an airplane...  Then a giant cruise ship but you don't even think, "it's a highway, how the ship got here, it's nuts!", you just can't look away.I wish the author would make it easier to understand, which stories were directly witnessed by the people who the author interviewed himself and which ones are the ones they heard have happened.  On the other hand, I don't hear many people who talked to the author saying "I never told him that" so we just have to draw our own conclusions.  To me this book just provided more details that we already new about and what was in the news for several years now, so I have very little reason to doubt it most of it.Interesting read but quite tiring.
This book is extremely well written. It's a very unpleasant and disturbing story. A True story. Thank you Michael Wolf. We need to be informed about what is happening in the White House.
Excellent fly-on-the-wall view of the messy, chaotic fighting inside the White House to try and turn a sloganeering boor into an American president with policies.

Although there are glaring inaccuracies (incorrect positions for example) and sloppy editing, the depiction of a fractured WH in the early days seems to reflect what has previously been reported. Probably too alarming regarding POTUS' mental capacity, but not far off on qualified for the job. Glad I read it.

Well written and full of detail, this is more documentary than tell-all. Michael Wolff's attention to detail, as well as in-depth analysis of the personalities surrounding President Trump, make for an engrossing read.
Excellent! Trump exposed is frightening, like a slow motion train wreck.

I leave this book not exactly sure where the truth lies in some of these stories but convinced that the author would not have presented the evidence as he did, and would not have arrived at his conclusions about the Trump White House administration and Trump on the prowl, if he had not been riding close enough to the truth throughout.  (The author Wolff explains that some stories contradict others and that phenomenon in itself is symptomatic of the Trump White House and it's infidelity to the truth and propensity for delusion; the author has done the best he can with the stories presented to him.)The other insight I have to offer is this:  As I noted, the authorâ€™s offerings have an overall ring of truth to them.  Any reader who has been paying attention will have â€˜ah-ha!â€™ moments that say â€˜I suspected this is what was going on while Trump has played at being leader of the free world.â€™  Any American capable of seeing through the glass clearly knows intuitively and objectively that Donald Trump is not cut out for the work at hand.I consider the author Wolf a patriot who could not have made all of this up; the truth has to matter more than Donald Trump's show.  For corroboration of truths we look to Trump as we have known him.  His latest antic with the derisive Tweet taunting North Koreaâ€™s leader plus thousands of more samplings of his behavior, available and known to us, offer proof that Wolf portrays Trump as he is.  We are in danger plenty.  Surely America will no longer be first.  Let us pray our democratic republic survives, that democracy survives as a force for good in the world, and the world is not drawn into a war because Trump was allowed to remain in the lead in spite of what we know about him.  He should not have presidential powers.  We must get him out of office before it is too late.

I don't know how much of the book is factual vs supposition and assumption but was saddened at how it illustrates the shambles we seem to find ourselves in.  I think we have lost our way - we aren't seeing the resurgence of America the great, but rather America the great joke. Regardless of whether the book is based on facts or is just one long recap of the worst of this presidency with some theatrical narrative thrown in for effect, it gives form and shape to the widening divide in our country - and hints at a brewing chaos and instability that leaves us vulnerable. No matter your political affiliation, as a country the call to unite should be loud and clear before we implode in a shower of media flamed division. No matter who you are, read it and then reach out to someone from the other side and vow to find a way to stand together on important issues before it's too late. Don't get so caught up in watching the crash that you neglect to put the brakes on and prevent it.

This book is a REAL behind-the scenes look at Whitehouse filled with inept, government-inexperienced people, each anxious to grab his/her slice of the pie and their "15-inutes of fame." The promise to "drain the swamp" became a race to erase all vestiges of not only the previous administration, button  government protocol and detente that had been in place for, in many case, decades. The author offers a fly-on-the-wall look at reactions by actual players in the game of "Who can wield the most power." Bannon vs."Jarvanka" and Priebus struggling to attach some sort of decorum to a cauldron of infighting, are but two examples of the peek behind the Oval Office curtain. This book is a must-read tat will be referred to for generations.

I neither like nor respect Trump. (I won't even dignify him by using his courtesy title.) That stated, I can't recommend this screed for a number of reasons.Although this is not my main criticism, the sheer number of editing errors (such as "was was") speak to how hastily this book was released, and as such, the book reads less like a compilation of issues and observations that lead to conclusions than a completely malicious list of grievances against Trump that the author already harbored and for which he was looking for justification(s).The author clearly relies heavily on discussions with/observations of Steve Bannon, probably the most loathsome player in the Trump drama, and portrays Bannon as the fulcrum behind a significant number of Trump's actions. And while I am not suggesting that the author depict Bannon as being a blameless, charming, nice and/or truthful human being if he isn't, (again, according to the author's subjective view,) the author disparages Bannon in such a way as to undermine whatever credibility Bannon might have within the book. And since Bannon is so central to the story, if he's undermined, so is the story Wolff tells.This book reads less like a contribution to the developing Trump presidency canon than a salacious, mean-spirited and pointless jeremiad meant to cash in on Trump's ever-dwindling popularity and the ever-mounting questions concerning Trump's sanity, thanks, in part, to this book. This is a nasty book in the style of Rona Barrett, without Wolff having Barrett's grace to admit that he's just a gossip monger and, in his case, one with dubious sources, a taste for invective, and a "literary" track record that I should have considered at greater length and more seriously before wasting money on this piece of trash.There are other, far better books that have been written about Trump. They are far more cohesive and foretold what is now happening with Trump. Likewise, 'How Democracies Die' portends to be more helpful in explaining what is happening in an administration that may well represent a significant decline in the ability of this democracy to survive.This book made me want to take a good, scalding shower after reading it - exactly the same way I'd feel if I ever got to shake Trump's hand, which I would decline to do.

What makes Fire and Fury a must read isn't in the writing, it's the fact that it captures the a moment in our history. It doesn't matter what is true and what is exaggerated. What matters is that the office of the President continues to capture our attention at unprecedented levels. This book doesn't do anything particularly well or break any ground but it is thoroughly entertaining because it paints a picture of the inner workings of American politics that we rarely see. It's so rare to have an administration that functions this way and this book is both a description and a reflection of that (dys)function. Truthfully, it is a pretty run of the mill political book. Readers will have to determine the credibility of the author and your own political views, as per usual in America, will determine whether or not you enjoy reading things you may or may not want to believe. If you're a Trump supporter, this book probably won't change your opinion. If you dislike the direction America has taken under Trump, you will likely revel in this depiction of our Commander in Chief as a complete and utter man-baby. The bottom line is that everybody is talking about this book. If that's not a good reason to read a book, then don't bother. In a month, nobody will care. There aren't any revelations in this book you won't see on the cable news shows discussing the book. Still, it's an incredibly fun read if you're into current events and politics.

This would be a hilarious depiction of the Trump White House if it weren't so scary and sad. But okay, I did laugh a lot. If you have been following the chaos of Trump, Bannon & Co., there's nothing new here, but the book does go deeper on all the nutty stories and outbursts of the last two years. I found the insights worth reading as they gave me a better understanding of what's happening in the West Wing. The buffoonery somehow made me feel a little easier - as in our country is more being taken apart by incompetence than pure evil, though certainly there's some of that. This is a good page-turner, but man there are a lot of typos and errors in it. They should have spent the weekend proofreading the thing instead of releasing it early.

This is written as though it is fiction, and I think it should be treated with the same amount of skepticism normally accorded something that claims to be based on reality (or at least, do not suspend disbelief per usual). Wolff said he was interested in the characters, and that's what's here: a politically themed, reality-tv-show-style soap opera in narrative form. Don't expect a detailed breakdown of the intricacies of political negotiations or analysis of how these peculiar personalities might impact that process. Do expect a lot of repetition and misspellings, as I'm pretty sure this was rushed to print before an editor saw it. Heck, even before a second draft. And expect, too, what might be gossip? Depending on if the narrator is reliable? The truth is... somewhere out there.

Stop Calling Them "Immigrants": They are PHIs (Persons Here Illegally) - The Solution Begins with Using the Right TermI hesitate to give reviews of fewer than three stars but I will "grade on a curve" when it comes to bestsellers. People have a right to know what they're getting.If we filter out all the "1-star"  and "5-star" ratings, by Trump supporters and bashers, respectively, let's get down to what this book really is: a squandered opportunity by a person lucky enough to have been blessed with virtually unlimited White House access. Michael Wolff had a golden opportunity to write the first important historical account of the Trump presidency, and he threw it all away for the cheap thrills of empty gossip and innuendo."It might be true" is not good enough.Worse yet, Wolff's perspective is that of one of the countless people who have no clue why Trump won.  (Hint: if you read my book, Stop Calling Them Immigrants [see link above], you find out why in the Conclusion: IMMIGRATION is the reason.)Wolff jumps of the theme of chaos and runs with it throughout the book. Not that anyone would argue with straight face that the Trump White House is eminently smooth and harmonious, but there are so many more powerful themes that epitomize this presidency - not least of which a national assailing of the major party establishmentarian duopoly - that "chaos" barely cracks the top 10.So if this book was so bad in my view, why not give it just one star? Because it is well written. Wolff is a talented wordsmith. Too bad he didn't put that talent to the more noble pursuit of presidential history. Thucydides he ain't....

Let's not beat around the bush: Not everything in this book is accurate. Some of the grammar and typos are unreal for an editor not to catch (e.g. "the presidential primary was still competitive in the winter of 2016" or "they had another think coming"). Some of the facts are just wrong.And yet this is exactly the kind of post-truth coverage that is deserving of this post-truth administration. Had a reputable journalist published this work with facts triple-checked and quotes reproduced verbatim, Trump would have attacked the media, called it fake news, and moved on. But Wolff's gripping pages, not letting mere objective truth stand in the way, truly get to the heart of the disaster that is this terrible man and the disease he has brought to this country. That is why this tale cannot be dismissed. Trump has scored his victories against facts. But when it comes to tests of character, he has always failed.
Great to have

Readers who follow politics and/or its increasingly symbiotic relationship to the media won't find much new information about President Trump in "Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House." This lack is more than compensated by Wolff's detailed portraits of not only the power players comprising Trump's inner circle but also those who want in, and those who prefer to run their own little fiefdoms that circumvent the president. The handful of Cabinet members, high level staff and advisors Wolff depicts as qualified for their roles are routinely stymied or ignored. Another handful are very shady, a few even criminal.  Most staffers are depicted as decent people increasingly occupied with preventing or calming Trump's explosive tirades and trying to mitigate damage from the many (most already well-publicized) episodes Wolff presents. He must, of course, mention the episodes in order to make his real contribution--showing the collateral damage to staff at all levels, a more important story than reports of a Department Secretary or similarly high-placed official insulting Trump sotto voce. The surprise is that so few insults have been leaked; the White House is a sieve according to Wolff. I expected to be disturbed by the details this book adds to my picture of our government deeply imperiled, and I am. What I didn't see coming was Wolff's characterization of the press in general as self-loathing. Self-loathing in general?

I bought both this Kindle version and the Audible.com version. Both were set to publish on January 9th, but the furor over its release forced the publisher to release both versions early. So early, in fact, that some 150 people were able to post reviews before I even could listen to the audio or read the Kindle.Indeed, as a speed reader myself, I am amazed that so many folks could read it so quickly.Here is my take, only about half way through:BUY THIS BOOK TODAY IN KINDLE AND AUDIBLE FORMAT. WHY? It is probably the most honest, real depiction, recorded as it actually is happening. Readers of my reviews will know that i am no Trump fan, but books reporting favorably on him have received impartial treatment by me. Same can be said of reviews I posted regarding HRC - when the book was bad, or dull, I reported such observations. When it came across as heartfelt and authentic, I praised it.BLUSH FACTOR Bearing in mind that this is a book reflecting the language spoken by people whom most of us know are familiar with so-called locker room language (I abhor such terms but i am trying to consolidate here), use your own judgment as to reading this to your youngster or to your elderly grandmother. Myself, i probably would read most of it aloud, but i would leave out the f-words, in a show of respect to my elders and as a matter of leadership to the youth.Fire and Fury is such an interesting, insightful book not laced with prejudicial statements by the author either in favor the Trump or to deride the man whom I believe to be the greatest barker of my generation.A book that seems to actually support much of the worth of this book is "Let Trump be Trump" by Corey R. Lewandowski and David N. Bossie (which is, arguably, the most prejudicial publication ever produced in favor of Trump) . Especially telling was their discussion of the man most responsible for Lewandowski becoming Trump's campaign manager - Roger Stone [refer to page 49 of Let Trump Be Trump].Let this excerpt from 4% into the book whet your appetite:â€œWhereâ€™s Donald on this?â€ù asked Ailes, now with the clear implication that Bannon was far out ahead of his benefactor.â€œHeâ€™s totally on board.â€ùâ€œFocused?â€ùâ€œHe buys it.â€ùâ€œI wouldnâ€™t give Donald too much to think about,â€ù said an amused Ailes.Bannon snorted. â€œToo much, too littleâ€”doesnâ€™t necessarily change things.â€ùâ€œWhat has he gotten himself into with the Russians?â€ù pressed Ailes.â€œMostly,â€ù said Bannon, â€œhe went to Russia and he thought he was going to meet Putin. But Putin couldnâ€™t give a sxxt about him. So heâ€™s kept trying.â€ùâ€œHeâ€™s Donald,â€ù said Ailes.â€œItâ€™s a magnificent thing,â€ù said Bannon, who had taken to regarding Trump as something like a natural wonder, beyond explanation.Again, as though setting the issue of Trump asideâ€”merely a large and peculiar presence to both be thankful for and to have to abideâ€”Bannon, in the role he had conceived for himself, the auteur of the Trump presidency, charged forward:â€œChinaâ€™s everything. Nothing else matters. We donâ€™t get China right, we donâ€™t get anything right. This whole thing is very simple. China is where Nazi Germany was in 1929 to 1930. The Chinese, like the Germans, are the most rational people in the world, until theyâ€™re not. And theyâ€™re gonna flip like Germany in the thirties. Youâ€™re going to have a hypernationalist state, and once that happens you canâ€™t put the genie back in the bottle.â€ùâ€œDonald might not be Nixon in China,â€ù said Ailes, deadpan, suggesting that for Trump to seize the mantle of global transformation might strain credulity.Bannon smiled. â€œBannon in China,â€ù he said, with both remarkable grandiosity and wry self-deprecation.â€œHowâ€™s the kid?â€ù asked Ailes, referring to Trumpâ€™s son-in-law and paramount political adviser, thirty-six-year-old Jared Kushner.â€œHeâ€™s my partner,â€ù said Bannon, his tone suggesting that if he felt otherwise, he was nevertheless determined to stay on message.â€œReally?â€ù said a dubious Ailes.â€œHeâ€™s on the team.â€ùâ€œHeâ€™s had lot of lunches with Rupert.â€ùâ€œIn fact,â€ù said Bannon, â€œI could use your help here.â€ù Bannon then spent several minutes trying to recruit Ailes to help kneecap Murdoch. Ailes, since his ouster from Fox, had become only more bitter towards Murdoch. Now Murdoch was frequently jawboning the president-elect and encouraging him toward establishment moderationâ€”all a strange inversion in the ever-stranger currents of American conservatism. Bannon wanted Ailes to suggest to Trump, a man whose many neuroses included a horror of forgetfulness or senility, that Murdoch might be losing it.â€œIâ€™ll call him,â€ù said Ailes. â€œBut Trump would jump through hoops for Rupert.Rupert. Like for Putin. Sucks up and sxxxs down. I just worry about whoâ€™s jerking whose chain.â€ùThe older right-wing media wizard and the younger (though not by all that much) continued on to the other guestsâ€™ satisfaction until twelve-thirty, the older trying to see through to the new national enigma that was Trumpâ€”although Ailes would say that in fact Trumpâ€™s behavior was ever predictableâ€”and the younger seemingly determined not to spoil his own moment of destiny.â€œDonald Trump has got it. Heâ€™s Trump, but heâ€™s got it. Trump is Trump,â€ù affirmed Bannon. â€œYeah, heâ€™s Trump,â€ù said Ailes, with something like incredulity.Wolff, Michael. Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House (pp. 7-8). Henry Holt and Co.. Kindle Edition.BOTTOM LINEAlthough I still enjoyed the book, I decided to reduce the stars to four after learning of some (only a few, but, still, it is supposed to be fact-checked) errors by the author. I still do heartily recommend it however.Four stars out of five.Did I address all the features of importance to you? Undeniably entertaining, the book discusses Trumpâ€™s first year in the white house, but honestly it reads more like a series of TV episodes than it does a critical analysis of the West Wing and the figures present. There was a passage describing how nothing gets done because no one is skilled enough to do anything that read like a â€œCatch-22â€ù excerpt, which was great and hilarious, but at the same time made me question the realistic approach of the book. I think that my biggest with it is problem is that it, very much like the Trump presidency, is searching for some television like narrative, Wolff wants media attention, Wolff wants it to be viewed favorably. The ending passage sets the seen for a sequel, Bannon standing on the steps of Breitbart waiting for vengeance, Jarvanka thinking they have secure placement in the White House, and Trump ignorant and degenerating. The thing reads like it was made for TV, or worse and probably true, that our reality is now more akin to television shows than it is to real life and reality is constructed with a deep regard for television. Read it, but be very critical, because this is what will be regarded, as some type truth.So as much as it is a sensational, biased, probably shadily-researched, cash-and-fame-grab, it will be accepted as some type of truth in contemporary political discourse.

Five stars to Wolff for being willing to report what others are not (or cannot, because they do not possess his journalistic instincts).Why are others not willing to report in such detail, as he has?  It is because they are afraid that no one would believe them. And this is a legitimate concern, because few in this country (even those who detest Trump) want to believe what is happening every day in this White House.  Perhaps Wolff's work (and extensive notes and tapes) will inch us closer to the reality.But all will still have difficulty accepting that it really could be this bad.  A constant, subtle strain of denial, disbelief, and looking the other way is the norm.  Why is this?There is one thing Americans are immensely naive about: mental illness in general, and the particularly common category called the personality disorder.  Few understand how widespread the various varieties are and how dangerous they can be (at work, at home, in relationships).  Instead, they are afraid of them (like mental illness in general) and look away.  They just don't want to accept that someone they thought they knew is not at all what they thought.The excuses and rationalizations are endless: "He must have a good reason." "She's just a little upset." "It must have been something I said." "I'll just explain things and everything will be okay."  We want to look the other way, completely unwilling to accept the bad news: that this is no longer a rational person with good intentions, someone capable of being self-aware, someone who will ever change.  We deny the damage being done, to ourselves, our careers, or our families, until it is too late and the damage is final.  And it is often catastrophic and irreversible.They are in all walks of life.  Many of those with the most severe personality disorders are your boss, or CEO of your company.  Many of them function well in certain roles, for a time, until their behaviors eventually cause them to self-destruct, but only after inflicting destruction on others.  And they take down those who "believe" in them, exhaust themselves defending them, who play along as if all of it is perfectly normal and rational, with just "a few bumps in the road".  These are the blind, the ones who hope that something good can come out of it -- something, anything -- until the roof caves in.Ultimately, this is not just about Trump.  It's about a bigger reality that involves millions of people: those with the disorders (and are roaming free), and those affected by them.  Every day, and often for a lifetime.I have some personal experience with this.  My family was in complete denial that it had such a problem on its hands.  All were subjected by one family member to regular screaming fits, paranoid accusations, and outrageous acts, over and over and over again.  We all wondered what we could do to help, assumed this person was otherwise "normal", and tried to tip-toe around it.  Absolutely nothing helped.  In fact, it got worse.  After decades of this, someone finally uttered the dreaded words: "It's a difficult thing to have mental illness in the family."  Everything changed for the better at that moment.As a companion read to Wolff's book, I strongly recommend another.  Without it, it is nearly impossible to appreciate what Wolff is reporting.  Written by a recognized expert in the field specifically for everyday people, it's calledÂ Difficult Personalities: It's Not You; It's Them.  Key point: they may not be in a mental institution, but that doesn't mean there isn't a serious problem that will bring great pain.  And you have to protect yourself.I wish I had read this book 40 years ago.  It would have saved me tremendous hardship in dealing with many people over the years.  And I think it will do the same for any reader.Do not look away.  Look directly at the problem.  Then admit there is a problem.  A very big one.  And it's not going to just "get better".  This is what Wolff is pointing to.  Compared to that, the details almost don't matter.

If you've been reading the news, then there aren't too many surprises in Michael Wolff's transcript of the clash of the Trump and Bannon egos. Bannon was a political arsonist who eveyone knew would burn his bridges when he left the White House. And in exchange for the access to the White House Wolff had gotten during Bannon's tenure, Wolff has written a book exclusively from Bannon's perspective. The book's only redeeming feature is to give an inside look, though seen from Bannon's perspective, at the complete disfunction of the Trump White House and an explanation: the dysfunction is intentional. Trump thrives on conflicts between subordinates. And in the period covered by Wolff, the three teams in conflict were Ivanka and her husband Jared Kushner (derisively called Jarvanka by Bannon and Wolff), former Chief of Staff Reince Priebus and finally Bannon. If you want the perspectives of Mattis, McMaster, Kelly or Tillerson, you will have to wait on another book, which is sure to come.

I'm not a Trump supporter, but I didn't go searching for this book to find "evidence" to support my personal feelings about him. I actually searched for this book out of curiosity. Several morning shows were talking about the book so I was aware of it, but when Trump was trying very hard to keep it from being published, I thought it warranted a closer look.The book itself reads like a thrilling political television series with a lot of twists and turns. That can be fun for some, but it made things a bit confusing for me. I wrote down a few side notes so I could make sure I was understanding every character and what was being said. This is a common style of writing for a book like this and there's nothing wrong with the style itself; I simply had to read it more slowly. I also rarely need a dictionary reference for books, but I did with this one. There are words both of a political nature and a very articulate nature that I had to double check on.Overall, it is an interesting story. It answered some questions that I had about Trump and his White House that either hadn't been answered before or that people simply wouldn't answer at all. These answers should count towards the validity of the book, but for all it divulges, there is still a lot left unsaid. Obviously, Wolff was not around at all times and could not answer everything.It is hard to put this book into perspective as a non-fiction about an actual American President who will go down in our Nation's history for all of time as one of our many Commanders in Chief. It reads more like a fast-paced, fictional account that someone could easily turn into a film or TV series and pitch it as a psychological mystery-thriller with an ambiguous ending that never lets us know exactly what the hell just happened and leaves us wanting more. We're not sure if our favorite characters are actually who we believe they are, or if the ones at the top are truly bad guys or a result of a series of unfortunate events and a faulty system.Since all of the book is based on interviews, point-of-view perspectives and direct quotes re-hashed from Trump's television appearances, I took all of the information from a neutral standpoint. It's the best way to read this book because you can easily get lost trying to separate solid fact from the appearance of fact. This is not to say that Wolff is lying. I believe he knew that this book would be heavily inspected upon release and he did the best he could to make it as perfect as humanly possible to avoid Trump's wrath. There are simply many things divulged through the lens of personal biases from the person speaking. There is no way to know for certain if what they are saying is absolute truth or what they think is the truth.I would not recommend this book for Trump supporters. If you are looking for something positive about him in any sense of the word, this is not the book for you. This was a bit of a concern for me because I do like books that tell both sides of a story. People both real and fictional are best when they are layered and it adds some validity to a story when there is more than one perspective. This is definitely a book where Trump is the primary antagonist, but it also appears that all those who surround him are antagonists in their own way. There are no heroes in this version of America.This book explores the modern struggle of Americans and the division of our country. It also explores what happens when someone with money and influence makes the choice to do something just to say they could and not because they really wanted to do it. There's a certain level of uncertainty that comes from that revelation. This book unearths a series of potential consequences that have happened and that could happen based on this choice. This book also leads readers to wonder how well we the people truly understand what goes on at the top.

Read this as an act of defiance, first & foremost, against an uninformed & unfit chief executive who believes he should be able to control the narrative. Read it for the delicious layers of dirt upon dirt. But most of all, read it to understand what it is we must dedicate ourselves as a nation to making sure never happens again.

While putting the events of the past year in an easy-to-read narrative has its merits, there really is nothing new here which hasn't already been reported on or couldn't be inferred by Trump's own words through tweets and speeches.

"Fire & Fury" (aka "The Fired & the Furry" based on the cast of characters) is amazing. I'm 2/3 of the way through, and this is absolutely the best slasher-horror-comedy (of errors ...so many errors) I've ever read. "The Fired" come off very badly, but "the Furry" (aka the Orange Dumpster, with, according to Wolff/Ivanka, a ring of fur around an inadvertent tonsure) comes off far, far worse. And of course the Not-Yet-Fired are enjoyably skewered too.Okay, so Michael Wolff has some known accuracy issues -- but even he can't make all of this stuff up. And regardless of whether only a sizable amount rather than most of it turns out to be true (or truthy), this really *is* the presidential biography/administration coverage classic of our times, and possibly the one that America deserves. We are, after all, embarrassingly enough, a country where a large part of the population believes Fox "News" and Limbaugh and Breitbart (and doesn't seem to believe in NPR/PBS, evolution, or climate change) -- so then, who better than the grand-standing and prone-to-confabulating Wolff to chronicle the posturing and falsehoods of President Dumpster and the, ah, trials and tribulations (may they be many) of his administration?So get your hands on a (library) copy of this now, and you'll be more entertained and/or horrified -- for longer! -- than when you first lost half a day to Angry Birds, or were just about crying because of the video of that starving polar bear.Grade: A (non-fiction and/or fiction); would read the sequel.

Nevertheless, it's bound to be interesting. Enjoy!

Anyone with half a brain could have deduced much of what is in this book by closely watching the Trump White House in action over the past year. It is a truly appalling administration, with a total ignoramus at the helm supported by greedy, grasping, and inept family members and a coterie of really stupid and ignorant aides, best exemplified by Stephen Miller, an alt-right nothing burger raised to prominence by a momentary lapse in judgment of the American public, aided and abetted by Russian interference in our electoral process.The book is moderately  interesting and confirmatory of what many Americans have already deduced  from watching the debacle that is our current president transact his first year in office. While the book has many sloppy errors, they are, for the most part, deminimis in nature rather than substantive. The author does have a somewhat awkward writing style, but one quickly gets used to it, and the substantive details ring true, consistent with the nightmare that the reader has seen unfold in our country  over the past year.  A pox on the houses of those who voted for the bloviating buffoon who now occupies the oval office. God help America!

This appears to be a well researched and crafted book. Never in history has a president given such access by a writer. As a reviewer commented, "even if  it is only 10% accurate, then it is good reading". Trump's personality has been exposed by himself and again by this author. In the book, he comes off more as a cartoon character than he does in personal appearances (TV, etc.). If exposed to this same, degree, then every presidency  would make similar good reading. I like reading about all sides of public personalities so I give this book a 3-star grade for presenting this author's viewpoint but not for much else. The further you read, the more he aligns with the liberal media so there is no way this can be a complete and accurate picture (no more than if Trump or one of his family wrote a similar book). How many people gave the much researched book "The Worst President in History" a top score?...Not nearly enough. Michael Wolff did a good job on the book, unfortunately within a year it will slide onto the deeply discounted shelf just like all the books on the Clintons and Obamas.
