The author mightâ€™ve been more honest with a disclaimer: â€œThis book is based on a true story or stories.â€ù Still, he did a very gossipy and readable job of piecing together all the clues he gathered. That's why to me it's both non-fiction and fiction, for he admits he guessed at a lot of the "truth" behind the gossip. That's good tabloid journalism.So what we have is a book purporting to be non-fiction but based on loose facts, hearsay and a conglomeration of conversations chosen to support the authorâ€™s thesis of â€œTrump stinks!â€ù Wolff himself admits that he often â€œsettled on a version of events he believes to be trueâ€_. the almost samizdat sharing, or gobsmacked retelling, of otherwise private and deep-background conversations.â€ù  I love sentences like that!The author has an up on Trump in that both have a way with using direct talk. What Wolff has done is â€œtweetedâ€ù the weaknesses of President Trump into a catchy book. (That is a bit of sarcasm on Trump's Twitter habit!)Wolff has a set-in-cement agenda. If the â€œfactsâ€ù and hearsay support that agenda, then it is (likely) true. And it bears telling. For instance, there HAS TO BE a Russian link to the Trump campaign. And since the â€œfakeâ€ù media believes there is a Steele dossier, therefore itâ€™s worth telling as truth. And even if the facts support something positive about Trump, Wolff tries to turn it into a negative with an angle such as, â€œI canâ€™t believe this." That makes the book's theme consistent.Perhaps you'll laugh here and there at all the absurdities of White House intrigue -- that reminds me of Mark Twainâ€™s more literary book, A CONNECTICUT YANKEE IN KING ARTHURâ€™S COURT.

Fire and Fury is a gossipy yet fascinating peek into the behaviors of a petulant Trump and of the power struggles between factions attempting to curry favor and wrest control of the agenda - Trump (The Boss) vs. "Jarvanka" (The Kids) vs. Bannon (The Foul-Mouthed Hardliner) vs several other power players. It paints Trump as a weak-minded, empty suit with no guiding principles and no moral compass, easily influenced by the last person he spoke to or the last segment he watched on cable news. It reveals a disturbing shoot-from-the-hip style of decision-making that produced a litany of bad hires and misfires.Even if it's only 80% factual, I find it to be 100% plausible. While its fairly well written, I grew annoyed at Wolff's incessant use of French turns-of-phrase (jeux de guerre & noblesse oblige, among the examples) which to me seem unnecessary and come off like a college freshman wishing to be mistaken for an intellectual.

This is a poorly sourced, hearsay laden book that would get ripped to shreds and given a C- if presented as a final project in any top 500 journalism graduate school in the country. However, I very much doubt the author intended it to adhere to The Rulebook of Journalistic Ethics and Integrity. In short, it revels in being a salacious story about gossip and innuendoâ€”fitting quite well in our age of social media, aggregated and questionable sources, and our own attention span lacking president. In effect, it reads like an extremely long, multi-part post in Redditâ€™s /r/bestof section.Regarding the â€œtruthinessâ€ù and authenticity of the facts that lies within: yeah, I generally believe most of it is probably true. There is not much secrecy in the bumbling ineptitude of the Trump administration and the in-fighting that is hidden in plain sight. Rake stepping seems a constant favorite past time of our Dear Leader and his cohorts. Bear in mind, â€˜Fire and Furyâ€™ seems clearly on the side of Bannon, so I would certainly take any of his character opinionsâ€”particularly, of those he clearly despises (Jarvanka)â€”with a boulder sized grain of salt. Also, there are some factual errors that are troubling to say the least. For example, Wolff suggests that Trumpâ€™s father was definitely a member of the KKK. From my cursory research on the topic, this claim seems circumstantial at best. There are also errors in poll numbers sprinkled throughout the text.Should you read it? Perhaps, but donâ€™t expect anything terribly enlightening. If youâ€™re like me: a mainstream liberal who reads the failing New York Times and the Bezos Washington Post, I doubt any of this will be much of a surprise to you. What the book mainly does is sum up the top 50 forehead slapping headlines of this disastrous presidency in the past year, so if youâ€™ve been paying attention, youâ€™ve already read a version of this. I suppose it is useful to have a story arc within a single book that covers the first year of the Trump presidency. Had it been better written, properly sourced, and factually correct, it might have really been something.

I am certainly no fan of President Trump, didn't vote for him, and he appears to me to be impulsive, narcissistic and childish.  I find the policies that he supports regarding the environment, tax reform, health care and international politics to either ignorant, short-sighted and/or self-serving.  However, in reading this book, I do get the impression that he has not receive a fair 'shake' from the media and feel that he is not being treated in the same way as past presidents.  Do I think that this is unfair?  Yes.  But, do I also resent that he is undoing many of the President Obama policies that I supported and believed in?  Yes.  Do I feel that his arrogance invites these types of negative reactions towards him and that he needs a fairly large dose of humility?  Yes.Most importantly though, I feel that this book provides an outstanding insider view into politics in President Trump's White House as well as politics in the White House of previous presidents.  My conclusion from all of this is that politics is dirty, the leaders in our government are not looking out for the welfare of regular individuals, and that no president, current or previous, is any better than another.  These presidents are simply the face of a very complex political machine in the background that is constantly looking to shift wealth into the hands of the few.My hats off to Mr. Wolff for writing a hugely entertaining book that was easy to read.

In today's modern climate of intense and angry political polarization, it's easy for the lines between gossip, spin and contemporary political history to get blurred. So is the story of a deeply disorganized and dysfunctional White House told by Vanity Fair contributor Michael Wolff, in Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House reality, misdirection from manipulative sources, or the product of a vengeful enemy of the current administration? It's not easy to discern where Wolff is coming from, but his description of the current West Wing, in the words of one of the book's subjects, "makes Shakespeare look like Dr. Seuss".Wolff tells the story or a Trump White House as divided as the nation itself. On the right there is Steve Bannon and the Breitbart faction. In the middle is Chief of Staff Reince Priebus, representing the GOP establishment, and on the left, the president's daughter and son-in-law, Ivanka Trump and Jarred Kushner (dubbed "Jarvanka" by Bannon, a term adopted by Wolff.) Wolff describes the power struggle between the three factions, and the mercurial president who is at times dismissive and mocking of all sides. He describes the evolution of the disorganized organizational dynamics during the first year of Trump's presidency, including the controversial dismissal of FBI Director James Comey, the investigation into connections between the Trump campaign and Russians intent on assisting the campaign, and Trump's troubling agitation of North Korean dictator Kim Jong-Un.Wolff's portrayal of the Trump himself is a deeply troubling portrait of a megalomaniac intent on making sure that no one else gets too much attention or credit, who hates reading, who constantly mocks his staff in front and behind their backs, who chooses the wrong advisors and doesn't take their advice any how, and who has an unrealistic understanding of his constitutional authority.Wolff's epilogue is especially interesting, containing Bannon's predictions for the future of the Trump presidency (giving his odds for impeachment, resignation or survival), and the future of the alt-right in 2020.Should you read this book? That depends on where you are on the political spectrum. Trump haters will love this book. Trump supporters will see it as a political hatchet job. If you're looking for objective contemporary history, it's more likely that Wolff is closer to a Kitty Kelly than a Bob Woodward. We live in a time when it's becoming harder and harder to tell what's real and what's "fake news", but Wolff seems to have an impressive array of sources. The book is a product of its times. Those who relish this kind of thing will love it. Those who can do without hearing about Machiavellian political infighting should give it a miss.

Devil's Bargain, at least to me, if a far better book, at the very least in so far as providing sources.  If I reflect on the two books together, I am, of course, dismayed by the behavior of all concerned in the two stories.  One has to wonder about the future of our country if it is the case that the (relatively) unseen hand of a single, eccentric activist billionaire resulted in a such profound outcome.  Neither candidate struck me as suitable for the Office of the President, but living in NY, I could have voted for my dog and still, NY would have voted for the democrat.  I would love to see a quality, investigative deep dive done on the Mercers and their outsized influence on American politics.  To me, at least, that's the story we collectively need to be told.  F&F; is a worthy read, just don't make it the last book you read on the subject.

I have been reading the New York Times every day since my landing in New York 58 years ago. Michael Wolff, in his book FIRE and FURY writes about some events and individuals that I have neither seen in the press nor on TV. I have no way to verify how accurate the author is in describing or revealing his information. On page 20, Wolff writes: â€œTrump had a twinkle in his eye, larceny in his soul.â€ù I wonder if it can be proven that Trump had indeed stolen personal property.  On page 78 he writes: â€œIvanka Trump, talking loudly on her cell phone: â€œThings are so messed up and I donâ€™t know how to fix itâ€_â€ù  On page 145, In the Trump White House, observed Henry Kissinger, â€œit is a war between the Jews and the non-Jewsâ€ù To me, this sounds to be a questionable quotation. I do know and appreciate that Wolf is at liberty to harshly criticize Donald Trump, the current President of the United States as well as past Presidents. It would be inconceivable in undemocratic countries. I am a Holocaust survivor. At the age of fifteen, the Nazis detained me in forced labor and concentration camps for three years, my school years. I had neither books nor newspapers. In Poland, under the German occupation nobody would dare to criticize Hitler, or his cohorts, in public or in private conversations; it would have intrinsically be considered to be subversive.FIRE AND FURY reflects domestic political vulnerabilities. I wish that this book will not exacerbate the discord in the U.S. political system.

This book will play well with those who already dislike or distrust President Donald Trump.  Those who support him, or at least, are willing to consider him to have good intentions, will immediately suspect the authorâ€™s bias, which Wolff somewhat admits when he says he filled in some of the blanks himself along the way.Nevertheless, a few themes do come through:- Trump didnâ€™t intend to win, nor did he live a life planning toward the Presidency- This president leads by instinct- Those closest to the President wield the most power- The presidency is far more than one person- Trumpâ€™s family is not just his saving grace, they are part of who he is and who provides him balanceWith the right editor and co-author, this could have been an incredible book.  Historical context relative to past/similar presidents, and an appreciation for key military leaders (McMaster, Mattis, etc) would have added much-needed credibility.Overall, this book reads mostly like a loosely-organized compilation of gossip magazine vignettes about Trump and various members of his inner circle â€” with some great insight, but sandwiched by a whole lot of juicy, heavily-biased trash talk.  Itâ€™s worth a read, if only to see some inside baseball through an angry lens.One quote of a quote stood out to me as what should have been the central theme:â€œIt certainly is an odd circumstance if you live your life without regard for being elected and then get electedâ€”and quite an opportunity for your enemies.â€ù

Fire and Fury  Inside the Trump White House, by Michael Wolff  (read 6 Mar 2018) When I put my name in at the Library for this book I was number 22, but there was more than one copy and I soon had the book--though it was due in one week instead of the usual three.  The book has no footnotes, no source notes, and of course no bibliography.  I recognize that it is the type of book where some sources will not be wiling to be identified, but there are some things in the book which could have been and  I wish had been sourced.  It is a pretty startling book although I cannot say anything in the book surprised me since we have been listening to and watching the current  president for many months now.  The book tells much about Steve Bannon, apparently a source for much in the book..  On page 309 in the book it is stated: that Steve Bannon says he himself will run for president in 2020, and will be elected.  My first reaction was he could never be elected and then, with a shudder, I recalled that I thought the same thing in regard to Donald Trump in 2015. One should take care not to underestimate the stupidity of the electorate, I remind myself.

A brutal and scathing account of the dysfunctional rot that is the Trump presidency.  That the author was allowed such unfettered access to White House intelligence is a source of wonder.  So there are 3 camps: Jarvanka (Jared Kushner and his wife Ivanka Trump) representing the progressive right wing, Reince Priebus and Paul Ryan representing the traditional GOP Republican ethos, and Steve Bannon the alt-right provocateur whose moment has come. The political intrigue and shenanigans from this unholy tripartite are enough to make MacBeth blush. I would wager that about half of the book is fake news or conjecture at best, as the author could not possibly verify some information, eg what the participants of a cosy dinner spoke about.  Also, sentence construction felt convoluted at times, which does not make for smooth reading. The book ended on a ominous note - that Trump is only the first agent in a movement to expose the weakness of the Democrats and Republicans and to advance the cause of the alt-right movement. Trumpism is more than just Trump, and ultra nationalism is the way forward for the US. Steve Bannon is featured extensively throughout the book as the cerebral force behind the Machiavellian manoeuvres in the West Wing. President Bannon for 2020? The world should be so afraid.

First, this is a review of the audiobook.  I don't think that impacts my review, but in case it does, you should know that.Second, my review is not about the subject, Donald Trump.  I dislike (a mild word) nearly everything about him, everything he does, and every one of his hangers-on.  He makes me ashamed and embarrassed to be an American.However, whatever you think of our president (lower case "p" in his case), this is a horribly written book.  Wolff comes across as omniscient to the max; he knows the innermost thoughts of everyone in the White House, what makes them tick and what makes them ticked off.  It's a hard concept to express, but I've never encountered an author (other than someone who writes his own memoirs) as arrogant, but that is Wolff to perfection.  So, while I strongly suspect that everything he says is true, I hate the way he says it.That goes for his writing style as well as his content.  He loves lawyerly, complicated sentences with lots of appositive (?) clauses that he sets off with commas.  As someone who's practiced law for 40+ years and who's seen his unfair share of horrible legalistic writing, I can't say how off-putting this style is.  If Wolff thinks it makes him look erudite, he's wrong; it comes across (together with his tone) as pompous and inflated.The narrator of the book is bad as well; he uses very odd pronunciations in many cases (one phrase that sticks in myth mind is "ne plus ultra"; I can't convey it in writing, but he mangles it).  He pronounces Lewandowski as "Loovandowski" (I've never heard anyone else treat the "w" in the name as if it were a "v".  And so on.Finally, if you haven't read (or listened to) the book by now, save your money.  All the good stuff is long since out there, as Wolff, who appears to be as big a media whore as his subject, appeared on every TV show known to mankind, full of the quotes that occupy the last part of the book.
I just couldn't read any more about the moron. It was like trying to listen to his speeches.

And, truth is, no matter what I say, depending on where you stand, this is either tabloid trash or great reporting.  Worth a read if you want to know what all the buzz is about. In any world, about anyone else, the writing is cheesy and the author thinks he is the smartest man in the room and if I wasn't so interested in the topic, I wouldn't have bothered to finish this.

I never - but Never  - till now - buy what people tell me to buy, or follow the crowd, or go for 'best-sellers' - but this I could not resist. So I bought the Kindle version on Day 2 of the early publication.  I really have no way of knowing what is factual or what is fiction or what comes between, but whatever, it is a rollicking good romp for anyone who has followed news over the last 18 months or so. It is entertainingly written, and only a few editorial errors and typos- perhaps due to haste of publication.This Reality Show is being aired to the globe by a huge cast of unlikely characters, and is bigger and  - no, I won't say better - than any other on media channels over the past many years so why not indulge? thinks I. ( It says Format Hardcover on this review but I assure you it's Kindle I bought - Amazon take note! - or perhaps even Amazon verification process has flaws). The importance of Veracity went out the window certainly from the day of the Inauguration, if not a long time before, so don't let truth stand in the way of a good story and it's definitely that. To plagiarize the book and others: "You can't make this **** up".  People have criticized Wolff's integrity as a journalist and I have no right to comment on what is not in my field, but he does make for an entertaining writer. Surely this has to be the first of a Trilogy, If Wolff can get at least some of the inside gossip, and if the world is allowed to last long enough to see volumes Two and Three. I look forward to them!

Sadly for our country, Fire and Fury is a painfully believable account of Trump's farcical first year as president, during which White House staff "struggled to express the baldly obvious fact that the president did not know enough, did not know what he didn't know, did not particularly care, and, to boot, was confident if not serene in his unquestioned certitudes." Staff who dared to question his dubious decisions, failed to meet his ever-changing demands or--worst of all--simply failed to stroke his ego, either quit in frustration or were fired, contributing to the constant turnover and continual chaos in the White House.Although Trump's first year is history and a new cast of characters populates the White House staff, nothing has really changed as Trump's administration continues to lurch from crisis to crisis as created by the "flexible" and often mindless whims of the president.  As Americans, we can only hope our country can survive this aberrant presidency and come out of the experience a wiser, stronger and more united nation.

Fire and Fury, Inside the Trump White House is actually a pretty good book. Contrary to popular -- obviously unread --opinions, it's not just one big Trumpbash. It does highlight an incoming administration that was unprepared for the task at hand and it does go into some sordid details that were already known about the president, it doesn't spend a lot of time speculating about the Russian dossier or offer any validity into the Russian collusion investigation, it does highlight how the press and the intelligence communities can use this sort of information and ongoing investigations to destabilize a presidency. There is a great deal of historical precedence presented of how political players (aka 'deep state') have used real and/or imagined scandals to destabilize and control a regime. Trump has no real political allies and plenty of enemies.

Fire and Fury isnâ€™t so much of a history book as it is a very long magazine piece. That isnâ€™t a criticism. Works like this that try to give us a narrative of important events in real-time cannot be carefully end-noted historical pieces like something Doris Kerns Goodwin would produce. Instead, Wolff gives us a personal view of things with the characters on display, and their motives explained. Context is key, and Wolff gives us a compelling story we can wrap our heads around.Some have pointed out the few factual errors, the fact that the book does, at time, have editing that could have been tighter, and that it isnâ€™t clear where Wolff is using direct quotes. This might prevent Fire and Fury from becoming a definitive work for this administration, but it gave us a contemporaneous view into the administration that no one else has been able to do thus far.

Itâ€™s really funny to me that the White House is losing its mind over Wolffâ€™s book, when the first part in the book at which I said to myself â€œno doubt, Trump has dementiaâ€ù is when I read a verbatim transcript of the word salad Trump spouted at the CIA the weekend after inauguration. Thatâ€™s all Trump, folks. If he doesnâ€™t like sounding like an idiot, he should send himself a cease-and-desist.Wolff has filled in the gaps with some humorous narrative about the stunned reactions of everyone who has come in contact with Trump post-election, but really, heâ€™s not telling those of us who have been paying attention anything we didnâ€™t already know. Trump is Americaâ€™s dumb, mouthy, petty, lying, racist, senile, handsy step-uncle, who should really be in an adult care facility, but through a hilarious and tragic twist of fate, is instead in charge of all of our military and nukes.But the book is still worth the money - for the laughs and the delicious backstabbing among Bannon, Kushner and Priebus, as well as for driving the final stake through the heart of the unholy Trump/Bannon alliance.

I went back and forth on reading and reviewing this book. I try to keep my reviews free of politics, and I typically like to think of my opinions as balanced. President Donald Trump usually incites the exact opposite. Most people are either staunchly supportive of him in everything he says and does or 100% against him. There's little middle ground. Still, there is no denying that Michael Wolff's account of the President's first 100 days in office has become part of the national conversation. As a person who writes a weekly review of books, how could I not read one of the most buzzed about books of the year?!The President has brushed off Wolff's book as little more than tabloid gossip. To be fair to Mr. Trump, Wolff does little to protect himself from these accusations. Wolff starts the book by stating that the version of events he presents is his best representation of the truth based upon the varying versions he heard in interviewing White House staff. The varying renditions of events can only add to the confusion of where the truth lies. Further, Wolff never provides direct quotes or references as is the norm in other works of non-fiction.Despite all of this, the most incriminating portions of the book are directly quoted from the President's campaign speeches, tweets, and press briefings. To the approval of his supporters and horror of his detractors, Donald Trump has never been one to mince words. He says exactly what is on his mind. That being said, reading the often incoherent ramblings of the President printed in black and white can be quite alarming. These irrefutable quotes seem to support Wolff's claims that Trump is ill informed about most of the big decisions he faces.Wolff also touches upon the alleged disfunction among the White House staff. He maintains that the President's background in business makes him more focused on the "big picture". Because of this, the smaller staff positions that make the larger machine that is the US Government fucnction have not been filled. Beyond that, there is a war for the President's attention and policy that was between three sections of American Politics. Steve Bannon represents the interests of the alt-right of the Republican Party, Reince Priebus lobbies for the interest of the traditional/establishment Republicans, and Ivanka and her husband Jared Kushner vie for the more liberal interests. This collision of ideologies coupled with the President's lack of governing experience, Wolff conjectures, caused Trump to not achieve any significant legislative victories during the first part of his presidency.For as much media attention and hype that Fire and Furry has received, I was surprised at how little of the book was shocking or presented new information. Even the more inflammatory excerpts that made headlines are not so crazy. For example, one passage about Ivanka making fun of and describing the formation of her father's infamous hairstyle was actually a quote from years ago when she was a college student. History will ultimately be the judge of Donald Trump's time in office. Because much of Michael Wolff's more explosive claims are not verified by any specific source, I'm not sure that Fire and Furry will be remembered as part of that history. Rather, supporters of the President will likely not be swayed by Wolff's claims while detractors will use it to further fan the flames of their discontent.

Author Michael Wolff, the man on the couch, who just kind of hung out in Trumpâ€™s corridor amidst the hyperbole of unfolding Trumpismsâ€”was an indiscrete observerâ€”left alone to record the shenanigans. Apparently he had received the blessings and approval of Trump and Bannonâ€”who apparently assumed he was benign, if not a friendâ€”a recorder, who, would document the happenings and put Trump and the workings of the oval office in the most favorable light in his upcoming book. The book, titled Fire and Fury, would be more like a tabloid expose than a whitewashed testimonial to an enlightened Trumpian governance.Wolff just blended in and has sort of made sense of the carnage. The end product does not glorify Trumpâ€”a bit unflatteringâ€”but it didnâ€™t exasperate the festering scandal. The book, although amusing, was far more innocent than I had expected. It was not a scathing indictment of the evils of Trumpism, but more a testament to frivolity and incompetence. If you are looking for salacious and unmitigated scandal, it does not quite register; what you get is a prism of opportunism and a kind of oracle of incompetence and chaos.In a tale of two books, David Cay Johnstonâ€™s Itâ€™s Even Worse than You Think and Wolffâ€™s own Fire and Fury, we have two visions of Donald Trump. In Johnstonâ€™s book, Trump is a dangerous, psychopathic, aspiring dictator, while Wolfâ€™s Trump is more like a â€œplay thingâ€ù or amusement. The tone of Johnstonâ€™s book is seriousâ€™ Wolffâ€™s is humorous, if not frivolous. The events begin unfolding immediately after inauguration. America has just elected and placed in office a man unsuited for the Presidency â€“ an eccentric, billionaire-businessman who doesnâ€™t read books and has an attention span of about five seconds, or less. Trump seems to have set out to reconstruct the White House into an arrangement similar to his own Trumpian business-organizational model. Fire and Fury unfurls with a conversation between Roger Ailes and Steve Bannonâ€”a performer with charisma who, some think, leads Trump around on a leash. Apparently there is some animosity between Ailes and the other Fox News honcho, Rupert Murdock, since Ailes was ousted by the Fox management team. The Ailes-Bannon conversation suggests that Murdock is a moderate compared to Ailes, and wants to steer Trump toward Establishment moderation. Murdock has forcefully lectured the President about the oddness and extremism of Bannonism, linking Bannon with Ailes. (Page 47) Trump seems to be siding with Murdock, to the dismay of both Ailes and Bannon.Trump, the first Fox News President, ran a â€œBannon campaignâ€ù about nationalism. Contrarily, Bannon is now predicting a great nationalist rise by Chinaâ€”like Nazi Germany in the 1930s. Bannon, as campaign strategist, had devised a brilliant campaign strategy that targeted white, working-class malcontents in select rustbelt states like Ohio, Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin. Bannon had acknowledged that a win was unlikely, but he wanted to win. But the real idea behind the Trump campaign was to build the Trump brandâ€”to enhance his celebrity status so that â€œThe Donaldâ€ù was sure to get his own conservative TV network. If by some remote chance Trump ended up winning, Bannon could certainly take credit and his brand would also rise. For Trump and his closest advisors, excluding Bannon, the goal was not to win the presidency. For Trump, losing was winning. But a revelation had eclipsed reality. Winning the presidency was a total fluke, if not a joke. But it showed with great clarity that the American working class, especially in the South and Midwestern rustbelt, were solidly behind Trump and the Republican brandâ€”the party of the uber-rich and endless tax cuts for billionaires. Democrats had lost this demographic. Hillary Clinton couldnâ€™t relate to them- at least not to working class whites. Those â€œschmucksâ€ù took Trump seriously at his word. But Trump, in his own mind, by losing, expected to become the most famous man in the worldâ€”â€œa martyr to crooked Hillary Clinton.â€ù This might seem contrarian for a man who constantly casts aspersions at â€œlosers,â€ù but in this case, Trumpâ€™s personal brand would soar. As for his staff, careers and egos were at stake. Merely losing was good for them too: Jared, Don Jr., Ivanka, Kellyanne, Reince Priebus, and Melania. Trump, to some, was kind of like a slick salesman who was being set up to win. He craved media attention, but also loathed unfriendly press. It was all about him.Trump, a man with an enormous ego that had to be constantly stroked and soothed, sometimes relapses into an unrefined, petulant case of grandiose narcism. He sought recognition and good press like his yearning stomach craved a juicy McDonaldâ€™s cheeseburger. His presidency revolves around his peculiar relationship with the mediaâ€”particularly whether they were friend or foe. Trumpâ€™s economic nationalist agenda is being steered by Bannon, who engages in broadside attacks on the media. The media is the enemy in opposition to every minutia of Trumpâ€™s agenda with a conspiracy-like fury. The legislative die was cast as a struggle between two Republican factions: the orthodox Republican Establishment versus the Tea Party-Bannon-Breitbart wing of the party.Bannon was the brilliant play maker, the strategist responsible for Trump's victory--the sultry king maker; but he was under the wings of his sponsors--the Mercers--who held the purse strings and his destiny in their hands. Breitbart was also under the control of the Mercers; Bannon, merely the co-dependent Breitbart operative.It was not just working class whites who believed in Trump. Southerners, evangelical Christians, rank and file Republicans, indeed, virtually the entire Republican Party, even Wall Streeters, were deemed true believers or, at the very least, just went along for the ride. The results of the election (winning), instead, brought horror. Trump had unexpectedly won. Now, Trump believed he deserved to occupy the White House. The Trumpian business organization would be consolidated within the White House operation. Business and politics combined. The Trump organizational chart fills in the political chain-of-command. Almost guaranteed to create chaos. Trump had to be gingerly coaxed, contained, and cultivated by his handlers. Bannon, however, is a power player who cannot be handled.The Trump Administration, as portrayed in the book, is a spectacleâ€”one to fear with revulsion or enjoy with novelty and amusement. Trump is a loose cannon, ready to go off script any second. Rife with humor, the rancid cast of characters looking for self-actualization are also loose cannons. The book gives appearances that Trump is somewhat delusionalâ€”like when he saw millions at his Inauguration but â€œfake mediaâ€ù only saw some 250,000. This begs the question: Is Trump a con man or a shrewd manipulator? Or does he suffer from some kind of reality distortion disorder? It is Bannon that has reinforced his tunnel vision and clarity. The book poignantly describes Bannon as an interesting and mystifying figure, if not shady: â€œBannon was not necessarily a nice guy. Several decades as a grasping entrepreneur without a satisfying success story doesnâ€™t smooth the hustle in hustler. One competitor in the conservative media business, while acknowledging his intelligence and the ambitiousness of his ideas, also noted, â€œHeâ€™s mean, dishonest, and incapable of caring about other people. His eyes dart around like heâ€™s always looking for a weapon with which to bludgeon or gouge you.â€ùThis ominously funny book, full of arcane accolades and sometimes chaotic, is about the daily workings inside the Trump White House (or Trump property) under the cultish personality of â€œThe Donald.â€ù Palace dynamics and colliding personalities must be reconciled. It is a description of a work environment centered on catering to the needs and whims of Donald J., of palace intrigue and overt and covert posturing for leverage and influence over the center of attentionâ€”the President. In the Trumpian Court, it seemed the Emperor had no clothes. Let Trump be Trump was a common saying. â€œRancor between competing factions persisted.A sundry cast of players looked to gain the edge and Trumpâ€™s earâ€”a power struggle among the factions for control of the White House. The Kushner side believed that Bannon or Bannonism had pushed the president into a harshness that undermined his natural salesmanâ€™s ability to charm and reach out. Bannon and his ilk had made him the monster he more and more seemed to be.â€ù As Karl Rove had been Bushâ€™s brain, Steve Bannon was Trumpâ€™s brain, at least until he fell out-of-favor. Bannon operated under a chaos management philosophy. A power struggle between Bannon and son-in-law Jared Kushner developed.Trump didnâ€™t really wish to share power; his is an unconventional Whitehouse. One professional staffer, Katie Walsh, saw chaos, rivalries, and the presidentâ€™s own lack of focus and concern and elected to resign. VP Pence was probably the most emasculated VP in history. It was difficult playing second fiddle to â€œThe Donald.â€ù Pence seemed more like a mere staffer, taking notes at meetingsâ€”useless in the daily effort to help restrain the president and stabilize the West Wing. The Trumpocracy was a national spectacle. All unfavorable news about Trump is fake news or even abject fakery. To help counter this torrent of vulgarian dishonesty, Trump sometimes resorts to hyperbole. Does this book capture the essence of the Trumpian Oval Office? You read and be the judge.

This book was everywhere. Comedians were talking about it. Politicians were talking about it. Magazines and newspapers were talking about it. Trump was talking about it. Even the Grammys got in on it, with Hillary Clinton making a special cameo, during which she read excerpts from the book. It was supposed to be game-changing. Scandalous. Dishy. Controversial. It was making ~waves~. Hell, I even got unfriended by several people after posting status updates for this book! It was that #edgy.Naturally, everyone wanted a piece of that sweet, sweet edge.I'm a bit late to the game, since I got my copy from the library (curse you, waiting list), but I did eyeball some of my friends' status updates as they read the book, and their lack of "OH MY GOD, NO WAY!" was a tip-off that this book probably wasn't going to be the ##BIGSCANDAL it was being hyped up to be. Things rarely are. I think we all remember how disappointed we were when Rachel Maddow went on TV claiming to have a copy of Trump's tax returns that she was going to reveal, live, and it was just an old, already released copy from 2005. I was expecting that.FIRE AND FURY has two major problems: unprofessional writing and lack of cited sources. The former makes sense. The author/publisher apparently received a cease and desist notice regarding the book, and in a sweeping gesture intended to support the first amendment and the free press, they sped up publication, thus putting the book into the public's hands faster and thumbing their nose at the president (and also garnering a fair amount of publicity and demand, as well). But it means that the book is riddled with typos like this (although maybe not quite so unfortunate): Bannon was making his first official pubic [sic] appearance of the Trump presidency (130). The writing itself is a bit breathless and sensationalistic and kind of reminds me of GAME CHANGE, the book that detailed the campaign between Clinton, McCain, and Obama. Both books take an omniscient third-person narrator approach that makes the reader wonder, "How many liberties are they taking with the story?"Which brings me to the second point. I'm a chronic Googler. I like looking things up. When reading nonfiction about a subject I find interesting or relevant, I immediately jump to the sources listed in the book, for further research. It's how I was raised: to question, to be skeptical, to gather data in the search for truth in the face of salient evidence. In the back of my edition of FIRE AND FURY, there is an index - but no page numbers, and also no bibliography or list of sources. The lack of footnotes concerned me, as many documentaries in book form have footnotes after quotes or data that are then indexed in the back by chapter with a list of the websites, articles, and interviews that the author gleaned that information from. This book did not have those things, which I found troubling.As far as the content goes, it told me nothing I couldn't have learned from watching Seth Meyers or Samantha Bee, or picking up a newspaper (God help me). If it did anything, it only reinforced the suspicions I already had: that Trump appears to be a childish, inexperienced, paranoid, petty, narcissistic man who needs to be fed praise constantly and obsesses over any negative statements about his glorious personage the same way Ebeneezer Scrooge greedily counted his coins; that Bannon appears to be a crude and nasty man who dreams of isolationism and wants to take down the liberal party with the same sort of elaborate schemes that Bond villains used to try to take over the world; that Jared and Ivanka appear to be trying to play Good Cop to Trump's Bad Cop in a pitiful effort to out-class the sinking ship that is the S.S. Alt-Right Party, but are in it for themselves as much as anyone else. It's freaking ridiculous, and not a day goes by when I wonder, "How did we get here?"I'm as liberal as they come, and live in one of the most liberal places in the entire United States, but I will be the first to admit that this book had problems. And while I can appreciate the publisher wanting to support free speech and the free press, the move did appear a mite publicity-driven. I'm glad people are reading this book, and I hope that it will encourage them to ask questions, too, and maybe think extra hard about the people who are affected by such gross changes in government, but at the same time, I think that the typos and sloppy writing make it way too easy for the points that this book makes to be dismissed, and that feels like it's going to be a big mistake in the long run.But hey, that's just my two cents.3 out of 5 stars

I purchased this book from Barnes and Noble to read. All opinions are my own. I do not even know how to begin to rate this book. Fire and Fury by Michael Wolff. Here is what I will say.......As an American, the highest office one can hold is the presidency. Our President has an abundance of responsibilities to assume and a bunch of roles to fulfill. As humans we tend to view all authority as bothersome. No one in the United States likes to be told what to do or how to do by someone or a group of someones, so no matter who is our President, I guarantee there is some person or group that will have issue with him. So with that being said nothing written in this book made me like or dislike our President more or less. Donald Trump is not, never has been a politician so I do not find it shocking that his first months in office were chaotic for him, his family, people around him or the fact he had no idea who should do what in what position. What does shock me is the behavior of people who thought it would be different. When you walked into that booth to vote for President you knew exactly what you should or should not expect from the candidate you chose to vote for, and whether you voted for him or against him, if you had done your research before voting you would not be shocked by what is written in this book. I am not aiming for a political argument on my page nor am I going to disclose my political opinions with anyone. I am just saying none of what is written here shocks me. None of it. Take words written for what they are, words. Do not put your own opinions or spins on things and read with an open mind and I do not feel you would be shocked either. _Ÿ‡º_Ÿ‡¸_Ÿ‡º_Ÿ‡¸_Ÿ‡º_Ÿ‡¸_Ÿ‡º_Ÿ‡¸_Ÿ‡º_Ÿ‡¸

Clearly, if you are a Trump enthusiast, you might not like this. Read it anyhow.If you are anti-Trump in your politics? Read it.If you are generally bored by politics? Read it anyhow.If you're a political junkie? For sure read this.This is partly so that you can have some inkling of what all the fuss is about, and also so you can get a--and this is qualified--peek inside a government run by flawed people.All governments are run by flawed people, as we know too well. But this government is perhaps exceptional in that respect. . .Politics aside, this is an easy, and fairly quick read.I was amused to see that Wolff seems to have a pretty deft hand with political and other slang--which made the book feel chatty to some extent. Certainly it made it accessible. A bit like Stephen King's neighborly word-style.What to say about the content?Well, IF Wolff really did sit around the White House interviewing people willy-nilly as he says he did--as members of the Administration confirm he did--then it's even more important to read the book. If not, well, then I'd say it was still an interesting read and a down-to-earth sort of filled-in timeline for what's been happening (hirings, firings, general political sashaying and so forth) written in a fairly painless form.

Reading this book it like a roller coaster. I believed everything , why wouldn't i? Since crazy pumpkin is not to be believed.The book is pretty much Steve Bannon talking . It is unbelievable how some clueless and random  dude now lives in the White House. He did not want to win and it shows !!!

If you think you've seen or heard it all by watching the news, you couldn't have because in this presidency there has been ongoing breaking news daily since Trump's inauguration. In this book, Wolff shares his findings from when he had a ringside seat as to what on earth is going on in the Whitehouse. A play by play accounting is shared on the inside chaos that continues under Trump's regime and the shameful and clueless shenanigans that continue to go on - a good who's who in the zoo starring a plethora of unsavory characters.Wolff takes us through a sea of often clueless disarray and shares some intimate details about the president. Wolff shares that even Trump didn't think he'd win but had his defeat speech ready, he was prepared to say the election was rigged, how the Whitehouse struggles to function properly, and the many lies that the administration struggles to keep up with and cover up. This book is a frightening look into what has become of American government with said president.This is not a book that will make anyone feel better, but may give you a better understanding about how this presidency came to be. And even if you only choose to believe half of what you read, it's an eye-opener. #Recommended.

There has been no shortage of books about the Trump administration and the 45th presidentâ€™s peculiar relationship with his advisors already. What immediately made this one stand out and suggest extra credibility came from Trump himself when he attempted to have its publication stopped.There have been many fair criticisms of Fire and Fury. Itâ€™s very poorly written. The circuitous sentences often need to be reread before they make sense, and some still donâ€™t. It gives the feeling of having been written by speech recognition with little redrafting for readability.Far from being an anti-Trump hatchet job, the book is about as sympathetic to the man himself as any objective account could reasonably be expected to be. Ultimately, it makes it harder to dislike Trump. The picture it paints is of a manchild who only ever ran for president as a marketing and branding exercise. Then, when he accidentally won, he took a little time to convince himself he deserved it, but all he really wants is the prestige and respect of the office. This has led to a 3-way fight between spivs and opportunists from the Republican Party, the alt-right and his own family, to control and influence his perilously short attention span.As to claims about the bookâ€™s credibility, most of its assertions can be verified by reports already published. Those that canâ€™t are not enough to negate those that can. Even allowing for embellishments by the author â€“ and there are sections that are quite obviously embellished â€“ if even half of this is true, the Trump administration is pathologically amateurish. So much so that theyâ€™re probably less dangerous â€“ at least in isolation â€“ that many of us have feared.Having read Fire and Fury, I canâ€™t be as angry at Trump as I used to be, because it shows the president himself as being an irrelevant figurehead. The real question is whether the country is being run by the nationalists Bannonites or the Dunning-Kruger influence of Ivanka and Jared. The answer seems to be: It depends what time it is.
just a rehash of well known issues. attempt by a left wing "journalist" to discredit Trump. useless

In 1925 and in 1926 a potential political leader wrote down reasons for his interest in politics and a blueprint for a nation. People ignoring this book were surprised when they found the thoughts and ideas being applied.In 2016, following the expiry of the copyright held by the Bavarian state government, the book was republished in Germany for the first time since 1945The United States now has a political leader who is not afraid of writing down his blueprint for the nation.In the 2018 book â€œFire and Furyâ€ù author Michael Wolf has interpreted that blueprint as he sees it by quoting and interviewing several people who are supposed to be in the know.Even though â€œfire and furyâ€ù may suggest a cabal or hidden agenda, it actually just reads like any old evening news program of this time.For the politically charged in the left and in the right they might be able to read something in this book and say â€œthere I told you so.â€ùI found the only real reason to find to read this book was to keep politically informed of the time. This will also help keep one from being surprised when finding this leaders thoughts and ideas being applied.

I believe much of what is written in this book, because it corresponds with the news filtering out from the White House.  Wolff paints a picture of three cliques that are helping in the Trump Presidency.  There is the Bannon faction, the Republican faction, and the Jarvenka faction (Jared and Ivanka).  The sketch of the first year is of these three factions fighting each other for the policies of their respective groups and leaking news of the other factions missteps.  During the course of the first year, the Bannon and Republican factions were decimated.  Steve Bannon and the Breitbart organization provided much of the ideology of the Trump Election Campaign and the early months of the presidency.  The Republican establishment also was reduced in the stepping down of Reince Preibus, Shaun Spicer, and Katie Walsh during the early summer of 2016.I believe most of the stories of the early months of the Trump Presidency.  I hope that as the presidency matures, a more durable administration will succeed to these positions of influence, and come up with a capable government.  This book is a unique insight into the first year of the Trump  Administration.

In a way, I dreaded reading this book. Dreaded being cast into depression. Wolff, however, writes as a journalist, reporting what he has witnessed in a matter-of-fact style, which I appreciate.The events come as reminders, with no surprises concerning Trump's actions and attitudes. What gave me insight were the aims of those surrounding him. Bannon, Kushner and Ivanka, and so many others are new-comers to politics, and their inexperience shows amid the in-fighting and chaos that reigns as they try to influence Trump. Bannon encourages the worst in him while Kushner and Ivanka try to make him appear more presidential. The Republicans try to maneuver him. The president, however, is like a recalcitrant two-year-old, given to temper tantrums and an unwillingness to listen to experts and to learn. Kelly is no more successful in bringing order to chaos than any of the others. And so we cripple through year one of the Trump administration.Here is a worthy read, interesting, illuminating, and important.

This book very much reminds me of Ed Klein's books on Obama and Hillary. Both Michael Wolff and Ed Klein had very distinguished journalism careers and then found that gossipy books are how to really cash in. That said, this was an incredibly fun read. Team Trump--except for Steve Bannon--didn't think Trump would win. Trump was ready to launch a network from his fabulous publicity stunt. Then he wins. White House staffers fear him and talk about the 25th Amendment. Trump's weird reason for eating fast food and he never reads.  I give it 3 stars for being fun. If I thought it was reliable, I'd give it 5. Sort of like Klein's books with various "sources." Wolff and Klein seem to just reinforce beliefs their target audience wants to read. Giving people a basis to say, "I knew it, and this proves it." In the case of Klein, it's far right theories on Obama. For Wolff, it's just cobbling everything we suspect about Trump in one book. To be fair, Wolff had access to the Trump White House that Klein most certainly didn't to the Obama White House. Still, the bottom line to the writing are essentially the same.

It's hard to believe it's only been 15 months. Michael Wolff's deep dive into the people behind the Trump presidency is likely to be the most gripping read of 2018. Here's hoping it becomes a standard reading in college PoliSci classes.Michael Wolff starts out all the way at the beginning, when Trump first announced he was running for President. From there, he gives us the backstory on Trump's personal and business life, as well as the lives of all the people Associated with the first 8 months of the Trump presidency. Bannon, Priebus, Jared, Ivanka, Conway, the Mooch, Ryan, their all in there. The book does little to discuss policy on merit, such as the plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act, but it attempt to explain why Trump has done so many of the things he has done, like accuse Obama of wiretapping him. It's fun, and it's educational, making it a book I cannot recommend enough.

There are reasonable criticisms to be made about Michael Wolff's inside account of the first six months of Donald Trump's presidency, and I'm hesitant to trust any particular anecdote within. In general terms, however, the book paints a credible picture of the chaos behind the headlines: a temperamental president who didn't expect -- and perhaps didn't want -- to win the election, a neophyte political staff in warring power centers, and a top-down focus on television broadcast news over traditional White House sources of intelligence and expertise. Overall it feels less gossipy than I had expected, and particularly insightful into Trump's governing psyche. This is unlikely to go down as the definitive version of the historical record, but if taken with a grain of salt, it's a surprisingly worthwhile read for anyone looking to better understand this administration.

This book is a riveting, scary, horrifying, thought provoking, and sometimes hilarious narrative of  human foibles and American innocence. If only 10% of this book is true, we are in BIG trouble. First, this explosive book gets four stars instead of five because of a slew of grammatical and basic factual errors. This is likely chalked up to a rush to publication. That said, Wolff's book lives up to the hype as a re-telling of much of the turbulence (to put it mildly) of the first six-nine months of the Trump Administration. Wollf doesn't source anything - another reason for four stars - but he does get some explosive quotes, a few (most famously Steve Bannon) on the record. I doubt this book will be long remembered by history, because there will almost certainly be better written, better sourced, and more thorough retellings of the entirety of the Trump Administration someone in the not too distant future. For now, this is the perfect book to reflect on the wild and frequently panic inducing early part of this Administration.
An important and wonderfully written book. In such troubled times, journalism of the type reported here is a point of light in an otherwise all too dreary media landscape.

I really like the book.  It is really shocking all the things that he writes in the book. Itâ€™s a real eye-opener and to all the corruption that has been happening in government. This book, at least initially, is one of the funniest things Iâ€™ve read in a long time. This is not to belittle the importance to the world of who sits in the Oval Office. But the author himself draws our attention to the similarity of the farrago that was the 2016 American election with the show and movie, The Producers. When Trump stood for the presidency, it seems as though it was simply a giant PR exercise; he and his team expected to lose but the Trump brand and everyone on the bandwagon would become even more famous and important. Therefore, it was win/win. And the actual win surprised them all.With few in the West Wing having any political experience whatsoever, the whole thing was chaos from the start. Very quickly, the people around Trump realised that his temperament and way of doing things would become an exercise in damage limitation. Two factions rapidly emerged: Bannon, Trumpâ€™s de facto Chief of Staff (in all but name), a shrewd operator who believed in Trumpism and completely â€˜gotâ€™ his bossâ€™s strengths and weaknesses. And daughter Ivanka and son-in-law Jared Kushner, termed Jarvanka, who Bannon referred to as â€˜the kidsâ€™. It wasnâ€™t long before hostilities between the two camps reached boiling point.Michael Wolff is so adept at conveying the presidentâ€™s personality that one comes away from this book feeling that Bannon is not the only one who fully 'gets' The Donald. We see what makes Trump tick - and it's terrifying. With a swiftly changing line-up of personnel, it might have been easy for the reader to have become confused. But Wolff is supreme master of his well-researched material and he knows how to put the points across directly, with journalistic flair and a smart turn of phrase. On Trumpâ€™s reluctance to read, well, anything: â€œHe was postliterate â€“ total television.â€ù On Trumpâ€™s lack of appeal to the cosmopolitan elite: â€œHe was, after all, Donald Trump, however much you shined him up.â€ù Wolff is superb on the pithy explanation, here talking about Louise Mensch: â€œa former British politician who, now living in the United States, had become a kind of conspiracy-central of the Trump-Russia connection.â€ù On the short-lived Scaramucci who was, according to Wolff: â€œwired by events beyond his own circuitsâ€™ capacityâ€_â€ùFire and Fury may have been rushed through by its publisher; there are several typos in my (British) edition that let the author down, though I did allow myself a snigger when Bannon makes â€œhis first official pubic appearance of the Trump presidencyâ€ù. And talking of Bannon, whatever his politics and whatever we readers make of him, itâ€™s clear that nine times out of ten he was the cleverest one in the room. (I donâ€™t think weâ€™ve heard the last of him.) This is a really great book â€“ and as close as Iâ€™ve ever come to understanding chaos theory.

Thereâ€™s no joy in reviewing a book that is remarkably well-written yet depicting a train wreck both tragic and ongoing. Wolff is a fine writer; his tell-all is crisp and organized. He scored journalistic coups and amazing interviews/confessions from all sorts of inside sources. Key to his access is the fact that there were three bitterly competing power centers in the Trump White House: Bannon, Kushner, and Priebus. Two are already gone, but while the trio was jostling for power in the early months, they leaked against each other with a vengeance. Forty years ago, it was startling to read Watergate details from Woodward and Bernstein, where they had almost verbatim conversations where only two principals were in the room. â€œThe Final Daysâ€ù boasted long, detailed back-and-forth dialogue between President Nixon and press secretary Ronald Ziegler. How did two reporters get such a scoop? Plainly, realizing that he was part of an unfolding historic saga, Ziegler agreed at some point to share what he had experienced. On the last night of Nixonâ€™s presidency, he and Kissinger were alone in the Oval Office. Nixon wanted Kissinger to join him in kneeling to pray. After blurting out a confession, Nixon fell over onto the carpet, sobbing: â€œWhat have I done? What have I done?â€ù Itâ€™s strange, almost surreal stuff, and it happened! How would two reporters from the hated Washington Post have that? Well, clearly, Kissinger bared his soul and told them. Itâ€™s the same here. Especially in the case of the now-departed Steve Bannon, this reporter ended up with endless on-the-record gossip and tell-all anecdotes. Two generalizations are especially disquieting. First is the moral cesspool of the administration. According to multiple reports, â€œTrump liked to say that one of the things that made life worth living was getting your friendsâ€™ wives into bed.â€ù He referred to fired Assistant Attorney General Sally Yates using the crudest of anatomical obscenities. The second is a well-reported worry. â€œTrump didnâ€™t read. He didnâ€™t really even skim. If it was print, it might as well not exist. Some believed that for all practical purposes, he was no more than semi-literate. . . . He was post-literate â€“ total television. But not only didnâ€™t he read, he didnâ€™t listen. He preferred to be the person talking.â€ù An outgoing email got leaked: â€œItâ€™s worse than you can imagine. An idiot surrounded by clowns. Trump wonâ€™t read anything â€“ not one-page memos, not the brief policy papers, nothing. He gets up halfway through meetings with world leaders because he is bored.â€ù I wouldnâ€™t take the now disgraced Bannonâ€™s testimony for anything in the world, but perhaps heâ€™s correct in his final diagnosis. He predicted a 33% chance President Trump would be impeached; 33% he would voluntarily resign or forced to step aside by the Cabinet invoking the 25th Amendment, and 33% he would stagger to the finish line of his first four-year term. In Bannonâ€™s estimation, there was almost zero chance of a second Trump term or even a try for one.

I watched a video about this a few months ago. I was interested after learning that it was supposed to have a different release date. I figured that alone warranted a different release date. That and I also figured that would be a must read because, neither Donald Trump or his cabinet have done something resembling a good job.On that note, the author explained how his cabinet was assembled despite a lack of experience. In fact, Neil Gorusch was one of the few exceptions. However, I read nothing about how Betsy DeVos got her position just by donating millions of dollars.On the other hand, I thought there were aspects that could've been improved. For instance, I thought he could've elaborated on how Obama's image might've disadvantaged him. He stole from the DNC (an organization that's supposed to focus on helping Democrats get elected), and invited BLM to the White House, despite lacking the power to consider them a terrorist group. In addition, I also found silly terms used quite irritating because, this is supposed to be serious to the core.On the plus side, this helped me not feel sorry for James Comey for being fired because, he leaked Hillary Clinton's emails 11 before the election. I assume this prevented a landslide victory because, it worsened her image. In addition, I learned why he was fired. I found that somewhat eyeopening because, I always figured he was getting closer to the truth.All that said, it's explained in 300+ pages why Donald Trump has such an inefficient cabinet. Speaking of that, I found out about a 'Democrat', who I'll call KH, reveal that she's still going to rely on corporate donors.
