(They realized that his administration was corrupt from the beginning.)
wow. wow. wow.

It took me a while to get my hands on this one - I was watching the scandal around its release, and laughed my butt off when the publisher scorned Trump's threats and published it early instead. My copy finally came in at the library, and I've been reading it off and on for the last couple of weeks. I normally read books far faster than that, and it's not a long book, but I kept having to set it aside for numerous reasons.It could have benefited from more thorough editing - between a couple of typos, some odd grammar, and a phrase being repeated twice in the same sentence (I think the sentence may have originally been broken across two pages, so no one realized, and then in the final formatting it was all together) - it definitely had some technical problems.It was also just infuriating. Especially the beginning, where so many of the campaign staffers don't think Trump SHOULD be president, but still campaign for him because it's impossible that he could win, so what does it matter if they don't think he should? That was incredibly frustrating to read.Honestly there wasn't a lot in this book that I didn't already know, but I've been following politics pretty closely since early 2016. If you haven't, and you're looking for a good way to get up to date on current American politics, this could be a pretty good place to start. (Don't stop at this book, though, there's a lot that it doesn't cover.)I can't say that anything really surprised me. Everything sounds like what I've come to expect from this administration. The book is decent, but anything terribly salacious from it has been pulled out and splashed across the news at this point, so if you've been paying attention, I don't actually think it's worth spending your time on. It's certainly not the groundbreaking INSIDE LOOK THAT NO ONE'S SEEN HURRY AND READ IT that it was advertised as.

The book was made a success as soon as the White House and Trumpâ€™s lawyers tried to prevent its publication. But was it worth it? Is it worth all the interest it got for a couple of weeks, maybe a month?The journalism practiced in this book is first of all a lot too long. What could be said in twenty pages is diluted into one hundred? That makes some pages, many pages so boringly detailed with semantically repetitive elements that it could have been stripped down to one and only one expression.The second irritating element is that it is some kind of pseudo-fictionalized reporting based on a few facts, a few rumors and a few cogitations from the author but all in all little real serious factual objective reporting. Many of the elements put forward are hear-say and nothing but hear-say. It might be true the author was told this or that by someone who was a first tier or second tier witness of something. But it is unreceivable in court. It is hear-say.Then do we have to believe it? Of course not. But for some time these at times hardly believable pages become the latest gospel against Trump. But this gospel contains little. It is even less acceptable than the apocryphal Gospel of Nicodemus because Nicodemus was for most of the things he speaks of an attested witness or even actor of the events he reports. Michael Wolff is none of that.It is true it will satisfy the anti-Trump cohorts and it will thrill the pro-plotting-theory bigots since it will go their way. Trump is so limited at all levels that he must be the puppet of some manipulating Deus ex Machina that is of course not identified. So every version of the basic plotting theory that says everything that happens is the result of the decisions of a group of half a dozen obscure shadowy and shady people, will be nourished and nurtured with new allegations, hear-say assertions, and rumors.In one word this book should never have gotten the attention, care and promotion it got from the White House, except if Trump knows the basic fact that there is no bad critique or review, there is only high-sounding and noisy review or critique. This book is helping Trump occupy the front of the stage in the limelight for a few weeks and then he will have to find something else like tariffs on steel and aluminum. Make waves and it will leave an imprint in the sand of the beach all the bigger if your waves are really big.Dr. Jacques COULARDEAU

I wasn't planning on reading this, because I didn't expect to read anything that I didn't already know or suspect. But then the other day I saw it sitting there are my local public library here in Cincinnati, and I simply couldn't resist."Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House" (2018 publication; 321 pages) is like watching a train wreck: you simply cannot stop watching it as it's happening, and I simply could not put down this book once I started reading it. Much of what is in the book is, as I mentioned, already well known and covered in the media, but when you read it like this in one setting, it just makes you shake your head in utter disbelief at it all. Trump simply cannot help himself, which of course isn't an excuse for any of it. The misleading and the lying, the bullying, the megalomania, and most of all, the utter incompetence, in levels never seen before and never thought possible. I mean, compared to the Trump White House, the Key Stone Cops looks like top-notch professionals. Steve Bannon must rue the day that he decided to let author Michael Wolff more or less take up residency in the West Wing. Wolff has of course been attacked by Trump and others for this book, but it is undeniable that the overall tone of the book reflects more or less what is taking place in the White House. This book reminds me in tone very much of last year's "Shattered" bu Jonathan Allen and Arnie Parnes about Hillary Clinton's doomed presidential campaign, just riveting from start to finish.I have always been of the opinion that people get the politicians they deserve. And that is true for Trump as well. There is a segment in today's society that seems to hanker back to what this country was 50 years ago or so. Guess what: it cannot and will not happen! Time to move on. Trump is not the cause, but simply the symptom. For me the bigger test will come in 2020, when this country has the choice to continue the buffoonery that rules this White House, or decide that enough is enough, and go in a different direction, Meanwhile, regardless of your politics, "Fire and Fury" makes for riveting reading, and is a WINNER.

Appalling, but perversely fascinating.  Since the 'highest office in the land' has been turned into a joke, I guess one might as well get a little entertainment from it.  From what this book describes, you might actually make a case that the presidency is unnecessary, since currently there's nobody home there -- or rather, as one White House staffer puts it, there's "an idiot surrounded by clowns" -- and the government and the nation still kind of continue to function, sort of.

I admit to be being disappointed with â€œFire and Furyâ€ù.  Perhaps the book has been over-hyped.  Perhaps too much had already been revealed in the press prior to my reading the book.  Either way, I came away feeling somewhat deflated.Despite my disappointment, it was still fun to read the book.  Michael Wolff has an easy to read style and, indisputably, had extraordinary access to the White House, especially Steve Bannon.  Accordingly, we learn (or at least have our understanding confirmed) that Washington is being chaotically led.  The Trump White House is wracked by competing factions and there is no clear decision making or analytical process in place.  Trump is not making America great again; rather, he is diminishing the great republic.With â€œFire and Furyâ€ù, there is also a sense that the book has been rushed out to meet the publicâ€™s pressing demand.  This is probably true.  It means that the book is more a contemporaneous narrative of events rather than a considered analysis.  In due course, I hope that Wolff will publish and updated edition or sequel.At this stage, it is not clear how the whole Trump experiment will pan out.  Things can and do change very quickly.  However, it is difficult to see Trump covering himself with glory.  The man is too abrupt and self-focussed.  And, of course, there is Mueller lurking in the shadows. Yes, we live in interesting times.  Unfortunately, this old Chinese adage is meant as a curse rather than a blessing.

I'm only about halfway through the book, and maybe it will get better. The problem is that the book seems like a re-hash of things I already knew. Anyone who regularly watches cable news will know most of what is in the book. The few new things are pretty minor.

I decided to read this book because the author claimed that it would end the Donald Trump's presidency. I doubted this claim because to me it seems that Trump does things that should end his presidency on a weekly basis. Nevertheless, I decided to give the book a try. I thought that if nothing else it is entertaining to read about what a sorry excuse for a president â€œThe Donaldâ€ù is. This book solidified my picture of Trump and his associates, however, I did not feel that this book gave me anything new. Neither was the book particularly entertaining. I was even taken aback by the author's tendency to sometimes treat rumors as facts - making him look like the man he is trying to take down.I think this book could potentially be good to read for people who believe that Trump is a serious and intelligent politician who is just acting like a giant baby. This book will illustrate - through lots of dialogue and descriptions of interactions between Trump, Bannon etc - that the current US president is not at all presidential.Then again, I don't think people who have not already reached this conclusion will be swayed by this book. It is simply more of what you see on the news on a daily basis. Personally, I would not be surprised if Trump turned out to be a serial killer or a closet homosexual. If it was any other leader I would be shocked by the ignorant and childish behavior described in this book. But in this case, I merely think â€˜whatâ€™s new?â€™.All in all, this book wasn't bad, but I find it hard to come up with a single reason for why anyone would want to buy it...
Great!

Although Iâ€™m glad I read Michael Wolffâ€™s FIRE AND FURY,  I certainly  struggled to get though the book.  Some of his sentences were so convoluted and sprawling that I had to reread them a couple of times to find the subject and verb. No one should ever have to reread anything written about the first year of the Trump White House.  One time is surely enough. Mr. Wolff is very fond of sentences with dashes inside parentheses; but he sometimes uses them to his detriment. Here is a good example:  He starts  a long sentence with â€˜Jaredâ€™ as the subject, then gives the reader his long parenthetical filigree  and then follows up with â€œthat.â€ù Canâ€™t do that, Mr. Wolff. Thatâ€™s Grammar 101. And it is often difficult to know what pronoun goes with what noun.  In a word: a readerâ€™s nightmare.Wolff though is describing a nightmare. The early reviewers of course cherry-picked all the dynamite quotes.  While some of the dirt I found new may be old news to others, here are some of my favorite cherries:  Corey Lewandowski called Jared Kushner â€œthe butler.â€ù Trump could foresee his son-in-law as secretary of state. And Jared, an Orthodox Jew,  is also an Internet Unitarian minister and then can perform wedding ceremonies. (To borrow a line from Sean Spicer, I canâ€™t make this S up.)  Ivanka can see herself as the first female president.  Pence is the â€œweakest vice president in decadesâ€ù and â€œan empty suit.â€ù Kellyanne Conway is a â€œcry-baby.â€ù  Flynn is a â€œdrama queen.â€ù  Wolff sees Bannon as a  character for Richard Ford, John Updike or Harry Crews. (Someone will certainly have to explain that allusion to Trump.) And here is one of my favorites of many other things the author has to say about Bannon who always sees himself as the smartest guy in the room: â€œâ€™I know no Russians, I donâ€™t know nothinâ€™. Iâ€™m not being a witness. Iâ€™m not hiring a lawyer. It is not going to be my aâ€” in front of a microphone on national TV answering questions.â€ù And I had not read anywhere that Trumpâ€™s brother Freddy was in Wolffâ€™s words â€œby many reports, gay.â€ùThere of course are no footnotes, bibliography or names of sources in Wolffâ€™s book. But authors (try Bob Woodward) never include their sources in these kinds of Washington tell-all books. There are also incidents where only two people are in a conversation. Are we to assume that one of the two talked to Wolff? A page-line (246) conversation between Jared and Bannon is one example of many. With all Wolffâ€™s faults as a writer, he certainly can turn phrases and use language as colorful as that of the White House satellites. He is fond of the S word, and I saw a â€œwackadoo moment,â€ù a nice choice of words. And finally here is a paragraph about Ivanka and her relation to her father that requires no comment from me. â€œFather and daughter got along almost peculiarly well. She was the real mini-Trump (a title that many people now seemed to aspire to). She accepted him. She was a helper not just in his business dealings but in his marital realignments. She facilitated entrances and exits. If you have a D-bag dad, and if everyone is open about it, then maybe it becomes fun and life a romantic comedyâ€”sort of.â€ùAs other reviewers have said, if only a fraction of Mr. Wolffâ€™s book is accurate, the clouds are very, very dark. I just wish he had written it better.

While some of it is hyperbole.  It gives you a great insight into the "mind" of the cautionary Bible story that was, "elected"  despite the fact 10 million more Us citizens voted agaisnt him than for him.  Makes me glad that I have dual citizenship and was able to leave the US
Doesn't cite sources. But still paints a good picture of the chaotic things going on in the Trump White House

Lot's of incomplete sentences.  Parenthetical phrases on every page.  Run-on sentences. The author does this weird thing where he dividends a sentence in half, and sticks an explanatory sentence in the middle, separated by dashes. Very annoying.Example "This was a successor company to DEN, a dot-com burnout, whose principles -- including the former child star Brock Pierce who went on to be the founder of IGE -- were sued over allegations...." (page 55).Who writes like that?  And more importantly, what editor lets writing like that get published?The book is laid out chronologically, but jumps back and forth to lay out the background of the main characters. Including main characters that were discussed on page 1. Which is somewhat disconcerting.  Very choppy.That aside, a fascinating read if you can make it past the distractions of the extremely poor writing.  This should have spent a few more months with the editor, but they obviously wanted to get it in people's hands before they were fighting the restraining order in court.
Itâ€™s not a good book

I was eager to read this book because DT didn't want me to read it.  It was informative but I didn't particularly like the writing maybe because my mainstay is mysteries?  I am happy that we were given this perspective as readers so I would urge people to read the book for the content.

Fascinating peek inside a white house that is like no other. I think the contents of this book, although shocking, shouldn't surprise anyone who follows the news. I think the book, mostly about Trump. is also a look at those who are with him in the chaos and who it feels like have sold their souls to the devil for position and power and sadly care nothing about the people of America. Kudos to the author for great reporting and being able to hang out for as long as he did.

The forces that fought for control of this â€œoverweight seventy-year-old manâ€ù who had, against all odds, won the presidency, are on display in all their ignominy: Jared and Ivanka, Steve Bannon, Reince Priebus, Michael Flynn, and others. Outside the White house, Rupert Murdoch, Henry Kissinger, various and sundry friends he would call at night as he lounged in his bed eating hamburgers.It makes for a Keystone cop mess. In our White House.

As a card carrying Never Trumper, "Fire and Fury" is very entertaining but I find Wolff's credibility to be suspect at best. The "Game of Thrones" type battle between Bannon, Priebus and Kushner for Trump's ear is believable and there is plenty of Bannon dirt in here. The rest just doesn't seem to be backed up with much. That being said, if you can get past any issues with Wolff's reputation and the numerous errors, it's not a bad book. Just comes off as more of a trashy beach read than your typical political journalism.
I am not a Trump fan but this book is poorly written, fails to cite most of the authorâ€™s sources and isnâ€™t worth reading.

Itâ€™s the insightful thread of Trump revealed that makes you continue to read. It all seems credible given the through-the-looking-glass feel of the whole administration. The crazy leaking to undermine the internal enemies was wild. Iâ€™d almost begun to believe the leaks were coming from the Deep State!
LIES,, fabrications,,,  what a bust..,,, I ordered it to read / keep up on how leftists hate  Pres. Trump-- waste of time!!!!
Wolff made a pretty dime on a fable. Glad he had his 5 minutes of fame.

I laughed. I scoffed. I laughed again. I cringed.  And then I laughed some more. In an alternate universe, this would be an amazing dramedy. In this world itâ€™s simply hysterically horrifying... or maybe, horrifyingly hysterical!

The writer is prone to long sentences with many clauses and commas so Iâ€™m finding this isnâ€™t a fast read. So far, Iâ€™m into the first weeks after the inauguration, and itâ€™s actually been a bit dry. Bannon sees himself as a savior and all controlling puppet master, Jared thinks heâ€™s going to be very influential and important, and Trump is incompetent. Probably most of the bombshells have been covered on cable news. Itâ€™s interesting for background, but Iâ€™m having to take it in small bites. It appears a lot of thoughts are being attributed to others via clairvoyance as I doubt they can all be substantiated. I am not a Trump fan at all and believe heâ€™s an embarrassment in the White House, but I wouldnâ€™t have purchased the book if Trump hadnâ€™t tried to block it. Does that mean I can blame him for my poor purchase decision?

Like 70% of the country, I strongly dislike (despise, actually) Pres. Trump.  I also strongly dislike sloppy writing and writers that are too casual with the truth.  Wish I hadn't bought this.  You're not really going to learn anything you can't find on twitter and some things just don't ring true.  It's also somewhat poorly written.  Borrow it, don't buy it.  You know he's crazy, I know he's crazy.  You don't need this badly copy-edited book to verify it.

So poorly written and incoherent that I'm surprised the White House had trouble disputing what it says. Wolff constantly concludes a paragraph with seemingly unrelated, garbled points. The opening chapter was engagingly fly on the wall at Roger Aisle's dinner though what you get is no more than sugar candy. The next two chapters are a running account of how the campaign got down to serious business but nothing seems authoritative or thought provoking. Opening premise is that everyone thought Trump was a joke. Think we knew that. Painful to read because Wolff floats along the surface of second hand narrative with no interest exploring his material. Mostly a blab; written for money and no real care for discovery. Reads like a first draft. Maybe I'm not accepting of the standard for political books but this is an effort to read.
A juicy synopsis of the Trump presidency thus far. Much of what is written correlates with what we learn daily via the media.

Entertaining, hilarious, and at times simply sad and shameful.  The book is easy to read and follows the events as already have been reported to the public in some form, but does it great job of putting it all together so that we can never forget it.  Even if only 5% of the events detailed in the book are true about our White House and the impostures that inhabiting it at this time, that is more than any American should ever accept. The existence and experience of "Javanka", "Trumpianism", "Bannanism" and a President of the United States of America who cannot read, process, deliberate, and do anything more than satisfy his own psychosis is now a part of our American experience, memorialized in this quick read for our future generations.  I'm not a big fan of Mr. Wolf, but even if his book is mostly fiction, Mr. Wolf hasn't written anything in his that we as Americans do not already believe is most probably accurate.  Buy the book & decide for yourself.
Hate, hate, hate the subject matter - but an importnat read about the corrupt world of a budding Dictator and his posse of bad actors
Ordered in error, was looking for the hardcopy, for a friend. Please cancel this, don't know how to contact you, having no luck. Thank you.

I enjoyed "Fire and Fury." It's a fun read. Palace intrigues make great stories, and this one is very well written. But it doesn't address a lot of the important issues. It's amusing to read about the West Wing feuds, but we really need to focus on whether we can avoid worldwide famine caused by climate change or a nuclear holocaust over northeast Asia. However, if this book contributes to ridding our country of the Trump presidency, Wolff deserves a great honor. May it come to pass!

I bought Fire and Fury because of the hype and, frankly, I was expecting a gossipy and "trashy" piece of work.  I was wrong - so wrong.  This was an engrossing and enjoyable read.  Well-written and factually-based.  I have found myself mentally referring back to it as I read and listen to what comes out of the White House, trying to figure out who in the WH is leaking - or who DJT spoke with on the phone the night before.  It was particularly interesting to read the Glenn Simpson hearing transcript contemporaneously with this book.  It's very clear that the things being discovered about this president and his family are true.  We can play see-no-evil, hear-no-evil...but in the end, a fact is a fact - and fact is truth.Highly recommended.

Warning! This is not â€œfake news.â€ù The only way this sort of detail could be amassed is from the inside. See what itâ€™s like to be a fly on the wall in the most inept administration in American history. I could not put it down.

An incredible look inside an incredibly corrupt and amateur administration.  None of these people belong anywhere near public office, let alone mayor of a small town.  And our dumbest citizens put him at the top of the entire nation.  Good going, you clowns.  Is one of only a string of books that will detail the corruption and chaos at the White House.  Whatever Bob Mueller digs up has to be incredibly explosive, time will tell what damage it will to to this administration.

While an interesting fast read ? It reads more like a leaked by Bannon revenge tale. It makes Bannon seem far more mercurial than President Trump.  Despite what is touted as unlimited access via West Wing couch most of the information appears gleaned from existing articles, rumor, and insider anonymous whisperings.  Considering the authors reputation while an interesting read it's abundantly apparent he is targeting a biased readership he assumed lack critical thinking skills and will buy unsourced gossip as gospel reporting.  Considering the abundance of books with cited sources? One must read this with some degree of objective criticism. I would recommend waiting for the completion of Woodward's book which will at least strive to uphold journalistic standards.  This is more like the national enquired of non fiction.
I wanted to piss off trump voters and give this book 5 stars _Ÿ˜‚_Ÿ˜‚_Ÿ˜‚

Ever watched a movie because the trailers were so good and realized the trailers were the only good parts? All the good bits have already been displayed publicly. The rest gets bogged down by . . . well, let me explain. I know Wolf had to rush to get this book out before the timeliness of it lapsed but ...  the chapters are poorly organized and whoo boy - talk about run-on sentences!

What a sad and pathetic chapter in American history we have reached!  This disturbing book is a chronicling of most of the flaws and shenanigans of the current inept White House, and proof that we have lowered our standards bigtime.  Both the left and right should be concerned since DJT is not a traditional, stable Republican.  He is part of the alt-right reactionary fringe that is most capable of hurtling us towards a nuclear conflagration that could otherwise be prevented if a stable, competent POTUS and his staff were in power!  Even the 'doomsday clock' has been pushed up to '2 minutes to midnight', which is scary stuff indeed!  To further compound this scary predicament, Trump actually lost by 3 million votes, yet he has become the leader of the free world!  We need to get rid of the electoral system and adapt the popular vote only (even Trump himself said this during an interview many years ago).  But I digress...
It'a on the Kindle and will be read after I finish LEONARDO DA VINCI, written by the guy who wrote JOBS and EINSTEIN..(each of those a real genius).  I expect to enjoy with disgust when I read  F & F

I heard the author interviewed and following the Tweetstorm on Twitter, so I got a copy from the library. It's a very easy and quick read. Nothing new if you've been following the disaster that is the Trump White House.It's very amusing and a bit nostalgic to read about the chaos that surrounded the administration during the first nine months. Of course, every day brings new scandal that makes these events in the book seem like old news, replaced by today's outrages. The midterm elections in 2018 are going to be very interesting.

I found this book to be informative and interesting.  It took me a little longer to read the book than it should have taken because the author had so many modifying phrases, sometimes separated by commas, and sometimes separated by dashes.  With so many words between the subject and the predicate, I found that often I needed to read sentences two or three times to understand what the author was saying.  The author used some political jargon with which I was not familiar so that slowed me down a bit.  I found at least 10 typos in the book and think those should have been corrected by the editor.  At times I had a news program on tv while reading this book, and I found it amazing that today's news was often very close to the contents of this book.  Some critics have said that parts of the book are not true, but history will tell us the truth some day.
What a mess this is save your money

Long, meandering sentences and paragraphs necessitate constant re-reading in order to divine the point the author is trying to make.Most of the content was already out there via newspapers, TV and Trump's own voice via twitter etc.Best aspect was the explanation of the divisions between the family, the alt-right and the Republican establishment contingents.In the end the establishment will win because they are the ones who know how to run the show, draft legislation and get it through Congress. It's just a waiting game.Thank God for the checks and balances of Congress and an independent judiciary. The U.S. will survive.

I am posting prior to reading.  I purchased it because I was able to download a free copy and felt it unfair the author would lose out.  Even if it was garbage, it would be worth the money to ensure that the ability to publish is not interfered with.

This book, given the topic, could have really written itself. Instead he chose to use lots and lots of words that most of the US has never even heard of before (some arent even in English).  You eventually just get bogged down in at all. It's a shame because the stories are generally interesting. I'm not sure about the truthfulness of all of it. He refers to Trump as semi-literate barely able to read however trump stands there for an hour and a half and reads off a teleprompter that's not even directly in front of him like a book would be. Seemed to be able to read just fine.
Forcing myself to finish it. What did I expect from a Vanity Fair and Guardian "writer"? So many typos that I'd be embarrassed to publish it for that reason alone. Boring and hyped up really well!

From the author: "Many of the accounts of what has happened in the Trump White House are in conflict with one another; many, in Trumpian fashion, are baldly untrue.Those conflicts, and that looseness with the truth, if not with reality itself, are an elemental thread of the book. Sometimes I have let the players offer their versions, in turn allowing the reader to judge them.In other instances I have, through a consistency in accounts and through sources I have come to trust, settled on a version of events I believe to be true."Translation: this book is contradicts itself and is unlikely to be wholly (or even mostly) accurate.At first I was put off by this, however I don't think it's total BS. Exaggerated, likely. Entertaining, certainly. We'll see how well it ages.It does make a great gift for that person in your life who hates Donald Trump.

As Michael Wolff has said in interviews, almost everything in this book has been in the public record, depending upon your news source.  Although Trump's base will consider this book "fake news", it should be mandatory reading for our populace.  Reality TV stars with no political experience should never be elected President.

I read this in March 2018. By then, it was already outdated. As a blow-by-blow account of Trump's first year in office, this is a detailed-level look that political junkies will love. If you're not a political junkie, then you'll likely be satisfied simply reading the highlights which hti the news outlets the first week the book was out. Those highlights are enough and very few others remain otherwise. It's challenging to read a book in the middle of the administration the book is about and hear of officials who are no longer a part of the administration because so many have left since the book was written. The book is decently-written and seems to have a reasonable number of sources so I don't doubt its accuracy, it's just a very detailed view of the first year.
This $15 is a tiny contribution to freedom of speech and justice I hope..

I didn't think I would finish this book before it was due back at the library, but I managed. About three quarters way through the book, I thought I would give up because the same scenarios and responses kept happening.This book reminded me of a never-made eighties movie about the most unlikely, senior girl because head cheerleaders, and all the other cheerleaders do everything they can to either steal the position, undermine her confidence or flat out try to manipulate her. Think "Mean Girls" meet "Bring It On."The question I kept asking throughout the book, which was never fully answered, was, "If all the White House Staff is trying to manage the President, who is running the country?"Michael Wolff is an excellent writer; I recommend reading this to anyone who wants to know.
Haven't read it. Just bought it cuz Trump didn't want anyone to read it. I'll get around to it, after he gets impeached. Cease and desist this.

Read the book out of curiosity and can I say that it might be the most  poorly written and fictitious book I have ever taken the time to read.  Michael Wolff seems to be pulling situations from the White House and twisting them into completely different, tantalizing stories as a producer would do. That is great for an author who is touting their book as fiction but not so great for a non-fiction writer. As a long time customer, probably one of Amazon's most loyal customers, I have to say that someone is tampering with reviews to encourage book sales or propaganda.  There is no way that intelligent, educated scholars and avid readers would review this book as 4 1/2 stars and I am inclined to believe that none of the books reviewed on amazon will have truthful, accurate reviews now.  Amazon check yourself or lose book sales.

Yes. I actually read it in full (knowing to only really believe 50% of it). To Wolff's credit, it's a central figure in his crusade to change modern politics by purging the White hour of rivals, particularly Jared & Ivanka Kushner. Wolff's bias is not as gratuitous as David Clay Johnson's awful "The Making of Donald Trump", yet the recollection of outrageous conversations are believable (anyone remember Oliver Stone's 2008 "W."? It's like that, but not as stupid). Much of the interplay rings similar to the detailed description of of presidential biographies, yet Wolff leans a tad too far to the left in his subtext to be taken wholly serious - nevertheless, a solid "first draft" of President's Trump's era.

I purchased the audio version and must say, I have never enjoyed doing house chores this much. Time flew as I listened to tales of backstabbing and paranoia as everyone around Trump comes to the realization that they are on a sinking ship. We have definitely dodged a bullet by having such a thin skinned megalomaniac rise to power instead of a disciplined demagogue. Bannon, who clearly saw the characters in this tragic comedy for who they really were, was the closest he will ever come to power and this is a good thing. He had the darkest message but he was the brightest among the clowns who now reside at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. I can not think of anyone more deserving of each other than Trump, his family and sycophants nor can I imagine the daily tremors vibrating through the halls of the White House as Mueller delves into these charlatan's finances.  My hope is that this is turning point for America.  It is time to take money out of politics, reign in our war machine and fund the FBI and other fraud agencies to go after money launderers, lobbyists, propagandists and corporate criminals who have America teetering on a ledge.

I watch quite a few reports about the things that happen in the Trump administration and I have read the indictments and the Steal report so this fills in the small details that are really not of any legal value, but show the attitudes behind why some actions are taken and why some things are done.

This is the 1st book I read by Michael Wolff. I'm not really into reading about politics but I was curious about what was the big deal. Some of the facts I heard on the news but a lot of the facts I didn't know. Now I see what like hype is. Thank you Mr. Wolff for writing this book I'm glad _Ÿ˜_ I read it.
Seemed to be full of innuendo and hearsay. The author's bias was in full display.

I did not plan on buying this book! But just knowing that the Dumpster was fighting it so bad, made me want it. Just hearing some of the excerpts that was in the book, I already believe that the contents are true. I don't care if you are a Republican or Democrat, parts of this book has to ring true to you. And just the fact that the Dumpster tried to fight it, it should also ring true to you also.

I spent half the time horrified and the other half wondering how true this all is. They say truth is stranger than fiction, but all of this seems to stretch the bounds of strange.On the one hand, this was definitely pushed through very quickly, which the occasionally awkward wording and frequent typos can attest. On the other hand, this book puts the POTUS circus series of events, starting with the campaign and inauguration and moving through to October 2017, in a mostly coherent narrative.
The apprentice show has moved to the white house. A show like Seinfeld about nothing. What can we expect? Well. Not Seinfeld per se. This is more like keeping up the the Kardashians with a twist

I really enjoyed it.  It was unfortunate that all of the "breaking news" when the book was released broke at least 6 weeks before I got the book, so by the time I read it, it was old news with new scandals and horrors breaking daily.  I hope Mr. Wolff has done well with this book.  It came on the scene like gang busters, good for him!

This book is an easy read but I think Michael Wolff is an arrogant writer.  I majored in English in College and still had to look up words that I didn't know the meaning of.  There was one sentence that had so many words that I had to look up in order to even understand what he was talking about.  If he's writing for the masses, he should at least write in plain English.

*I listened to the audible version*The narration for this book was really good and I thought it added to the overall experience. It was a really entertaining read. I thought it was interesting hearing about the inner working of the White House. Well, maybe. Considering how unreliable every person in the White House is, it's hard to know what's true and what's not! It's best to take what's in this book with a grain of salt. Very fun read, though!

Michael Wolffâ€™s Fire and Fury takes the reader on his journey as he exposes the reality of the Trump White House. The dysfunctional West Wing has been exposed. It appears that his staff was willing to talk and reveal the frightening truth behind @realdonaldtrump. Trump does not have a moral compass. A must read for any political junkie.

I totally hated this book but my inability to stop reading a boik before the end is well known.I find the â€œarchnessâ€ù so very annoying. And also the feeling of being â€œallowedâ€ù in to find out what is going on offensive.Notwithstanding my dislike of politics this book went way too far.  Tonight is the â€œState of the Unionâ€ù address. I may just watch to see how it gets messed up.
If you are a "Trumper" then I'm sure you think everyone quoted in this book is lying.  Really?  Everyone?  What a mess for this country.

Hopefully the success of this book will motivate other revealing books, and maybe people will not be so afraid to speak up.  It is not an "easy read".  I never watch soap operas on TV, and reading this book is  worse than the sleaziest of fiction- because the Trump regime has the ability to destroy this fragile thing we call democracy.  Other reviewers stated that the book might embarrass the White House- NOT! They cannot be shamed and will not change their ways from a book. They will keep right on doing what they  always do- until they  are made to stop - or they stop making money from it.
A great read, found it tough to put down. Mr. Wolfe spent months in the White House with an amazing amount of access. What a strange trip that must have been. I loved this book.

This book should be read by every voter so they can gain a little insight how government really works. Elected government officials are no less more qualified morally and mentally than 65% of the population, the other 35% are Trumpidites. The book demonstrates how the 1% control and manipulate the 99% into doing their bidding. To them government is just a big board game where the players struggle for power to go along with their excessive wealth - not one smidgen of nobelesse oblige amongst them all. Term limits and holding elected officials accountable for their lies, broken promises and self-serving subterfuge is what this book cries for.
Team Trump is a disaster.  Man, are those people messed up!  Could not put it down and wish there were more.
The print is so small it is very hard to read effectively so I returned the book.

Michael Wolff's book reminds me of a Kitty Kelley tell-all with political overtones. Wolff has collected a lot of rumors and innuendos from people of questionable ethics and motivations. His writing is uneven and he could have used a better editor. Donald Trump has many flaws and his administration many problems, but the public discourse is not well served by this book. I read it because I like to be informed, but it did not influence my viewpoint of either the president or the people surrounding him. The nation is politically divided more than at any time since the late 1960's and this book does not contribute anything meaningful to the debate.  I cannot seriously recommend it.

I am not judging whether Wolff was truthful or not. But, he wrote this like a sensationalist tabloid gossip column without citing any sources. I understand why he would not explicitly disclose his sources, but I think he should have at least vaguely hinted or even said something as simple as whether it came from his observations or somebody telling him, and if so, whether that source witnessed it first hand or was telling a second hand story. And how does he know what Trump is thinking in an exact moment? Is he inside Trump's brain? Did Trump tell him directly? Did he overhear something? This book just gives Conservatives more leverage in the whole Fake News debate because Wolff wrote this book in a way that makes his information sound, frankly, like fake news. The book was disorganized and poorly written, frankly.And why is there such a fuss over this? Trump is an incompetent troll and a misogynist-- What a surprise!!

I had low expectations about this book, but found it very well written with detailed intrigue on the Machiavellian machinations inside the West Wing. I found myself looking up word definitions from the book. Absolutely riveting. Steve Bannon, Reince Priebus, and Ivanka and Jared Kushner fight for power. Funny dialogue and Trump's oblivion about many world events paint a disturbing picture for the country.

350+ pages of he said-she said and not particularly well told. Difficult to maintain interest in each and every interpersonal dynamic. All and all a sad state of affairs that our country is being led by a poorly prepared group of people. Sad.

Is it just me or is this a really poorly written book?"(Bannon) leveraged his gaming experience into using Gamergateâ€”a precursor alt-right movement that coalesced around an antipathy toward, and harassment of, women working in the online gaming industryâ€”to build vast amounts of traffic through the virality of political memes."  This book is  full of gems like that.
Interesting, fun, enjoyableGo read it nowBelieve it or not, still a good readTrumpers should read it too.

Usually when I pick up an interesting book I'll digest it in a day.  This one took me almost a month as I just couldn't bond with this author. I just found that I was reliving what I just watched on the news last year with little in the way of new revelations.  In addition everything I ready suspected "on the inside" was true so that left me with the author alone as the sole personality here and I found the delivery a bit uninteresting.  I'm pretty sure this book will appeal to the "never Trump" reader who's looking to affirm their beliefs.  For the rest who don't live under a rock don't waste your time.

It reads like a bad episode of "Law and Order"...very repetitive and way beyond the pale when it comes to the nature of the internal conversations. Either the principals are clueless or Wolff really did morph into a fly on the wall. That aside its a page turner!

Most of what was read in this book is pretty much common knowledge obtain and publicized during the campaign and the first year of Trumps presidency. The publicity leading up to the release is the primary reason this book sold as it did in my opinion. I feel as if the author, Michael Wolff, was more interested in putting his intelligence on display instead of writing about the Trump Whitehouse. The constant use of extravagant words or words not commonly used by the everyday reader was over the top. It felt to me like Wolff used a thesaurus to come up with words that the common man would have to use a dictionary to understand what he was attempting to say. I just didnâ€™t understand the use of words that are not used in everyday conversation other than Wolff trying to prove he was smarter than the common person. I guess what Iâ€™m trying to say is that I spent more time looking up definitions that I did actually reading the book thus making this an extremely hard and boring read. I would not recommend this book !
It was definitely over sold.

I got this book and I am glad it was written, as the people need to know about the terrible things being committed by this sub-human monster.I would also like to say that I believe that Trump's ongoing criticisms of Amazon and Mr. Bezos are no doubt, based on pure, desperate jealousy and envy. Deep in his dark, mediocre heart, Trump knows that compared to Mr. Bezos, he is just little, insignificant (money) change. However, unfortunately Trump is in a potentially advantageous position, where he can try to hurt those he dislikes because he knows that they despise him. With Trump, it is about getting even with those who do not support him and his ill-gotten presidency.The bottom line is that that type of harassment on his part, amounts to a blatant, but serious abuse of presidential power.I just cannot wait for his impeachment!!!

A compelling read and generally believable. I think Trump is the guy that Gary Cohn, Tillerson, et.al. described. Unbelievably ill-suited - and worse - to be president. But, Wolff needs to be read with some skepticism. In the end, he is probably 85% precisely accurate in general characterizations and even facts. So, the Trump crazies will jump on an overdrawn point, but the rest of us get the story.
The book leaves the reader with why trump should never have been president. How much is fact can be debated but the reality us it us what it is.

It is a boring book. While the material was interesting it was a chore to read through it. We all know Trump is a narcissistic liar with a foul mouth and all this book did was to confirm it with dozens more examples.

Whether you are Pro Trump, or Anti Trump, I believe this to be an eye opening book. The reader does an excellent job.Even elements that one might say are likely either fabricated, or exaggerated, its all easily believed.So, take the book with a grain of salt, simultaneously knowing, the bulk of it is probably believable. Especially if you've been paying attention to whats happened/is happening.

First of all my major peeve with the book is the timeline, which bounces back and forth - sometimes so quickly that it is hard to stay on track.  That said, the whole recounting(?), is truly terrifying, astonishing and disheartening. What kind of yahoo group lets a reporter sit in on strategic (ha) meetings without so much as an agreement??  It also shows what happens when real news and information gets hijacked by corporations for profit, dumbed down and piecemealed into sound bites for mass consumption.I listened to the audiobook, which I recommend, the narrator is great, and was truly entertained by the bulk of the story.

Fills in the blanks on what's been happening.  Not entirely well documented, yet way interesting and as close as anyone has reported at length and at a personal position, first hand witness. Very sad but glad I read it.
Poor choice of subject. Boring
Poorly written and extremely dull. Litany of name dropping and Bannon worship.

While I have no reason to doubt anything he says, the book reads too much like a novel to inspire confidence in its accuracy.  Don't get me wrong, much of what he talks about is well documented by reliable sources like WaPo and NYT, so I'm not doubting the veracity of his "facts," but a good storyteller could take the documented facts of this non-stop train wreck of a presidency and spun a good yarn, even including unattributed quotes.  It's as easy to interpret the motivation for this book as a way to make a quick buck as it is to believe he is giving us the straight dope of what's going on at Trump 1600.  The book begins to sound repetitious after a while, and most of the most interesting parts were released by people with advance copies before the book was released.  I wouldn't discourage a person from reading it, but my suggestion is to make use of your library card, not you credit card if you are curious.
trump is still president, so it didnot meet my expectations

Wolff was so emotionally invested in trying to create a "smoking gun" book to take down Trump, that he missed the opportunity to write something great- the story of how an intellectually incapable sycophant stumbled his way into being President, and his absolutely hopeless struggle to prove to everyone that he deserves to have the position.

Meh OK read. Decent read. If you are familiar with the inner workings of the presidency, it won't be a shock. I didn't find any of the revelations to be shocking or earth shattering. Politicians have to sell a part of their soul to be politicians.I'm happy that the Resident didn't block the book from being released. I don't think the people whose comments make up this book expected the mess they are making to actually end up in a book, since they thought they were going to lose anyway. I'm happy to say I did not buy this book. So I did not directly contribute to the money to be made from it. I say that because the conspiracy theorist in me won't allow me to believe the author got the unfettered access he had for nothing. I think a 'deal' was made for 'all access'. Still, in spite of the attacks on the author, there IS some truth to what is in this book. I will be generous and say if 1% of what is in the book is true, and more than 1% IS true, Lord help us.I was fortunate enough to borrow one of the first book copies that were available at my library. I have to say what others have said: reading this book is like you are watching a train wreck in slow motion --you can't stop looking. I found it mind numbing to read in many cases because of how much of a constitutional crisis our country is in. None of the revelations should surprise you given how much of the book has been talked about on TV and what is in the 24-hour media.No matter what your politics are, if you aren't uncomfortable in some way about this administration, you are wealthy, you don't care, or you aren't paying attention. There's nothing this administration is doing that doesn't hurt the average American, meaning those of us who aren't rich in some way. I suggest you read the book and as you do ask yourself 'Are these people who I want to represent me?' Then do your civic duty and vote for someone with a spine and a conscience. If nothing else is to be gained at this time, this book helps you get your mind around the fact that the Presidency as we knew it does not exist...until this administration ends.

If one reads this with an open mind rather than an ideological bias, you'll soon discover that the big winner here is Michael Wolff.  Not only did he publicly admit that he wasn't sure what was true and what was either false, conjecture, or opinion, he told us this was largely fiction with a not so well cloaked veil in the first 25 pages or so.  He said that the press had ALWAYS given accolades and positive treatment to a new president--the first time they did not was with Donald Trump.  Ha!  Many readers will remember how the press treated G.W. Bush from day one, actually before the election, and I'm old enough to remember the fire and fury the press gave Ronald Reagan. At the time, I had been working for Jimmy Carter traveling the region setting up campaign booths and forums, and I well remember how the vicious comments about Reagan somewhat softened the blow of us losing the second term. So, with some clouded honestly, right there he told us this book was not to be regarded as factual.And, for fiction, I actually enjoyed it. It's so removed from what has been known to us previously as the current White House reality that even a stalwart Trump fan should not be offended. Nor should a neverTrumper or solid Democrat think this book is going to make a particle of difference in the coming years and elections. It won't because it's narrative and mostly fiction--we don't know what could be true as there's no sourcing.As a non-fiction publisher, I admire Wolff's execution of a fast money publishing plan. He certainly knew his market, and that this market was less interested in facts, sourcing, and evidence of truth in statements, and far more interested in confirmation bias content. And, that's OK from an enterprise point of view, and that's partially why he gets three stars, even in the face of largely fictional and sometimes fraudulent content.One reviewer mentioned he uses $5 words when a $.05 word would suffice, and I'll agree that was annoying. Others have complained about editing, and that publication phase was apparently all but absent; the errors are glaring. His writing, although it does not flow well, nor is any chronology evident, is typical of a pulp fiction detective novel, which I do enjoy on occasion.I don't feel cheated from buying the book, as this isn't Wolff's first rodeo, and the writing is not atypical of his previous works. His "insider secrets" never are, and his conclusions are always subjective and always lacking sourcing. Still, he's fun to read and he's a pretty good story teller.Vegans need not apply--this is USDA red meat, Select grade.
Interesting but even though I donâ€™t care for Trump I donâ€™t like the author being unfair about his purpose of writing the book!

For those that don't know: The entire content of the book is actually old news, stories that only had a single, shaky source, and thus were not ran by larger media outlets. Wolfe consolidated these stories, and then set out to create a meager impression that he had a source in the white house who could confirm all these accounts, probably knowing he had a good enough lawyer to avoid getting his bluff called on the second source. More of a sneaky entrepreneurial move than authorship. All that being said, since these stories were at the bottom of my daily news feed, I hadn't read past the tagline of most of them, and Wolfe did a fairly good job of plucking these out and assembling them into a list.

Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House - Michael WolffWith all the Fury surrounding "Fire and Fury"  one ends up feeling as if weather forecasters had been warning about a category 5 hurricane looming and experiencing a tropical storm.I can not help but ponder if my indifference was more  related to the my following the horror of the last of the last year or the hype.Upon completion , Wolff's introduction made much more sense. Cover your bases. A non fiction book that starts off with this may have kinda of happened - a little bit -- sorta ought to have been a red flag.As an avid Vanity Fair admirer discovering that he had been published there was exciting.By the end of the torturous experience I reminded myself that he was only a contributor, on occasion.Fury, might have been, months ago, an interesting magazine feature - its appearance, now, between two covers is nothing other than exploitation.On my end, my biggest shocker was that it appears that Wolff believed that it would be a revelation to readers that the president is severely impaired and not fit for office.That certainly is not news for the majority of purchasers.Many of us had enjoyed "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", and this certainly was not that.here is nurse Ratched when  the world really needs her?At times - often- it felt as if he was trying to reach a word count or something. It was often long winded and tiresome.It would behoove him to release a short snippet of the tapes he claims to have if he wants to continue his number one perch atop any bestseller list.I suppose I ought to take some responsibility here.  How Bannon being the primary source was not a red flag from the beginning is something I must own.Save your money-- turn on the nightly news (not Fox) and you will know as much , with much more sourcing than is present in these pages. You can thank me saving you the need to purchase an unneeded fire extinguisher..............................

If you value your time, read the excerpts variously published. The book adds marginal value and fails on several fronts.First, the book isn't particularly well-written. The prose is inflated, laborious to read, not the tight disciplined accounts we are accustomed to from wordsmith journalists. More the writing of a tabloid writer trying too hard to appear otherwise.Second, on the content side, the book is essentially a psycho-babble that is sprinkled with salacious quotes, some over-interpreted and others clearly speculative. There are many instances where staffers and friends/advisers of Trump allude to him in unfavorable terms ("idiot," "fool," etc.). If you've been in an organization, for a period of time, with underlyings and superiors, sometimes that's how others refer to you behind your back. Or, even in your company. It's not that uncommon. In many cases, this doesn't mean a whole lot beyond a temporary relief of feelings. The author makes too much of it. The book is organized around such quips.Sure, when it comes to the President of the United States, one would think that more caution and discipline would be in order. However, keep in mind that Trump has been a reality TV star for many years which breeds false familiarity. People feel they know him, they have a measure of the man, and are more prone to engage in discourse reserved for pals, colleagues, and overbearing bosses. And, certainly the oftentimes crass manner in which Trump expresses himself does not lend itself to an atmosphere of civility and decorum by those around him.The speculative component permeates as a narrative glue of the book. A mild example is the statement, "for many years, he had humored Trump more than embraced him" (referring to J. Kushner) which, obviously, no one outside Jared Kushner can truly know. I even don't know if I "humored person XYZ more than embraced him" without engaging in significant contemplation and reflection. Even then I might not. The book is replete with such speculative account.A second weakness on the content-side is the over-simplified superficial characterization of Trump as a person. There is a penchant for popular media, including journalists, to engage in a cartoonish characterization of Trump which should be left to political cartoonists and comedians. This book is no exception. We are inundated with personal deficiencies of Trump which have been evident, for all to see, from the moment he ran for office in the Republican primaries. Surely, the leaking of the Billy Bush tapes was horrifying (whether locker room talk or not) and would have sunk the candidacy of any other man/woman. How did Trump manage to get elected despite all that? His uniquely polarizing opponent, Hillary Clinton, had something to do with it. So did the concerns of the middle class that the establishment, Democrat or Republican, had not given sufficient voice to. But surely Trump, beyond the superficial characterization espoused in the book, had something to do with it as well.Distilling the information provided by the author, there is little insight. The author doesn't seem to know Trump. Nor have those who have been part of Trump's inner circle for many years confided in the author. All that the author has going are quips, anecdotes, and second hand accounts, from which he weaves a story consistent with the dysfunction and chaos we have been coming from The White House. Oh yeah, and the book's not particularly well-written.
Considering nothing in the book has been verified, it makes for one hell of a fiction novel.

This review covers both the Kindle and the Audible versions, as I purchased both of them.  The Kindle edition is one of the better formats, like the format for JB Bury history books, useful more on PC than Android, but tolerable on Android.The Audible is expertly read by Holter Graham.  I can't stand the Audible Player, which is totally dysfunctional. YOU CANNOT DOWNLOAD TO PC AS THE INSTRUCTIONS CLAIM, YOU CAN ONLY PLAY THE BOOK ONCE AND THEN IT WON'T STREAM AGAIN, YOU CANNOT PLAY IT IN CHROME, AND YOU CANNOT DOWNLOAD IT USING THE AUDIBLE DOWNLOAD MANAGER.  When it first sets up it offers Windows Media Player, but after set up you can't get the Windows Media Player. SO YOU ESSENTIALLY GET ONE READ AND THAT'S IT.  Considering the one read is more expensive than the book, who would want to ever use Audible again?  REALLY BAD PROGRAMMING AT THE AUDIBLE SITE.  HORRIBLE HORRIBLE HORRIBLE.As usual, the 'help' helps not at all.  Total waste of money if you can't play the book but ONCE and cannot download it!HOWEVER you can hear it using the Audible App for Android.  The app doesn't number the chapters rightly: to get Chapter 17, you must select 19.  But you can plug in a line cable to feed to your computer stereo speakers, and hear it. Which, was why I wanted it for the PC.  So I docked a star for the horrid Audible PC software.Hope someone will instead put this GREAT audio narration into WhysperSync, so you can hear and read it on Kindle at the same time.  Seriously, the audio is, if you can only afford one version, the one to get.  When Graham gets into the long passages pretending to be Trump talking, he gives the words a liveliness which makes you see how vapid DT really is.  Text alone can't do that.  If you READ what DT says, your eyes glaze over from his insanity. But when you HEAR them through Graham, you realize the Ruling Class (movie with Peter O'Toole) era we've gotten into, and your comprehension increases.The book itself is both famiiar and shockingly new.  Familiar, cuz all that stuff we heard said, is fit together coherently.  Shockingly new, cuz Wolff specializes in WINDOWING the POVs of the folks in the White House, so you see through THEIR eyes, how it looked and felt.  That's not a perspective I've found in the other books on Trump, and it's important to get a LIVE version of what it's like to literally be, 'a fly on the wall'.Many journalists are trashing Wolff.  They are wrong to do so.  You'll see why as you HEAR the book read.As always, yell at me if you disagree.  Feel free to call me names, I yell at myself all day long.

This book is nothing more than a rehashing of publicly available information about the Trump administration with a few shock quotes thrown in to get headlines and sell the book.  I'm neither a never-Trumper nor am I a supporter, and was hoping to gain some insight through Wolff's supposedly exclusive access.  Instead, there is hardly anything in this book that we didn't already know.  I suppose there is some value in hashing it all together in one place, but not a lot.  In addition, it's very poorly written.  Wolff uses hip-hop slang words like "dis" and pens confusing sentences like:  "She and Jared, or Jared, but by inference she too, were in effect the real chief of staff-or certainly as much a chief of staff as Priebus or Bannon, all of them reporting directly to the president."  Goodness, where is the editor?  Regardless of whether you like or hate President Trump, don't waste your money on this book, as you won't learn anything.

If I am wrong I plan on making updates, until then it's fair to gather opinions on both sides.

I voted for Obama twice and Hillary so with that in mind I think it is important that we read this book with a few things in mind.  Obama himself said he could not believe how limited the powers of the Presidency are.  The real machine in washington are the lifers on capital hill and I don't just mean the elected officials.  I mean the people who are retained across administrations that do all the support work on capital hill for our senators and congress people as well as the whitehouse.  They have long-term cushy jobs and are "not going anywhere".  By and large these are the people that actually run the country.  Sooo, with this in mind, after reading this book I am disappointed that this well known author would build this work based almost entirely upon hearsay and third-person rhetoric.  It's like he is playing to the crowd.  Hey, let's write another book about lambasting this President.  I cannot in good conscience actually say that Hillary or Bernie are actually better people.  The facts are that the economy is up $5 TRILLION and that we have experienced job growth in the last 2 months than the prior 2 administrations. The fact is that under the Obama administration we nearly doubled the nation's debt and put us at the brink of financial collapse with the loss of the American dollar as being the global currency.  If you do not have an indepth understanding of how things are really done, this book is believable and is more rhetoric that continues to drive a false narrative that continues to fragment this once great country.  Hearsay, rhetoric and a disappointing effort by the author to make money in this political climate when what we really need are facts and accountability on both sides of the aisle.

It would be an understatement to simply indicate that Trump demonstrates the characteristics of a short sighted, pompous ego driven narcissist; A conclusion easily reached by his daily Twitter rants combined by his apparent inability to intelligently string multiple words together and not sound like a 12 year old child.  I concede that he is far from presidential and further admit that he received my vote, not a vote of support but a vote against Hillary, basically the lesser of two evils.Michael Wolff's book adds little to my impression of the Trump organization but is an affront to my intelligence in his attempt to sell this rubbish as the result of investigative reporting.  Short of Mr. Wolff having a supernatural gift of clairvoyance and thought reading, it would be impossible for him to create a factual representation of Trump and staff as throughout the book he references the collective and inner thoughts of groups and individuals.  I suggest the reader highlight the terms " everyone", "they", "in Trump's view", etc.  Somehow Mr. Wolff is able to discern the unspoken thoughts of essentially every member of the Trump team, Trump's wife, daughter, son-in-law and acquaintances without them actually saying what is written in the book. The author liberally takes every opportunity to inform the reader what an individual or collective group of people are not saying but "believe", "think", "in their view", etc.While there may be much truth in the story that the White House is far from organized and the President has few redeeming attributes, this book falls short in meeting the standards of credibility based on well researched facts.  Mr. Trump's questionable character, demeanor and erratic behavior should give reason for concern for our nation. The impossible perspective and insight required for Mr. Wolff to present this as a factual account of the Trump organization is an insult to any one of average intelligence.

Update:The Author gets 5 stars for getting the reaction he wanted by his readers. But, as you can see in the news today. This work is fiction. I will be getting a refund, and am dropping my stars to 1 as Steve Bannon has made a statement. Enjoy your book!"Bannon said in the statement to Axios that his comments about the Russia meeting were aimed at Paul Manafort, the Trump campaign manager at the time of the meeting, rather than Donald Trump Jr. Bannon is quoted in â€œFire and Furyâ€ù as saying that Special Counsel Robert Mueller will â€œcrack Don Junior like an egg on national TV.â€ù In the statement to Axios, Bannon calls the presidentâ€™s son â€œboth a patriot and a good man.â€ùThis book is Fiction and you are all falling for it. Suckers! =)From the author: "Many of the accounts of what has happened in the Trump White House are in conflict with one another; many, in Trumpian fashion, are baldly untrue. Those conflicts, and that looseness with the truth, if not with reality itself, are an elemental thread of the book. Sometimes I have let the players offer their versions, in turn allowing the reader to judge them. In other instances, I have, through a consistency in accounts and through sources I have come to trust, settled on a version of events I believe to be true."

I really wanted to take one for the team and pick this thing apart but it was tedious gasbagging and I fell asleep at about 11%.If you were a reporter for Newsweek or WaPo or something, and you were reading a story whose premise was that itâ€™s author was granted unlimited access to the WH and had concluded > 200 interviews after January 20th, wouldnâ€™t you ask yourself how the author managed to place himself in a conversation between Bannon and dead Roger Ailes where he was able to observe every sip of water and sideways glance â€” prior to when Michael Wolff supposedly got access to these people after the inauguration?It isn't even good for toilet paper if you happen to have bought the Kindle edition.I am dreading picking this up and finishing it even worse than I'd dread an HIV/STD test after an unprotected all-nighter at a brothel.
